Parts.Name: Thief Drone Bay
Parts.Content: Deploys [[Thief Drone|Thief Drones]].

Parts.Name: Wardrone Bay
Parts.Content: Deploys [[Wardrone|Wardrones]].

Parts.Name: XL Autogun Array
Parts.Content: After the XL Autogun Array falls to around 50% integrity, a log message [[GameText]]XL Autogun Array falls apart.[[/GameText]] will be shown. When this occurs, the Array will be destroyed and 4 [[XL Autogun Subcomponent|XL Autogun Subcomponents]] will appear on the floor around Cogmind.

Parts.Name: XL Autogun Subcomponent
Parts.Content: 4 of these are created when the [[XL Autogun Array]] falls apart.

Parts.Name: YOLO Cannon
Parts.Content: Rarely on firing, the YOLO Cannon will explode with the log message [[GameText]]YOLO Cannon suddenly explodes.[[/GameText]] When this occurs, the YOLO cannon and up to 3 other random parts will instantly be destroyed. Cogmind will also lose half of the current core integrity when this effect happens.

Parts.Name: Z-Drone Bay
Parts.Content: Deploys [[Z-Drone|Z-Drones]].

Part Groups.Name: Authchips
Part Groups.Content: Authchips are single-use items that allow printing the relevant type of item at a fabricator. They can be acquired at a [[DSF]], [[Garrison|Garrisons]], corrupted in [[Storage]] or by using [[Spoiler]][[GameText]]Force(Recompile)[[/GameText]][[/Spoiler]] on a fabricator.

Part Groups.Name: Relay Couplers
Part Groups.Content:
Relay couplers are used with [[RIF]] to enable special bot hacks via [[Datajacks|datajacking]] that particular robot class described in the couplers description.
Relay couplers will fry themselves when attached if you do not have [[RIF]].

Part Groups.Name: Storage Unit
Part Groups.Content:
Storage units expand a bot's inventory size by their listed amount. Cogmind has 5 innate storage spaces, but other bots can have a few builtin slots, or none at all.[[Table]]
Name|Storage|Mass|Equip Slots|Coverage|Max. Integrity||
[[Sml. Storage Unit]]|3|5|1|25|150||
[[Med. Storage Unit]]|5|10|1|25|250||
[[Lrg. Storage Unit]]|10|20|1|25|350||
[[Hcp. Storage Unit]]|15|40|1|25|500||
[[Huge Storage Unit]]|20|80|1|25|600||
[[Cargo Storage Unit]]|25|140|2|50|1000||
[[Humpback]]|30|200|2|160|400||
[[Vmp. Humpback]]|30|200|2|160|400||
[[Lightpack 2.0]]|35|5|3|45|*500
[[/Table]]

Part Groups.Name: Transdimensional Reconstructors
Part Groups.Content:
Transdimensional Reconstructors are one of the most common [[Alien Artifacts]] and can be found in a great variety of locations from different sources.

Attaching a Transdimensional Reconstructor consumes it and teleports the user and any part they might be standing on to an approximate distance of 32/64 from current position, depending on the range of the Transdimensional Reconstructor variant used. The direction of teleportation cannot be controlled. If a Slip Node is present on the map, Transdimensional Reconstructors will always teleport to one, regardless of the Reconstructor's range.

Using a Transdimensional Reconstructor also deteriorates core integrity by 5-10% of current. Parts, including any the user is standing on, are unaffected. The resulting damage does not appear in scoresheets.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Spoiler]][[Lore]]0b10 Records|Transdimensional Reconstructor[[/Lore]][[/Spoiler]]
[[Redacted]][[Lore]]0b10 Records|Reconstruction Test Results[[/Lore]][[/Redacted]]

Part Groups.Name: Transmission Jammers
Part Groups.Content:
Transmission jammers are parts allowing to limit consequences of your activity by blocking enemy signals. Need [[Line of Sight|LoS]] to enemy to work.
[[Heading:2]] List of effects [[/Heading]]
[[List:Ordered]]Block [[Distress Signals|distress signals]]|Stop [[Heavy]] reinforcements calls|Prevent [[U-05 Engineer|engineers from calling reinforcements]]|When paired with [[Transport Network Coupler|TNC] block [[Hauler|hauler's reinforcements call]] [[/List]]

[[Heading]] Tips [[/Heading]]
Most jammers have short range, so attention needed to keep enemies in range. [[Watcher]] and [[Heavy]] bots require special attention due to their big visual range.
Significantly decreases chances of small confrontation snowballing into big fight.
Limits consequences of mistakes during stealth, if you can deal with bot that spotted you. Gives significantly more freedom to stealth builds able to take on small groups of enemies.
If you can destroy [[Extermination Squad|extermination squad's]] leader without the rest of the squad seeing you, they might wander away.
Jammers allow you to force 1-v-1 fights via [[Line of Sight|LoS]] manipulation. Works best versus stationary bots like [[Caves|caves outposts]]. Alternatively, good jammer paired with strong [[Cloaking Devices|cloaking device]] or [[Exp. Transmission Jammer]] on it's own allow forcing 1-v-1 fighting by surpassing enemy's visual range.

Part Groups.Name: Traps
Part Groups.Content:
Traps are most often found in groups called arrays, and appear in a variety of layouts including rows, blocks or sparser "minefields". They are, however, usually triggered individually.


[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Traps[[/Lore]]


[[Heading]]Triggering[[/Heading]]
Moving over a trap does not always trigger it. The chance is instead determined by the form of [[Propulsion]]:
[[Table]]
Mode|Probability
||
 Overweight | 100%
||
 [[Treads]] | 100%
||
 [[Legs]] | 75%
||
 [[Wheels]] | 50%
||
 [[Hover Units|Hover]]/Core | 40%
||
 [[Flight Units|Flight]] | 20%
[[/Table]]
Note there are also multiple undocumented circumstances under which a trap may be triggered, not simply regular movement. Also, [[Stasis Trap|Stasis Traps]] are a special case and their chance to trigger is the opposite of the values listed above (Flight ex: 100 - 20 = 80%).
Some other ways to trigger traps include: 
[[List]]When corrupted, it is possible to accidentally trigger allied traps when moving over them, with a [corruption %] chance of triggering.
|Attempting to install a trap at a location that already contains a trap unknown to Cogmind will fail to install the new trap and trigger the old one, regardless of the old trap's faction.
|It is possible to manually trigger known traps, although doing this will attribute all alert generated by explosive traps to Cogmind, unlike the methods listed above.
|EM explosions have a chance to trigger any traps they hit. [[Sub]](Note: The writer of this is not sure if an EM explosion attributed to Cogmind would cause explosive traps triggered that way to also be attributed Cogmind)[[/Sub]][[/List]]

Once triggered, the trap at that position is spent and will not trigger again. (Some traps exhibit special behavior in this regard.)


[[Heading]]Detection[[/Heading]]
Cogmind has a 1% chance to detect each trap in view, checked every turn, and each active Trap Scanner [[Comment]]and allied [[Drone Bays|Drone]], i think? I can't find the source i thought i remembered.[[/Comment]]has a separate chance to detect Traps.
Some other ways to detect traps include:
[[List]]
Successfully hacking [[GameText]][Locate Traps][[/GameText]]/Traps(Locate) at [[Terminal|Terminals]] will reveal all nearby trap arrays.
|In [[Garrison|Garrisons]], hacking Download(Registry) will locate all traps within the Garrison, among other things.
|[[Spoiler]]Using the [[GameText]]locate_traps[[/GameText]] on [[Operator|Operators]] with [[RIF]] in combination with a [[Datajacks|Datajack]] will reveal all trap arrays within a range of 30.[[/Spoiler]]
|Collecting a pre-expiry [[Operator]] [[Data Core]] will reveal the location of nearby trap arrays.
|Nearby allied Operators in range will reveal hidden traps within your field of vision.
|Some [[0b10 Decoder Chips]] are capable of passively detecting traps over time.
|Sources of Derelict intel can provide the location of all traps across an entire map.
|Using the [[GameText]]find_chute[[/GameText]] on a [[K-01 Serf]] with a [[Datajacks|Datajack]] will reveal the closest [[Chute Trap]].[[/List]]


[[Heading]]Removal[[/Heading]]
The simplest way to remove one or more traps is to destroy the section of floor housing them, for example using a [[Launchers|Launcher]]. Arrays of hostile traps can be permanently disarmed one array at a time via terminal hacking or [[Spoiler]][[RIF]]-hacking Operators[[/Spoiler]], and disabling traps on an individual basis is a possible side effect of attempting to hack one with an active melee [[Datajacks|Datajack]]. Successfully hacking [[Alarm Trap|Alarm Traps]] or [[Ambush Trap|Ambush Traps]] using a melee Datajack will always disable them.


[[Heading]]Reprogramming[[/Heading]]
Traps can be reprogrammed through various means, including:
[[List]]
Successfully hacking [[GameText]][Reprogram Traps][[/GameText]]/Traps(Reprogram) at terminals will reveal and reprogram a nearby trap arrays within range.
|[[Spoiler]]Using the [[GameText]]reprogram_traps[[/GameText]] on Operators with a Datajack in combination with RIF will reveal and reprogram the nearest trap array within a range of 30.[[/Spoiler]]
|Moving into a known hostile trap with an active melee Datajack has a base 10% to successfully reprogram it, increased by [[Offensive Hackware]].
|Having an active [[Trap Reconfigurator]] [[Exiles Vault Prototypes|Exile prototype]].
[[/List]]
From the [[https://www.gridsagegames.com/cogmind/changelog.txt|official manual]]:
By default traps are programmed to trigger on detection of any foreign robot, a setting that can be modified via hacking. Known traps may be reprogrammed with an active melee Datajack by bumping them, and entire arrays of traps can be reprogrammed at once from nearby terminals. Reprogrammed traps will no longer recognize Cogmind or allies as a threat, instead reacting to local combat robots. As part of the new programming, each trap's sensitivity will also be set dangerously high, ensuring it will trigger whenever a hostile moves over it, regardless of propulsion.


[[Heading]]Collection[[/Heading]]
An enterprising Cogmind can, with the use of a [[Trap Extractors|Trap Extractor]], extract and store or pick up friendly traps for their own use. However, Chute Traps, [[Alarm Trap|Alarm Traps]] and [[Ambush Trap|Ambush Traps]] cannot be extracted to begin with. Stasis Traps also exhibit special behavior; they can be extracted but cannot be stored inside a Trap Extractor, and they can still be extracted even after they were triggered, as long as the stasis field they produce hasn't been depleted.

Last edited during Beta 14.

Part Supergroups.Name: Hackware
Part Supergroups.Content: Hackware is a group of Utility parts that improve hacking capabilities, mainly success chance for terminal hacks, trap rewiring and robot rewiring. Hackware also helps you hack hostiles through the defense of a [[Programmer]]. Additionally, later Hackware makes it harder for your allies to be hacked.

Part Supergroups.Name: Infowar
Part Supergroups.Content:
Infowar (information warfare) is a general category of parts that revolve around gaining additional information about the surrounding map or its inhabitants and/or reducing the capabilities of hostile robots. Wandering around completely blind is possible, but can cause a lot of bad encounters and is generally very [[Community Challenges#No Info Only War|Challenging]]. Infowar can be used to do things like locate and avoid hostiles, search for specific elements of a map such as [[Interactive Machine|Interactive Machines]] or [[Exit|Exits]], and to generally navigate through a map more efficiently. Infowar is composed of primarily [[Utilities|Utility]] slot parts, although a few [[Alignment]]-related abilities can grant infowar-type effects without dedicating an active slot to them. The largest categories of infowar are bot detection and map detection.
Infowar is useful on all build types, from combat to stealth alike. Stealth builds tend to have many slots of infowar active at once in order to completely avoid all contact with hostile bots. Combat builds, especially on slower propulsion types like [[Treads]], have difficulty avoiding encounters altogether, even with a large amount of infowar. However, infowar can help make informed decisions about combat encounters and help Cogmind take fights in beneficial scenarios. For example, one good use is preparing an [[Explosive Launchers|Explosive Launcher]] if a [[Swarmer]] squad is known to be nearby. Blindly wandering around into that same Swarmer squad might see Cogmind in a bad position, forced to take damage while spend turns swapping out a launcher or becoming surrounded.
Many infowar utilities tend to be low integrity devices and should ideally be swapped into inventory before entering combat. High coverage [[Armor]] can help protect these parts, but even then, these parts tend to get destroyed fairly easily in combat. [[Utility Shieldings]] may reduce the need for swapping in combat, especially for a faster-moving flight or hover build that doesn't want to stick around for prolonged combat.

[[Heading]]Infowar Types[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:2]]Robot Detection[[/Heading]]
This type of infowar revolves around detecting bots before they are seen through normal [[Line of Sight]] mechanics. Being able to detect bots through walls, especially at a large distance, can be a large boon for avoiding unnecessary combat encounters.
[[Heading:3]][[Sensor Arrays]][[/Heading]]
Sensor Arrays are the most basic and one of the most common forms of robot detection. Lower rating sensors have a low detection radius, equal or smaller than the primary 16 tile line of sight distance, so their primary use is finding bots in nearby rooms or around corners rather than long-ranged detection. Sensors are best paired with [[Signal Interpreters]] due to their ability to distinguish between different classes of bots. They can easily be looted from [[TF Node|TF Nodes]].
The [[Active Sensor Suite]] is a variant of the standard Sensor Array. It combines both the sensor and signal interpreting capabilities into a single part. It also provides a unique type of intel that shows commonly traveled robot paths to points of interest on the map.
[[Heading:3]][[FarCom]][[/Heading]]
FarCom is not a part, but is a free source of 18 tile radius robot detection that can be acquired by using the FarCom Aligner machine in the [[Exiles (Location)]]. Unlike most other types of robot detection, FarCom can detect only combat bots and only in [[0b10]] controlled maps. While [[Mines]] is counted as an 0b10-controlled map, [[Caves]] is notably not.
[[Heading:3]][[Seismic Detector]] (bot detection)[[/Heading]]
The Seismic Detector is an indirect and somewhat unreliable source of robot detection. Grounded bots that move generate varying amounts of seismic activity that can be detected. Wheeled, legged, and treading bots create dark orange short, bright orange medium, and bright yellow long trails. Airborne bots cannot be detected by Seismic Detectors. They can often be looted off of [[T-07 Excavator|T-07 Excavators]].
[[Heading:3]][[IFF Parsers]][[/Heading]]
IFF Parsers are a basic form of robot detection. All bots are revealed by this part, although the type of bot is not revealed. Instead, the IFF parser reveals the faction of the scanned bot. 0b10-aligned bots show up in yellow while other bots show up in blue.
[[Spoiler]]
[[Heading:3]][[Quantum Companion]][[/Heading]]
The Quantum Companion is a unique weapon with many different effects. Some effects are not present on the [[Companion Sword|base form of the sword]], but only appear in the evolved Quantum form. One of these effects is a 12 tile radius sensor effect. While the range is very low, this part is unique in that it provides infowar in a weapon slot rather than in utility slots.
[[/Spoiler]]
[[Redacted]]
[[Heading:3]][[Sigix Exoskeleton]] (Robot Detection)[[/Heading]]
The Sigix Exoskeleton is a unique propulsion item. It has a large number of effects, one of which is an 18-tile range robot detection effect. All active bots within the range are instantly detected. This part is unique in that it provides infowar in propulsion slots rather than in utility slots.[[/Redacted]]
[[Heading:3]]Robot Detection and Patrol Navigation ([[RIF]] abilities)[[/Heading]]
Robot Detection and Patrol Navigation are abilities that can randomly be gained when using a RIF installer. Robot Detection grants the detection of any 0b10-aligned combat bot within a 24 tile range when a matching [[Relay Couplers|Relay Coupler]] is attached. Patrol Navigation grants the prediction of squad movement paths within a 24 tile range when a matching Relay Coupler is attached, although it only reveals the path of the squad leader. While these abilities can detect bots with the Scan Cloak trait, they will not work in non-0b10 controlled maps like Caves. They tend to be fairly unreliable due to the many different types of bots that are present in 0b10. Having a coupler for every possible bot type takes an unreasonable amount of slots.
[[Heading:3]][[0b10 Decoder Chip [Skirmisher]]][[/Heading]]
The Skirmisher, and to a lesser extent, the [[0b10 Decoder Chip [Generic]|Generic]] decoder chips, are two unique sources of bot detection. They do not directly reveal the class or location of specific bots like most bot detection sources. Instead, they can occasionally pick up the type and locations of patrol, investigation, reinforcement, and security squads and mark them as intel on the map. This effect only occurs in 0b10 controlled maps. This effect is somewhat unreliable due to the infrequent intel updates.
[[Heading:3]][[Triangulator]][[/Heading]]
The Triangulator is an extremely niche 24 tile robot detecting utility with one major catch: It can only detect robots that are currently tracking Cogmind. This makes it unhelpful for avoiding hostile bots in the first place. However, once spotted, it can be a helpful tool to shake pursuers on faster propulsion types. This makes it unlike all of the other forms of bot detection since they are proactive instead of reactive. The Triangulator also has other effects including hostile visual range detection and travel paths, but they effects don't actively help in detecting bots. It has no restrictions on bot detection and can even detect bots with the Scan Cloak trait.
[[Heading:3]]Robot Detection Infowar Comparison[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Category|Sensor Arrays|Active Sensor Suite|FarCom|Seismic Detector|IFF Parsers|[[Spoiler]]Quantum Companion[[/Spoiler]]|[[Redacted]]Sigix Exoskeleton[[/Redacted]]|Robot Detection/Patrol Navigation|0b10 Decoder Chip [Skirmisher/Generic]|Triangulator||
Range|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]14-20|[[CellStyle:Good]]20|[[CellStyle:Good]]18|[[CellStyle:Good]]22|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]16-26|[[CellStyle:Bad]]12|[[CellStyle:Good]]18|[[CellStyle:Good]]24|[[CellStyle:Good]]22|[[CellStyle:Good]]24||
Detect Bot Class|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]With Signal Interpreter|[[CellStyle:Good]]Yes|[[CellStyle:Good]]Yes|[[CellStyle:Bad]]No|[[CellStyle:Bad]]No|[[CellStyle:Good]]Yes|[[CellStyle:Good]]Yes|[[CellStyle:Good]]Yes|[[CellStyle:Bad]]No|[[CellStyle:Good]]Yes||
Ignores jamming/scrambling|[[CellStyle:Bad]]No|[[CellStyle:Good]]Yes|[[CellStyle:Good]]Yes|[[CellStyle:Good]]Yes|[[CellStyle:Bad]]No|[[CellStyle:Good]]Yes|[[CellStyle:Good]]Yes|[[CellStyle:Good]]Yes|[[CellStyle:Good]]Yes|[[CellStyle:Good]]Yes||
Bot detection limitations|[[CellStyle:Good]]Affected by Scan Cloak, requires [[Exp. Signal Interpreter]] but can detect dormant bots|[[CellStyle:Good]]Affected by Scan Cloak|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Combat bots only, does not detect dormant bots|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Grounded and moving bots only|[[CellStyle:Good]]Does not detect dormant bots|[[CellStyle:Good]]Does not detect dormant bots|[[CellStyle:Good]]Does not detect dormant bots|[[CellStyle:Good]]Does not detect dormant bots|[[CellStyle:Good]]Does not detect dormant bots|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Only combat bots actively tracking||
Slot requirement|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]1 swappable utility, optionally 1 unswappable utility|[[CellStyle:Bad]]3 unswappable utility|[[CellStyle:Good]]None|[[CellStyle:Good]]1 swappable utility|[[CellStyle:Good]]1 swappable utility|[[CellStyle:Good]][[Spoiler]]1 swappable weapon[[/Spoiler]]|[[CellStyle:Good]][[Redacted]]3 unswappable propulsion[[/Redacted]]|[[CellStyle:Bad]]1 unswappable utility per bot class|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]1 unswappable utility|[[CellStyle:Good]]1 swappable utility||
Alignment requirement|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Exiles|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A|[[CellStyle:Neutral]][[Spoiler]]UFD or scraptown attack[[/Spoiler]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]][[Redacted]][[Core Reset Matrix]] + Sigix Exoskeleton[[/Redacted]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]RIF|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A||
Update frequency|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Once per turn|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Once per turn|[[CellStyle:Good]]Realtime|[[CellStyle:Good]]Realtime|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Once per two turns|[[CellStyle:Good]]Realtime|[[CellStyle:Good]]Realtime|[[CellStyle:Good]]Realtime|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Infrequent|[[CellStyle:Good]]Realtime||
Map restrictions|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]0b10 only|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]0b10 only|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]0b10 only|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A||
Other limitations|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Can be difficult to decipher without a Signal Interpreter|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Can be difficult to decipher, many bots are not detected|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Can be difficult to decipher|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A
[[/Table]]
[[Heading:2]]Terrain Scanning[[/Heading]]
This type of infowar revolves around detecting nearby terrain, especially exits, rooms, and machines. Terrain scanning can make traversal through a map more efficient and easier. When combined with robot detection, hostile squads can often be bypassed entirely with a safe path out of sight.
[[Heading:3]][[Terrain Scanners]][[/Heading]]
Terrain scanners are the basic form of terrain scanning that reveal a random selection of nearby tiles nearby. The basic rate of terrain scanning is very low and only reveals up to a few tiles per turn. They can be combined with [[Terrain Scan Processors]] to dramatically increase the amount of tiles that are scanned per turn. Slower propulsion types tend to get more value out of terrain scanners as it provides more time for the scanners to do their work. A powerful enough processor can make terrain scanning fast enough to work well for even fast flight builds.
[[Heading:3]][[Structural Scanner]][[/Heading]]
Structural Scanners are a form of short ranged terrain scanning that operate instantly. When a wall is seen in visual range, immediately surrounding tiles are instantly revealed, including emergency access doors. [[Spoiler]]For the [[Deep Structural Scanner]], 3 tiles deep are revealed instead.[[/Spoiler]] Due to its cheap upkeep and instant scanning speed, it is a high value for faster builds. It is particularly helpful at locating short digs and emergency accesses between adjacent rooms.
[[Redacted]][[Heading:3]]Sigix Exoskeleton (Terrain Scanning)[[/Heading]]
The Sigix Exoskeleton is a unique propulsion item. It has a large number of effects, one of which is an 18-tile range terrain scanning effect. All types of terrain within that range, including hidden doors, are instantly detected.[[/Redacted]]
[[Heading:3]][[Machine Analyzer]][[/Heading]]
The Machine Analyzer is an indirect source of terrain scanning. It does not reveal random terrain tiles, but it does reveal most types of machines. Once any interactive or non-interactive machine is spotted, nearby machines are also revealed. If an interactive machine was spotted, the nearest machine of the same type is also revealed regardless of distance.
[[Heading:3]]Seismic Detector (terrain scanning)[[/Heading]]
The Seismic Detector is an indirect and unreliable source of terrain scanning. Certain machines will generate seismic activity that are picked up by this part. This only happens for a few types of non-interactive machines, and mostly in Factory maps. Interactive machines are never detected. This does not reveal any specific information about the terrain, but approximate room sizes and locations may be guessed based on the detected machines.
[[Heading:3]][[0b10 Decoder Chip [Scout]]][[/Heading]]
The Scout, and to a lesser extent, the Generic decoder chips, are two sources of indirect terrain scanning. However, their terrain scanning effect is very limited. Only exits, [[Garrison Access|Garrisons]], and hidden doors can be detected.
[[Heading:3]]Structural Interface  (RIF Ability)[[/Heading]]
Structural Interface is an ability that can randomly be gained when using a RIF installer that provides an indirect source of terrain scanning. Hidden doors and phase walls (primarily inside Garrisons) are instantly revealed on sight, similar to the Structural Scanner.
[[Heading:3]]Terrain Scanning Infowar Comparison[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Category|Terrain Scanners|Structural Scanner|[[Redacted]]Sigix Exoskeleton[[/Redacted]]|Machine Analyzer|Seismic Detector|0b10 Decoder Chip [Scout/Generic]|Structural Interface||
Range|[[CellStyle:Good]]14-30|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Visual range|[[CellStyle:Good]]18|[[CellStyle:Good]]Potentially Map-wide|[[CellStyle:Good]]22|[[CellStyle:Good]]25 (square area)|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Visual range||
Scanning type|[[CellStyle:Good]]Scans tiles at random in range|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Scans tiles just past visual range|[[CellStyle:Good]][[Redacted]]Scans all tiles in range[[/Redacted]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Scans machines only|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Scans only certain machines|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Scans only exits, Garrisons, and hidden doors|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Scans only hidden doors and phase walls within visual range||
Ignores scrambling|[[CellStyle:Bad]]No|[[CellStyle:Bad]]No|[[CellStyle:Good]]Yes|[[CellStyle:Good]]Yes|[[CellStyle:Good]]Yes|[[CellStyle:Good]]Yes|[[CellStyle:Good]]Yes||
Slot requirement|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]1 swappable utility, optionally 1 unswappable utility|[[CellStyle:Good]]1 swappable utility|[[CellStyle:Good]][[Redacted]]3 unswappable propulsion[[/Redacted]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]1 unswappable utility|[[CellStyle:Good]]1 swappable utility|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]1 unswappable utility|[[CellStyle:Good]]None||
Alignment requirement|[[CellStyle:Good]]No|[[CellStyle:Good]]No|[[CellStyle:Neutral]][[Redacted]]Core Reset Matrix + Sigix Exoskeleton[[/Redacted]]|[[CellStyle:Good]]No|[[CellStyle:Good]]No|[[CellStyle:Good]]No|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]RIF||
Update frequency|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Once per turn, very low rate without processor|[[CellStyle:Good]]Instant|[[CellStyle:Good]]Instant|[[CellStyle:Good]]Instant|[[CellStyle:Good]]Instant|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Infrequent|[[CellStyle:Good]]Instant||
Map restrictions|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A|[[CellStyle:Good]]None|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]0b10 only|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]0b10 only|[[CellStyle:Good]]None
[[/Table]]
[[Heading:2]]Vision Manipulation[[/Heading]]
Unlike the previous larger categories, there are only 2 types of vision manipulation. [[Cloaking Devices]] reduce vision of hostile bots and [[Visual Processing Units]] increase vision of the bot using them. While they function slightly differently, they serve a similar purpose of allowing additional exploration without being spotted by hostiles.
[[Heading:3]]Vision Manipulation Infowar Comparison[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Category|Cloaking Devices|Visual Processing Units||
Range|[[CellStyle:Good]]-2 to -6, up to -9 when half_stacked|[[CellStyle:Good]]+2 to +8, not stackable||
Energy Upkeep|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Expensive: -5 to -20 energy per turn|[[CellStyle:Good]]None||
Slot requirement|[[CellStyle:Good]]1 swappable|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]1 unswappable||
Other positives|[[CellStyle:Good]]Allows sneaking into areas guarded by bots without being spotted|[[CellStyle:Good]]Allows for seeing further in combat and sniping||
Other Negatives|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Low integrity/high coverage, no use if bots are already tracking Cogmind|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A
[[/Table]]
[[Heading:2]]Other Infowar Types[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:3]][[0b10 Decoder Chips]][[/Heading]]
While some of the decoder chips were mentioned in other categories, as a whole they're an oddball group. They tend to provide intel that crosses in between major categories, while also providing unique intel like part detection.
[[Heading:3]][[Drone Bays]][[/Heading]]
Drone bays send out controlled allies to explore the map. Basic drones can only be used for exploration, although other drones can be used for combat purposes as well.
[[Heading:3]][[ECM Suites]][[/Heading]]
ECM Suites are used to end tracking against Cogmind quicker. Each type of ECM Suite has a multiplier that makes hostile tracking less effective. Additionally, the [[Alert]] gain that occurs when a bot loses tracking on Cogmind does not occur when. While this doesn't help avoid bots in the first place, it is helpful for losing pursuers.
[[Heading:3]][[Transmission Jammers]][[/Heading]]
Transmission Jammers are used for several purposes, but generally help prevent communication between hostiles, especially summoning of reinforcements. While in range, they will prevent bots from transmitting tracking data about Cogmind to other allies on spot. This can help pick off bots in a squad 1 by 1 and to eliminate or bypass Watchers even when hostiles are nearby. They can also block [[Alarm Trap|Alarm Traps]] entirely.
[[Heading:3]]Signal Jamming (RIF Ability)[[/Heading]]
Signal Jamming is a RIF ability that behaves similar to Transmission Jammers. Instead of requiring a specific part to use, 0b10 bots are jammed based on attached Relay Couplers. Additionally, Alarm Traps are blocked entirely.
[[Heading:3]][[Trap Scanners]][[/Heading]]
Trap Scanners do exactly as their name implies: They scan for traps. Trap Scanners add fixed percentage to the chance to detect a trap each turn that one is within Cogmind's line of sight.

[[Heading]]Infowar gallery[[/Heading]]
