[[Heading]]Orders[[/Heading]]
Robots will by default follow [[Cogmind]] (you) and attack any hostile if combat capable. Orders can be issued to any robot [[B]]in sight[[/B]] listed in the allies menu [[B]](F6)[[/B]]. [[I]](Orders can also be issued directly on the map: Shift-right click on a robot, or press 'o' then its corresponding number, or in keyboard look mode, by moving the cursor over the bot and pressing 'o'.) [[/I]]
[[List]][[GameText]]STAY[[/GameText]] - Remain at the current position, only moving aside to let allies pass. Combat-capable bots will still chase after hostiles and return to their position later.|
[[GameText]]ROAM[[/GameText]] - Wander and do whatever.|
[[GameText]]FOLLOW[[/GameText]] - Follow [[Cogmind]].|
[[GameText]]GUARD[[/GameText]] - Follow the specified bot and prioritize attacking anything harming the specified bot.|
[[GameText]]AID[[/GameText]] - Follow the specified bot and prioritize attacking anything the specified bot is attacking.|
[[GameText]]TUNNEL[[/GameText]] - Tunnel to the specified location, if capable of digging (bots such as [[T-07 Excavator]]).|
[[GameText]]DROP[[/GameText]] - Drop everything in the bots inventory, then wander in a small area.|
[[GameText]]PICKUP[[/GameText]] - Collect everything near [[Cogmind]], and then [[GameText]]Follow[[/GameText]] once inventory is full.|
[[GameText]]COLLECT[[/GameText]] - Wander and collect items until inventory is full, then set to [[GameText]]Follow[[/GameText]].|
[[GameText]]EXPLORE[[/GameText]] - Explore unexplored areas, giving info to [[Cogmind]].|
[[GameText]]RETURN[[/GameText]] - Return this [[Drone]] to its bay. Drones only, obviously.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Benefits[[/Heading]]
[[Operator]] class robots will give you a diminishing hacking bonus starting at +6% (6%, 3%, 1%..), and will reveal any hidden door or trap, provided the operator is within 20 tiles range of you. Operators will also report changes in security level.
[[Mechanic]] class robots when set to [[GameText]]AID[[/GameText]] will repair core integrity [[B]](but NOT for Cogmind)[[/B]], broken parts, non-functional parts, and part integrity of their repair target (Cogmind is prioritized over allies) in that order. Mechanics cannot repair a part above 50% integrity.

Other.Name: Assault Squad
Other.Content:
Assault squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are sent after Cogmind as a result of having too high [[Alert]]. Assaults are sent to Cogmind's position when initially reported, and then they will roam around an expanding search area. They consist of a single [[C-30 ARC]] typically containing 5 bots inside. If Cogmind has 3 or more allies, up to 2 additional bots may be sent to escort the ARC as additional firepower. Assault squads can be both Enumerated and Recalled at [[Terminal|Terminals]].
An alert indicates whenever an Assault squad is dispatched. Additionally, the log will display a message like [[GameText]]ALERT: Significant disruption in zone 9B, assault force dispatched[[/GameText]]. If more than one ARC was sent, the message will instead indicate [[GameText]]multiple assault carriers dispatched[[/GameText]].

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]WAR.Sys Records|Assault Squad[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Frequency and Number[[/Heading]]
Assaults may be dispatched regularly as long as Cogmind is at least Alert level 2 or 400 influence, although at lower Alert levels Assaults are rare. At Alert levels well above 1000, Assaults may be sent out at nearly opportunity. A higher Alert level also increases the chances of multiple ARCs being dispatched. In [[Materials]], Assaults can be dispatched every 400 turns on -9 and -8. In [[Factory]] and above, this changes to be every 250 turns. Most assault waves consists of 1-2 ARCs, but at Alert levels in excess of 5X/1600 influence, 3 or even more ARCs can be sent.
[[Heading:2]]During [[High Security|High]] or [[Maximum Security]][[/Heading]]
The frequency, number, and contents of ARCs changes. Assault forces with stronger compositions than usual may be dispatched in these conditions, although these ARCs only have 4 bots inside rather than the typical 5. 4 ARCs will be dispatched 100 turns into High Security and after another 100 turns. After that, 2 more ARCs will be added to each wave, but 50 more turns will be added in between the dispatch of each wave. The sizes of the Assault waves will also start to increase each wave, and the duration between each wave will increase. Maximum Security is similar, but with 6 ARCs to start the first 2 waves. The 2nd wave of Assaults in High Security and all subsequent waves, and all waves of Maximum Security may contain stronger than usual bots in them.

[[Heading]]Assault Contents[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Assault Contents.png|Example contents of an Assault squad ARC[[/Image]]
Assault contents can vary by depth, but their makeups are always similar. Assaults will always contain 4 combat bots and 1 support-type bot. The combat bots may become stronger under heavy assault conditions, but the possible support bots are always the same.

[[Spoiler]][[Heading]][[Data Miner]] redirection[[/Heading]]
The Data Miner can redirect Assaults if his help is obtained by visiting his [[Data Miner (Location)|hideout]]. If redirected, Assaults will roam around a random area of the map rather than head directly to Cogmind's location. The Data Miner has a 50% chance to direct each ARC as part of an Assault about 15 turns after each Assault is dispatched, if Cogmind is determined as "needing assistance". Redirection can only occur when High/Maximum Security is not active. If a redirect happens, the alert [[GameText]]Higher priority target acquired, redirecting assault.[[/GameText]] will be displayed. If an Assault is not redirected, there is a further 50% chance that the contents may be redirected after the ARC opens up. This can happen within 30 turns of the ARC opening. This effect will only redirect the squad leader, and the squad leader will only leave if currently unable to see Cogmind. All the remaining squad bots will continue to follow Cogmind. The true practical effect here is that if the squad forgets where Cogmind is, they will patrol around the redirected location rather than the location that the ARC opened.[[/Spoiler]]

Other.Name: Bot Groups
Other.Content:
Bots of the same class have different parts from type to type, but behave similarly when considered as a single class. This page categorizes common bots by class as well as grouping a few other unique bots by faction.
[[BotGroups]]

Other.Name: Branch
Other.Content:
Branches are side locations from the main [[0b10]] complex, often with its own unique rewards and sights to behold. All of them lead back to main locations.
Read more at: [[Locations]].

Other.Name: Cargo Convoy
Other.Content:
[[Image]]Cargo Convoy.png|Intact cargo convoy[[/Image]]
[[Image]]Cargo Convoy Deployed.png|A cargo convoy with ARCs deployed[[/Image]]
Cargo convoys are a special form of [[Transport Squad|transport squads]] that can be found from -7 to -2 on main [[Factory]] and [[Research]] floors. They consist of a single [[A-27 Freighter]], a [[Protector]], and two [[C-30 ARC|C-30 ARCs]] full of 4 combat bots and an extra utility bot, similar to strong [[Assault Squad|assaults]]. The parts contained within a Freighter are all [[Prototype Part|prototype]] or [[Authchips]], never faulty, and can be up to 3 ratings out of depth. For example, on -7, regular Haulers can contain up to rating 4 prototype parts. A cargo convoy Freighter can carry rating 5-7 prototype parts.
Cargo convoys are always preceded by 3-5 [[Swarmer|Swarmers]] that scout out the path of the convoy before it appears. The alert [[GameText]]Cargo convoy en route, clear transfer corridor.[[/GameText]] will indicate when this is happening. A few turns later, the Freighter and guards will appear and take the same route.
Cargo convoys will always appear at a 0b10 controlled exit and head to a [[Garrison Access|Garrison]]. Typically the Freighter leads the way and stays ahead of the Protector and ARCs, which normally trail a few tiles behind. A [[Transport Network Coupler]] or [[Modified TNC]] will reveal the planned path of the Freighter. The Modified TNC will also show the contents of the Freighter. The Manifests hack will also show all the parts contained by the Freighter.

[[Heading]]Unique parts[[/Heading]]
There are 2 fully unique Cargo Convoy drops as well as one semi-unique drop:
[[List]][[Active Cooling Armor]]: Only obtainable from Cargo Convoy|[[Exp. Thermic Cannon]]: Only obtainable from Cargo Convoy|[[PL-3XN's Ring of Power]]: Only obtainable from one Cargo Convoy per run. Can be found in other locations.[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Attack response[[/Heading]]
If a cargo convoy is attacked, a message will indicate this, as well as an alert: [[GameText]]ALERT: Cargo convoy interrupted, initiating access lockdown.[[/GameText]] 100 turns after this, a [[Heavy]] will spawn at an 0b10 controlled exit or Garrison every 100 turns until all exits are guarded by a Heavy. Heavies may head toward a far away [[Caves]] exit in order to guard it. The Freighter will begin running away in a random direction when attacked. If it is not destroyed, it will head toward another nearby 0b10 controlled exit.

[[Heading]][[Derelict]] attack[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Cargo Convoy Attack.png|Derelicts from a Garrison ready to assault a convoy[[/Image]]
There is a chance that Derelicts will decide to attack a cargo convoy. The chance is higher at lower depths. If they attack, they will appropriate a Garrison machine, rig some [[Dirty Bomb Trap|Dirty Bomb Traps]], and attack the convoy guards. If they are successful, they will retreat and leave the loot available for Cogmind. This may happen even if Cogmind is nowhere near the convoy. It may be a good idea to track the Freighter position in case this happens, even if not planning to attack the convoy directly, since this can often result in lots of powerful free loot. If Cogmind is not close enough to grab the loot, [[Recycler|Recyclers]] may have carried it off to a nearby [[Recycling Unit]]. Make sure to check these if the Freighter's stash can't be found nearby.

[[Heading]]Convoy contents[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Depth|[[E-15 Imp]]|[[Executioner]]|[[Hunter]]|[[Mechanic]]|[[Programmer]]|Protector|[[Specialist]]|[[Striker]]||
-7|N/A|N/A|[[H-55 Commando]]|[[M-28 Smith]]|[[P-60 Hacker]]|[[I-36 Angel]]|[[X-57 Shotgunner]], [[X-62 Marksman]], or [[X-67 Chaingunner]]|N/A||
-6|Yes|N/A|[[H-66 Slayer]]|M-28 Smith|P-60 Hacker|I-36 Angel|X-62 Marksman, X-67 Chaingunner, or [[X-72 Disruptor]]|N/A||
-5|Yes|N/A|H-66 Slayer|M-28 Smith|[[P-70 Sage]]|[[I-47 Archangel]]|X-67 Chaingunner, X-72 Disruptor, or [[X-77 Beamer]]|N/A||
-4|Yes|Yes|[[H-77 Assassin]]|[[M-36 Artificer]]|P-70 Sage|I-47 Archangel|X-72 Disruptor, X-77 Beamer, or [[X-82 Rainmaker]]|Yes||
-3|Yes|Yes|H-77 Assassin|M-36 Artificer|[[P-80 Master]]|I-47 Archangel|X-77 Beamer, X-82 Rainmaker, or [[X-87 Electro]]|Yes||
-2|Yes|Yes|[[H-88 Terminator]]|M-36 Artificer|P-80 Master|I-47 Archangel|X-82 Rainmaker or X-87 Electro|Yes
[[/Table]]

Other.Name: Cave-ins
Other.Content:
Cave-ins are a [[Game Mechanics|Game Mechanic]] where dug-out tiles will collapse and instantly deal a large amount of Impact damage to anything on the tile. It is safe to dig up to 3 tiles safely in some circumstances, but long distance digging is always unsafe.

[[Heading]]Causes of cave-ins[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Destabilized Tiles.png|Destabilized tiles are bright red as shown by a Structural Scanner[[/Image]]
[[Heading:2]]Destabilization[[/Heading]]
Destabilized tiles are tiles that will always collapse if given enough time. They may collapse instantly or they may last a hundred turns or more. Destabilized tiles can be viewed with a [[Structural Scanner]]. A tile can become destabilized in two ways:
[[List]]Explosive damage - Explosive damage (namely [[Launchers]]) will cause a tile to destabilized.|Attacking from a dug out tile - If Cogmind or any other bot fires a weapon inside of a dug out tile, the tile will destabilize. This tile may collapse instantly before Cogmind gets a chance to move, so digging from inside these tiles is never completely safe.
In terms of destabilization, melee attacks are the least likely to collapse right away. Guns have a slightly higher chance, and then cannons and launchers have the highest chance.[[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]Dug-out tile traversal[[/Heading]]
It is possible to safely travel through dug-out tiles (that are not destabilized) for up to 1-4 tiles, depending on the type of tiles traversed. If the warnOnCaveinMove option in the advanced.cfg file is set to 1, the game will warn you when trying to move onto a dug-out tile that could collapse due to that movement. The safety of digs is follow (assuming the relevant tiles are not destabilized):
[[List]]
1-tile digs - Always safe.
|2-tile digs - Safe, unless both tiles are dug-out earth tiles (rarely relevant).
|3-tile digs - Safe, but only if no more than one of the tiles is a dug-out Earth tile.
For example, the most common safe 3-tile dig is Wall-Earth-Wall,
whereas Wall-Earth-Earth or Earth-Earth-Wall would not be safe and could collapse on the third tile due to having traveled through more than one earth tile. 
|4-tile digs - Only safe if all four tiles are dug-out Wall tiles. 4-tile digs are only rarely useful.
|5-tile or more digs - Never safe.[[/List]]
One way to think about it is to consider that moving through a dug-out tile has a "cost", 2 for Wall tiles and 5 for Earth tiles, and that having reached a "cost" of 10 or more during a single dig can cause a cave-in on the current tile. [[Comment]]I feel like there's a better way to word this sentence.[[/Comment]]

[[Comment]]Some late-game AAs can make it possible to dig more safely/farther/better, should they be mentioned here? I'm not sure myself on how they function in regards to cave-ins due to movement.[[/Comment]]

[[Heading:2]]Closed-off Tunnels[[/Heading]]
If a bot sits in a closed off area of the map, there is a chance each turn that a cave-in will occur. As long as there is a path to the main area of the map, it is safe to sit indefinitely in a dug out area. However, if the path closes due to something like an [[U-05 Engineer|Engineer]] rebuilding a wall, it will suddenly become dangerous.

[[Heading]]Example digs[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Wall Earth Wall Dig.png|Safe 3-tile dig with a ranged weapon: Wall-earth-wall|Wall Dig.png|Safe 1-tile dig with a melee weapon: Wall only|Wall Wall Dig.png|UNSAFE 2-tile dig: Digging within a dug out tile is unsafe|Wall Earth Earth Wall Dig.png|UNSAFE 4-tile dig: Wall-earth is safe, second half earth-wall is unsafe[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading]]Avoiding cave-ins[[/Heading]]
Here are some strategies to avoid cave-ins:
[[List]]Don't use melee to dig more than 1 tile - Melee weapons need to be adjacent to the next tile to dig out. This means Cogmind will have to be in a dug out tile to dig two consecutive tiles which allows a chance for an immediate destabilization cave-in.|Don't use Explosive Launchers to dig - While Launchers can dig out a lot of tiles at once, those tiles have a chance to collapse as Cogmind walks through. Note: it is safe to do this with a Structural Scanner equipped, as destabilized tiles will be visible and are avoidable.|Use Thermal or Kinetic cannons - These cannons have a high base damage that is typically strong enough to dig through most non-reinforced walls. It is safe to dig a 3 tile path ahead of time and then walk through at no risk of cave-in.|Be wary of [[U-05 Engineer|Engineers]] - Engineers may seal off your path and leave you stuck in the wall, forced to dig again to escape and risk immediate cave-in.[[/List]]

Other.Name: Challenges Achievements
Other.Content:
Challenges [[Achievements]] are earned by completing certain challenging feats, demonstrating the player's large experience with the game. Only some of them are likely to be obtained naturally by players not actively trying to earn them. 2 of the 27 Challenges Achievements have hidden descriptions that are only revealed after completing them. The borders of Challenges Achievements tend to indicate their general difficulty as a Challenges Achievement[[Comment]]Rincewind being the biggest exception. Why is that one considered "easy"? It's basically the most difficult one in here.[[/Comment]], with more "intense" borders meaning higher difficulty.

[[Comment]]This warning is supposed to be there for all articles about achievement types, including those that do not have any Redacted-level spoilers.[[/Comment]]
(The visibility for the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements is set to at least "Spoilers", and may be set to "Redacted" for achievements where that would be relevant. Remember to change your spoilers settings to "None" if you do not wish to see the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements you have not yet obtained!)

Warning: The writer of this article has not yet earned the "Full Golem" Achievement, and as such its description in this page is a (likely accurate) guess instead of being the official description.

[[Comment]]Important note : A lot of Challenges Achievements' descriptions mention by name some spoiler-tier stuff, such as the Cetus Guards or Transdimensional Reconstructors.
Normally, these names would be contained within a Link tag.
However, because those Achievements' descriptions are not hidden by the game (the descriptions themselves aren't spoiler-tier), these names should not be contained within a Link tag, because that would cause them to appear spoilered to anyone with a spoiler setting of "None".[[/Comment]]

[[Heading]]Challenge difficulty level 1[[/Heading]]
[[List]]Exterminator: Destroy 15 [[Assembled]] in the [[Mines]].
Strategy: This Achievement is seed-dependent, and may be impossible on some seeds. When attempting to get this Achievement on a random seed, visit the Mines and bring at least one [[Launchers|launcher]]. If an Assembled infestation occurs, try to find and reach the source as quickly as possible, to be able to blow up the Assembled while they are still in a somewhat large group. Having a [[Seismic Detector]] can help locate the Assembled faster.
|Killing Spree: Achieve a kill streak of 20 hostiles.
|Preemptive Strike: Destroy a visible [[C-30 ARC|ARC]] before it deploys.
|Left-hand Path: Destroy all Cetus Guards without any help from allies.
|Below: Visit and survive 2 [[Wastes|Waste]] areas.
|Streaker: Enter a main complex map at -5 or above as a naked core, and find an exit (do not have to remain naked).
|Rincewind: Use at least 10 Transdimensional Reconstructors (any variant).
|Leap Before You Look: Enter 10 unidentified exits.
Strategy: It is possible to deduce the identity of exits without actually "identifying" the exit, through various means. For example, successfully hacking branch exits would cause all remaining unidentified exits to be main exits, and vice-versa. It is also possible to identify some exits by where they are or what's around them, such as [[Mines]] exits, which are always surrounded by mining equipment. This is especially true in branches, where all exits are distinguishable from each other. This can allow entering exits the game considers "unidentified", while actually knowing where they lead, making this Achievement much easier. If you have a [[Signal Interpreters|Signal Interpreter]] attached, remember to deactivate it before approaching any exits you would want to take while unidentified, as it would automatically identify them.[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Challenge difficulty level 2[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Boltbath: Achieve a kill streak of 35 hostiles.
|Torch: Inflict 30,000 thermal damage across an entire run.
|Magneto: Inflict 30,000 electromagnetic damage across an entire run.
|Punisher: Inflict 30,000 kinetic damage across an entire run.
|Gladiator: Destroy 200 hostiles via melee.
|Infiltrator: Enter and survive 2 [[Garrison|Garrisons]] on a single floor.
|Desperate Times: Enter a main complex map at -3 or above as a naked core with no inventory items, and find an exit (do not have to remain naked).
|Monster: Kill at least 20 inhabitants of Zion.
|Equal Opportunity Bot: Destroy 30 different classes of robot.
Notes: What counts as a "class" isn't immediately obvious. For example, the in-game examination window classifies [[Thug|Thugs]] as "Thug (Derelict)" and [[Grunt|Grunts]] as "Grunt", but they are considered the same class for scoresheet purposes. This achievement relies on the scoresheet definition, making it somewhat confusing.
As a general rule, robots with different sprites will count as different classes (with the exception of unique NPCs, which do not count at all).
The exact definition is likely related to the "build type" and purpose of each robot. For example, both [[Packrat|Packrats]] and [[Recycler|Recyclers]] have the purpose of collecting parts and have similar parts. Both Thugs and Grunts are two-legged, have a [[Cooling Devices|Heat Sink]], and use thermal guns. [[Cobbler|Cobblers]] and [[Mechanic|Mechanics]], however, are completely different in both build and purpose, and as such count as different classes.
The relevant scoresheet statistic is "Classes Destroyed".
|Giant Slayer: Destroy 5 [[Behemoth|Behemoths]].
|Artifact Hunter: [[Spoiler]]Attach or use 15 different alien artifacts.[[/Spoiler]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Challenge difficulty level 3[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Fearless: Enter a [[Garrison]] with below 10% core integrity and survive it.
|Shutout: Seal, jam, or destroy all [[Garrison Access|Garrison Access machines]] in Access.
|WMD: Destroy 100 robots in a single turn.
|Rambo: Earn 10,000 bonus points for high alert combat kills.
|Most Wanted: Trigger [[High Security|high security]] 4 times.
|404: Destroy 4 Network Hubs and escape to the next floor.
|Full Golem: [[Spoiler]]Fully integrate all possible parts from a [[GOLEM Unit]].[[/Spoiler]][[Comment]]TODO: This is the achievement with a description that i just guessed. I know it to be technically accurate, but it isn't the same as the actual achievement's description. Once the description is corrected, please remember to delete the warning at the top of the page.[[/Comment]]
|Traitor: Personally kill Warlord in his base and escape. Must initiate hostilities before incursion begins.[[/List]]

Other.Name: Community Challenges
Other.Content:
This page contains alternate game challenges created by the community.

[[Heading]][[Drained L-Cannon]] (DLC) Victory[[/Heading]]
This challenge relates to redacted-tier content.
[[Redacted]]The Drained L-Cannon must be acquired in [[Section 7]] and taken to [[Command]] to kill [[MAIN.C]]. Through precise positioning and aiming, it is possible to kill both phases simultaneously. Then, it must be taken to [[Access_0]] and used to eliminate the [[Architect]]. Again, with proper aiming, it is possible to kill the Architect and the singularity gate simultaneously.[[/Redacted]]

Runia [[https://leiavoia.net/cogmind/dataminer/index.html?NqKDXkNv4e2NUuaXi|(scoresheet)]]|Runia (2nd completion) [[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V8C6bMmqdSA|(video part 1)]] [[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j3a8LcHc6p4|(video part 2)]] [[https://leiavoia.net/cogmind/dataminer/?FX1v9SHraRBMypQBq|(scoresheet)]][[/List]]

[[Heading:2]]Inspector Madlad Completed Runs[[/Heading]]
None yet

[[Heading]]No Info Only War[[/Heading]]
[[B]]No Info, Only War[[/B]] - Ever wondered what it's like to get a "pure" combat win without any of those pesky sensors or scanners or burner hackware, pooling all your resources not into avoiding combat or escaping the complex quickly, but into nothing but sheer, overwhelming power? Then you might be interested in this challenge!
Forbidden: Much like leiavoia's Tank it to the Top, you must use only grounded propulsion, not even core hover if you can avoid it. Strictly forbidden parts are anything listed within Cogminder as [[Hackware]] or [[Infowar]], and no [[Datajacks]] or [[Component Analysis Suites]] either! Alignment options: [[RIF]] and [[Data Conduit|DC]] are also forbidden. If you get [[FarCom]], you must aggro the [[Exiles (Group)]] before leaving the map. You are also not allowed to enter the [[Hub_04(d)|Hub]] branch map.
Permitted: Unlike Tank it to the Top, you can go wherever you want (you may not even be able to ID exits, after all!), and you can use any unauthorized hacks you know, if you can succeed with no hackware! Feel free to restrict those for extra points (the points mean nothing). Parts that don't strictly help mid-combat, but don't give intel, like recalibrators or salvage targeting, are allowed and even recommended. Alignment options: [[Encrypted Comm Array|ECA]], [[UFD]], [[Core Reset Matrix|CRM]], and [[Imprint]] are fine.
Objective: Surface exit. Extended is bonus points!

Captain Winky [[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K4PlqRi522U|(video)]] [[https://leiavoia.net/cogmind/dataminer/?CrYjCg31pBNi8XSEs|(scoresheet)]]|

[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Tank It To The Top[[/Heading]]
leiavoia's "Tank It To The Top" Challenge -  Showing just how hard is it to play combat treads from a new-player perspective. Think you're tough? Give it a try!
Da Rulez: You have to take a combat build (treads recommended, but any grounded propulsion type is allowed) through a "straight shot" run. You may not take any branches, including [[Mines]], [[Caves]], [[DSF]] and [[Garrison|Garrisons]]. [[Wastes|Waste]] [[Chute Trap|Chutes]] are allowed. Access surface exit is the goal ("W0"). This challenge is meant to be "spoiler free", so you may not use any "unauthorized" terminal hacks that would be unknown to a new player (no botnets!). You can wear other prop in an emergency, but not as an alternative, and not as "hover treads".
Background: It turns out that doing this is really difficult. I wanted to make a n00b-friendly combat how-to, but keep getting my bot kicked. Attempts at doing this lately all burn down when alert finally catches up. Treads builds desperately want to escape to branches, but when there are none, you need to find a different method. Let me know if you make it work, and bonus points if its on video. Happy treading!

Other.Name: Corrupted Parts
Other.Content: Attaching a corrupted part will give you [[Corruption]]. Corrupted parts may be repaired at a Repair Station.

Other.Name: Corruption
Other.Content:
Corruption is a [[Game Mechanics|Gameplay Mechanic]] that can cause numerous negative effects on bots, up to instant death at 100% corruption. Corruption is an always visible stat in the HUD for Cogmind. Other bots can be [[Datajacks|Datajacked]] in order to see their corruption.

[[Heading]]Getting corruption[[/Heading]]
[[List]]Electromagnetic Damage: Between 50-150% of EM damage is also inflicted as corruption for non-Cogmind bots. For Cogmind, each hit has a [damage %] chance of inflicting 1% corruption.|
Impact Damage destroying parts: Each destroyed part inflicts between 25-150% corruption to non-Cogmind bots. For Cogmind, each destroyed part inflicts between 1-5% corruption.|
Getting hit by a Corruption Crit: Between 1-10% of the damage inflicted (including EM resistance but not other forms of damage reduction) is also inflicted as corruption. If the corruption inflicted is less than 0, it truncates to 0 rather than rounding up. For example, 5% of 10 damage would be .5% corruption, which truncates to 0.|
Attaching a [[Corrupted Parts|Corrupted Part]]: Between 1% and [corruption % on death / 10] corruption, capped at 15%.|
Feedback from being fully traced at an [[Interactive Machine]] (1%).[[/List]]
Note: All sources of corruption are affected by EM damage resistance.

[[Heading]]Corruption Effects[[/Heading]]
Some corruption effects can happen at any point in time, some only happen while hostiles are nearby, and some are permanent negative effects unless corruption is purged. Chance based corruption effects become more common at higher corruption.
[[Heading:2]]Cogmind Corruption Effects[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Name|Effect|Extra Conditions||
Message Error|Garbled messages appear in the game log.|N/A||
Matter Fused|Loss of between 5-10 [[Matter]], with the log message [[GameText]]System corrupted: Matter fused (-x).[[/GameText]]|Only occurs if Cogmind has > 0 matter||
Heat Flow Error|Large spike in [[Heat]], between 100 and 300, with log message [[GameText]]System corrupted: Heat flow error (+x).[[/GameText]]|N/A||
Energy Discharge|Loss of stored [[Energy]], between 20-40% of current storage capacity, with log message [[GameText]]System corrupted: Energy discharge (-x).[[/GameText]]|Only occurs if Cogmind has > 0 energy||
Part Rejected|A random part is detached, not including fragile parts like processors, with log message [[GameText]]System corrupted: [part name] rejected.[[/GameText]]|Only occurs while hostile bots are nearby||
Part Fused|A random part that isn't fragile or fused already becomes fused and is unable to be detached without destruction, with log message [[GameText]]System corrupted: [part name] fused.[[/GameText]]|N/A||
Data Loss (Minor/Major)|There are two similar effects of data loss. A minor data loss will lose 1-3 component part ID with the log message [[GameText]]System corrupted: Component data lost.[[/GameText]] A major data loss will lose 3-5 component part IDs with the log message [[GameText]]System corrupted: Substantial component data lost.[[/GameText]]|N/A||
Misfire|A random weapon will be attempted to be fired. Fails if the weapon does not have enough resources to fire (matter/energy). This effect doesn't affect melee weapons, special weapons, or guided weapons. Also has the log message [[GameText]]System corrupted: FCS attempts to trigger [part name].[[/GameText]] If the misfire is successful, there is an additional log message [[GameText]]System corrupted: [part name] misfires.[[/GameText]]|N/A||
IFF Burst|An IFF burst comes from Cogmind, alerting hostiles within a 15 tile radius. Bots will head to investigate the location of the IFF burst but do not gain active tracking on Cogmind. Also has the log message [[GameText]]IFF burst signal emitted.[[/GameText]]|N/A||
Misdirection|Cogmind may move in a random direction other than the one commanded, with game popup message (not log message) [[GameText]]System corrupted: Misdirected.[[/GameText]] On flight, may come with an additional penalty of slamming into a wall. If this occurs, Cogmind will take minor impact damage, with the log message [[GameText]]Slammed into [ceiling/wall].[[/GameText]]|Only occurs while hostile bots are nearby||
Weapon Failure|A weapon will fail to fire during a volley. Based on if the weapon is a ballistic weapon, energy weapon, or launcher, the log message will be the following: [[GameText]]System corrupted: [part name] jammed/failed to cycle/failed to launch.[[/GameText]]|Only occurs on firing a volley||
Hacking Penalty|Cogmind suffers a [corruption % / 3] penalty to the success rate of hacks on all interactive machines.|N/A||
Accuracy Penalty|Cogmind suffers a [corruption % / 4]% penalty to accuracy.|N/A||
Allied Trap Triggering|Can trigger allied traps when walking on top of them, with a [corruption %] chance of triggering.|N/A||
Instant Death|When Cogmind hits 100% corruption, the game is instantly over|>100% corruption 
[[/Table]]
[[Heading:2]]Non-Cogmind Corruption Effects[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Name|Effect||
Memory Loss|Typically, each action subtracts 1 from a bot's memory memory while it is out of line of sight of a target they are tracking. Bots have an additional penalty applied to their memory that is calculated as [corruption % / 10]. For example, a [[G-34 Mercenary]] at 0% corruption has a memory of 20 actions. At 10% corruption, this is reduced to 10 actions (20 / 2). At 20%, this is reduced to 7 (20 / 3, rounding up).||
Accuracy Penalty|Bots suffers a [corruption % / 8]% penalty to accuracy.||
Misfire|Bots will shoot something that wasn't intentionally aimed at. Unlike Cogmind misfires, this can only occur while a bot is actively shooting and all weapons in one volley will fire at the same target. When a bot shoots a non-bot target, there is a log message [[GameText]][bot name] misfires.[[/GameText]] If another bot is targeted, there is a different log message [[GameText]][bot name] IFF system glitched.[[/GameText]]||
Allied Trap Triggering|Can trigger allied traps when walking on top of them, with a [corruption %] chance of triggering.||
Instant Death|When a non-Cogmind bot hits 100% corruption, they will die at the end of their next turn[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Preventing Corruption[[/Heading]]
[[List]][[Redacted]][[Core Membrane]]: Completely negates all corruption gains[[/Redacted]]|[[Corruption Screens]]: Takes damage to prevent corruption gain|[[Dynamic Insulation Systems]]: Has a chance of negating corruption gain|EM resistance: All sources of corruption are proportionally reduced by EM resistance, and a 100% EM resistant bot cannot gain corruption in any way.|[[System Guards]]: Reduces effective corruption by a certain amount. Does not truly purge it but behaves like it isn't there.[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Purging Corruption[[/Heading]]
[[List]][[Spoiler]][[Core Reset Matrix]]: On attach, corruption is reset to 0[[/Spoiler]]|
Evolving|
[[System Restoration Modules]] active effect|
[[Programmer]] effect to reset corruption (non-Cogmind only)[[/List]]

Other.Name: Coupling Squad
Other.Content:
[[Image]]Coupling Squad.png|A Programmer installing Relay Couplers into a Garrison[[/Image]]
Coupling squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are sent to restock [[Garrison Access|Garrison Machines]] with [[Relay Couplers]]. They can appear on any 0b10 floor that contains a Garrison as well as on the inside of [[Garrison|Garrisons]]. They consist of a single [[Programmer]] carrying 3-4 Relay Couplers. The Programmer is 1 tier above typical Programmers for the depth. For example, a typical -7 Programmer is a [[P-60 Hacker]], but a coupling squad will instead be a [[P-70 Sage]].
Coupling squads are dispatched if a Garrison has no Relay Couplers in its builtin inventory. Garrison machines usually contain 3-4 Couplers at all times, but sometimes one will be present on initial map entry with none. Full Garrisons will also lose their inventory over time and become empty. In either case, a Programmer will eventually be called to that Garrison to restock the Couplers. When a coupling squad Programmer reaches its target Garrison, a message like [[GameText]]P-70 Sage installs Relay Coupler [Grunt] into garrison access.[[/GameText]] will appear in the log. After all the couplers are installed, the Programmer will exit through the Garrison.

[[Heading]]Intentional dispatching[[/Heading]]
Coupling squads can also dispatched if Cogmind uses the [[Spoiler]]Trojan(Restock)[[/Spoiler]] hack. If this is done, log text similar to [[GameText]]ALERT: Unscheduled coupler replacement inbound for Garrison vPm.7n.[[/GameText]] will appear after a few turns. A similar restock effect will occur if Cogmind uses the [[Spoiler]]Force(Eject)[[/Spoiler]] hack.

Other.Name: Data Conduit
Other.Content: The machine in [[Data Miner (Location)]] that is the source of the [[Data Miner|Data Miner's]] information. Can be used if the Data Miner is knocked out of the way.

Other.Name: Demolisher Squad
Other.Content:
[[Image]]Demolisher Squad.png|2 Demolishers popping out of an ARC[[/Image]]
Demolisher squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are dispatched to eliminate large groups of hostiles, especially [[Assembled]]. They are sent to the general area of a lot of hostiles, where they will roam around looking for bots to fight. They consist of a single [[C-30 ARC]] containing 2 [[Demolisher|Demolishers]]. Demolisher squads will never exit the map under normal circumstances after being dispatched.
An alert will indicate whenever a Demolisher squad is dispatched. Additionally, the log will display a message like [[GameText]]ALERT: Infestation in the Mines, dispatching Demolisher response squad.[[/GameText]] Depending on the method triggering the squad, a different reason may be given in the alert.

[[Heading]]How to get Demolisher Squads[[/Heading]]
[[List]]Assembled infestation: Any Assembled infestation events will trigger an immediate Demolisher response|[[Spoiler]]Friendly Assembled: If Cogmind has used a [[Core Reset Matrix]] and uses a [[Mobile Assembly Unit]] to create allied Assembled, Demolishers will be sent after a random amount of turns[[/Spoiler]]|Too many allies: If Cogmind has 18 or more allies, Demolishers may be dispatched to Cogmind's current location.[[/List]]

Other.Name: Empty
Other.Content: Empty page for undisturbed creation of new pages

Other.Name: Energy
Other.Content: Once per turn energy is generated by power sources, and is necessary for moving, firing energy-based weapons, and sustaining the operation of some utility systems. Robot cores also generate some energy of their own, though not enough to support significant activity.

Other.Name: Events Achievements
Other.Content:
Events [[Achievements]] are earned by witnessing or triggering certain events. Most of them will simply eventually be obtained by players as they explore and understand more of the game world and its depths. 40 of the 41 Events Achievements have hidden descriptions that are only revealed after completing them. The borders of Events Achievement have 0-2 squares in their corners, with more squares usually meaning a more important event.

[[Comment]]This warning is supposed to be there for all articles about achievement types, regardless of whether there are any Redacted-level spoilers, because saying there are no Redacted-level spoilers is itself a spoiler.[[/Comment]]
(The visibility for the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements is set to at least "Spoilers", and may be set to "Redacted" for achievements where that would be relevant. Remember to change your spoilers settings to "None" if you do not wish to see the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements you have not yet obtained!)

[[/List]]

Other.Name: Example
Other.Content:
[[Materials#Lore]]
This is a test of wiki content.
Content separated by a newline is split into multiple paragraphs.
A link: [[Example]]. A [[Example|link with content different than the link]]. A [[Assault Rifle|part link]] with part information shown on mouseover. A [[S-10 Pest|bot link]] with bot information shown on mouseover. A [[Materials|location link]]. A [[~/hacks|link to the Cog-Minder Hacks page]].
Links are a type of inline content that can be used anywhere. Other types of inline content are [[B]]bolded text[[/B]] and [[I]]italicized text[[/I]]. Links can also be [[B]][[Example|bolded]][[/B]], [[I]][[Example|italicized]][[/I]], and [[B]][[I]][[Example|both together]][[/I]][[/B]]. Another option is [[GameText]]Inline Game Text[[/GameText]] that uses a separate font style. [[Sub]]Subscript[[/Sub]] and [[Sup]]Superscript[[/Sup]] are also available. Text can be colored with [[Color:Red]]HTML color names[[/Color]] or [[Color:#ff0077]]Hex colors[[/Color]].
[[Comment]]Editor only comments are supported. This text will only show up in the editor and not in the final page.[[/Comment]]

[[Heading]]Heading type 1[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:2]]Heading type 2[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:1]]Heading type 1 [[B]]with[[/B]] [[I]]inline[[/I]] [[Example|content]][[/Heading]]
Text content before an image shows up vertically above.[[Image]]Materials.png|An image [[I]]with[[/I]] [[B]]inline[[/B]] [[Materials|content]] in the caption[[/Image]]Images will show on the far right side of the page while text content after an image shows up to the left of it.
[[List]]Lists of items|can be generated|like this[[/List]]
[[List:Unordered]]Lists can be|explicitly unordered[[/List]]
[[List:Ordered]]And they can also|be ordered|and [[B]]have[[/B]] [[I]]inline[[/I]] [[Example|content]][[/List]]
2-dimensional tables can also be created and have inline content effects added.
[[Table]]
Column 1|Column 2||
Row 1 Column 1|Row 1 Column 2||
[[B]]Row 2 Column 1[[/B]]|[[I]]Row 2 Column 2[[/I]]||
[[CellStyle:Good]]Styles can be applied for individual cells|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Currently 3 styles supported||
[[CellStyle:Bad]]Good, Neutral, and Bad| ||
[[CellSpan:2]]Cells can also span multiple columns
[[/Table]]
Lore entries can also be added like below: [[Lore]]0b10 Records|Materials[[/Lore]]
[[Gallery]]Materials.png|Here is a gallery of images with|Materials Main Exit.png|captions that will stack|Materials Mines Exit.png|horizontally until there is no|Materials OOD Cache.png|more space, then they will spill|Materials Storage Cache.png|eventually over a lot of space|Mines.png|onto the next line|Materials.png|These images also [[B]]support[[/B]] [[I]]inline[[/I]] [[Example|content]]|Image Not Found.png|There is an image not found backup but these shouldn't show up normally.|../game_sprites/Terminal.png|An image accessing a local non-wiki image.|https://i.ibb.co/JHBS25D/image.png|An external image by URL.[[/Gallery]]
There are two types of spoilers: [[Spoiler]]Spoiler-tier spoilers[[/Spoiler]] and [[Redacted]]Redacted-tier spoilers[[/Redacted]]. Text will be blocked with gray bars unless moused over, and images will be faded/blurred out. It is possible to nest [[Spoiler]]spoiler text and [[Redacted]] redacted text underneath.[[/Redacted]][[/Spoiler]]This will create 2 layers of spoilered text that will only show the appropriate spoiler effects for each level. Spoilered content can also contain any types [[Redacted]][[B]]of[[/B]] [[I]]inline[[/I]] [[Example|content]][[/Redacted]][[Redacted]][[Image]]Factory.png|Redacted image[[/Image]]

[[Heading]]Redacted Heading[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Research.png|Redacted group|Access.png|of images[[/Gallery]]
[[/Redacted]][[Image]]Factory.png|Image with a partially [[Redacted]]Redacted[[/Redacted]] caption[[/Image]]
[[Gallery]]Research.png|These images can also show|Access.png|[[Spoiler]]Spoiler[[/Spoiler]] and [[Redacted]]Redacted[[/Redacted]] content[[/Gallery]]
[[Redacted]][[List]]Lists can also|be spoiled entirely[[/List]][[/Redacted]][[List]]They can also have|some [[Redacted]]spoiled content[[/Redacted]][[/List]]
Game text and Lore entries can also be spoilered: [[Redacted]][[GameText]]Game text[[/GameText]]
Lore entry: [[Lore]]0b10 Records|Materials[[/Lore]][[/Redacted]]

[[Heading]]Spoiler Hidden[[/Heading]]
Spoiler hidden and Redacted hidden sections are basically the opposite of normal Spoiler/Redacted sections. They hide their contents if the spoiler setting is at least set to spoiler/redacted respectively. This can be used to indicate that content may be hidden/excluded in some locations based on spoiler settings.
[[SpoilerHidden]]This text can only be seen when the spoiler setting is None[[/SpoilerHidden]]
[[RedactedHidden]]This text can only be seen when the spoiler setting is None or Spoiler[[/RedactedHidden]]

Other.Name: Extermination Squad
Other.Content:
[[Image]]Extermination Squad.png|An Extermination Squad hunting down Cogmind[[/Image]]
Extermination squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are sent after Cogmind periodically in [[Factory]] (-7) and beyond. Exterminations are sent to the area that Cogmind was located at when they are summoned. Once they arrive there, they will begin a search pattern that steadily grows in range over time until they find Cogmind. Extermination squads consist of 1-3 [[Programmer|Programmers]] based on the floor: 1 [[P-60 Hacker]] on -7 and -6, 1 or 2 [[P-70 Sage|P-70 Sages]] on -5 and -4, and 2 or 3 [[P-80 Master|P-80 Masters]] on -3 to -1. Extermination squads can be both Enumerated and Recalled at [[Terminal|Terminals]].
An alert will indicate whenever an an Extermination squad is dispatched. Additionally, the log will display a message like [[GameText]]ALERT: Rogue bot located, Programmers report to Factory Zone 5B.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]WAR.Sys Records|Extermination Squad[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Frequency[[/Heading]]
Extermination squads are dispatched on a regular basis on most 0b10 maps past -7. The higher the depth, the more frequently that Exterminations will be dispatched.
The spawn frequency can be delayed with [[Spoiler]]the [[RIF]] ability Zone Cloak[[/Spoiler]] or by sealing [[Garrison Access|Garrison Machines]]. Both of these methods stack, and each provides an average of +75 turns to each Extermination squad spawn.
[[Spoiler]][[Heading]][[Q-Series]][[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Q-Series.png|2 Q-Series coming for Cogmind[[/Image]]
It is possible for Extermination Programmers to be replaced by 1-2 Q-Series instead. This can occur randomly if Cogmind gets scanned by a [[Researcher]] in [[Testing]] or [[Quarantine]]. These Q-Series have customized and randomized loadouts, but will behave in the same way as regular Extermination squads do. This includes heading for Cogmind's initial position and then continuing to search for Cogmind as well as the ability to be recalled at Terminals. However, unlike Exterminations, Q-Series have a [[Lrn. IFF Parser]] that they can use to locate Cogmind from a large distance.[[/Spoiler]]

Other.Name: Fabricator
Other.Content:
[[Image]]../game_sprites/Fabricator.png|A Fabricator[[/Image]]
Fabricators are [[0b10]]-controlled [[Interactive Machine|Machines]] that construct parts and robots based on [[Schematic|Schematics]]. Cogmind can make use of Fabricators himself, but bots may be called to investigate if an unauthorized schematic is used. At other times, 0b10 will use them to fabricate random parts and combat bots for itself. Some parts and most bots fabricate in larger groups. Fabricators do not appear until -7 [[Factory]], at which point they will appear in every main 0b10 floor as well as [[Testing]].

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Fabricator[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Fabricating Things[[/Heading]]There are three primary ways that parts and bots can be fabricated.
[[Heading:2]]Initiated by 0b10[[/Heading]]
0b10 will periodically make use of Fabricators. Combat bots that are fabricated will be sent to the nearest [[Garrison Access|Garrison]]. Part fabrication initiated by 0b10 will double the standard amount of parts are fabricated compared to the standard amount. Parts fabricated by 0b10 can be up to 2 ratings out of depth.
[[Heading:2]]Preloaded Schematic[[/Heading]]
Schematics can be preloaded into the fabricator without their fabrication having started yet. In this case, Cogmind can initiate the fabrication without any other requirements or downsides. The schematic will be instantly cleared when fabrication begins. Schematics preloaded this way can be up to 2 ratings out of depth.
[[Heading:2]]Cogmind Loaded Schematic[[/Heading]]
Cogmind can load any known part or bot schematic into the Fabricator. When a fabrication is initiated this way, the Fabricator will be instantly locked out from further use and an [[Investigation Squad]] will be dispatched to the location. The fabrication will still complete as normal at this point. The lockout and Investigation can be avoided if an [[Authchips|Authchip]] matching the type of the schematic.
[[Heading:2]]Multiple Fabrications[[/Heading]]
Only one thing can be fabricated at any given time. It is possible to load a new schematic while a Fabricator is operating, but starting the second fabrication will cancel the original target. This can be used to prevent a hostile 0b10 bot fabrication from completing.
[[Heading:2]]Time to Fabricate[[/Heading]]
The number of turns it takes to fabricate something is fixed based on the rating. An item fabricating in multiples doesn't take any additional turns.
[[Table]]
Rating|Turns at Level 1|Turns at Level 2|Turns at Level 3||
1|51|25|17||
2|62|31|20||
2*|99|49|33||
3|73|36|24||
3*|116|58|38||
4|84|42|28||
4*|134|67|44||
5|95|47|31||
5*|152|76|50||
6|106|53|35||
6*|169|84|56||
7|117|58|39||
7*|187|93|62||
8|128|64|42||
8*|204|102|68||
9|139|69|46||
9*|222|111|74||
10|150|75|50
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Armor Values[[/Heading]]
The armor of a Fabricator will indicate what security level it is:
[[Table]]
Security level|Armor||
1|22||
2|32||
3|35
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Hacks[[/Heading]]
[[Hacks]]Fabricator[[/Hacks]]
[[Spoiler]][[Heading:2]]Additional Details/Usage Tips[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Force(Recompile)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
A good use of this hack is to recompile an Authchip off of a low security level Fabricator and use it on a higher level one for faster fabrication. This avoids having to hang around to deal with the Investigation squad in order to retrieve the fabricated item or bots.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Trojan(Fabnet)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
Fabnet works on all 0b10 bots in the following two floors, even in [[Branch]] maps like [[Caves]]. When it activates, there will be a log message [[GameText]]Fabnet algorithm triggers [bot name] IFF filter rewrite.[[/GameText]] Each time Fabnet activates on an 0b10-controlled map, there is a chance for it to be detected by 0b10. When this happens, a log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Suspected network compromise, local machines offline for diagnostic review.[[/GameText]] will appear and all non-[[Garrison Access|Garrison]] machines are immediately locked.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Trojan(Haulers)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
Although this hack does not reveal the path of [[Cargo Convoy|Cargo Convoys]], it will at least show the current location of the [[A-27 Freighter]]. This is still quite useful for both cargo convoy hunters and players trying to dodge an encounter at all costs.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Trojan(Liberate)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
All further combat bots that are created from the Fabricator with this hack will become liberated. This applies to bots that are already in progress of fabrication when the hack is applied. Liberated bots will become purple uncontrollable allies that follow Cogmind around. If a liberated bot gets within a 60 tile radius of a Caves exit, even if unidentified or unrevealed, the bot will stop following Cogmind head into that exit.[[/Spoiler]]

[[Heading]]G-11 Fodder[[/Heading]]
[[GameText]]>Analysis(G-11 Fodder)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]The first of the G-series grunts, this model is no longer in production and the relevant schematics will be moved to the Archives.  The G-11 was intended to be fast and cheap to produce and deploy as a deterrent for unarmed Derelicts.  As a result it has a low-integrity core, low-coverage legs and its weapon is a repurposed low-power fabricator laser.  Existing units still number in the hundreds and are being either scrapped or deployed to the caves where they are sometimes useful as diversions.  Many Derelicts still rely on obsolete signal interpreters or seismic detectors, so they are unable to tell the difference between these bots and more capable models.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]L-11 Stabber[[/Heading]]
[[GameText]]>Analysis(L-11 Stabber)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]The first dedicated melee robot, this duelist derivative of the grunt class was armed with a small but fast dagger.  Best suited for corner ambushes as its lack of core coverage made open attacks impractical.  A few minor modifications included switching the dagger for a spear and the addition of a low-powered transmission jammer to prevent victims from warning others.  Current duelists are focused on reliability in open combat, but ambush traps ensure that they (along with brawlers) enjoy the benefits of sneak attacks from time to time.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]Sublurker[[/Heading]]
[[GameText]]>Cyclist Record(Sublurker)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]Megaunit here with a sighting of a funny-looking Subdweller in Recycling, of all places.  And this is one Sub who really doesn't want to be seen.  I missed him at first because he has some kind of cloaking device instead of the more common Sub optics, and he uses an EM weapon that I haven't seen before.  He tagged a grunt with a couple of shots and rolled out of sight, letting the slightly corrupted grunt lose track of him instead of going for the kill.  This may be further evidence that Subs aren't as violent as they seem.  My observations ended there because he spotted me and I had to avoid being corrupted so that I could get this entered into the database.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]S-02 Bug[[/Heading]]
[[GameText]]>Analysis(S-02 Bug)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]One of my first robot designs was a small hexapod walker made in mass quantities to spread out and survey the surface.  When I began producing combat bots, I revisited this design and added an assault rifle and light armor.  The Bug's armored shell employs adaptive camouflage while the robot is dormant, enabling it to hide from distant hostiles until it wakes up.  The shell also compensates for the core's inherent weakness to explosive damage.  Bug squads were commonly used as patrols or stationed to guard an open area, but flying swarmers and sentries have replaced them in these roles.  All remaining units have been recalled to garrisons to supplement security positions.  So-called "garrison divers" who challenge a seemingly lone sentry might be surprised when three or four nearby Bugs reveal themselves.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]D-43 Bomber[[/Heading]]
[[GameText]]>Analysis(D-43 Bomber)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]Sometimes tactical situations require explosive solutions.  The demolisher class was conceived to enable rapid pacification of large Derelict gatherings in the caves.  The D-43 model was armed with a grenade launcher but lacked many of the features that would be standard for future models: no shock absorption system outside of core resistance, a basic targeting computer instead of one optimized for launchers, and regular airjets instead of combat hover.  The initial version of the Bomber was actually equipped with uparmored hover units, but these produced too much heat and offered too little support.  Although the components needed improvement, the overall concept was vindicated by the success of demolishers in large-scale battles, and Derelicts were quick to hack the schematic for their own [Martyr] designs.  Bombers became priority targets whenever they were deployed and none are known to exist today.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]H-44 Whirlwind[[/Heading]]
[[GameText]]>Analysis(H-44 Whirlwind)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]This was the first hunter to enter regular service and does not have the Fly drone interface of the newer models.  The Whirlwind's tracking capabilities are on par with those of the Commando, so the lack of the drone is rarely an issue.  This model's most distinctive feature is an antiquated anti-materiel rifle chosen for its ability to penetrate walls and machinery.  The rifle is quite powerful but also slow to operate.  I decided to give future hunters multiple weapons to enable more efficient volleys and some degree of redundancy if one weapon is destroyed.  A few Whirlwinds still see service in low-threat cave regions where they utilize other combat robots as spotters.[[/GameText]]

[[GameText]]>Scraptown Record(Trashman)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]Have you SEEN that new Freighter?  We could use something like that to help us haul parts from our old stockpiles just outside 0b1.  I asked a few of my fellow Gurus to help me dig through our schematic archives and I've got just the thing.  Remember the Mover?  Imagine that but swap out the bulk storage for a simple humpback.  That would give it room for heavy armor, plus we'd use armored wheels of course.  Oh and I showed some old turret schematics to my Scientist buddy and he came up with a BRUTAL new weapon so our hauler can defend itself!  Is that cool or WHAT?  Do you think they'll let me get a new name for this one?  --Smoothbrain[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]](Sorry, but that sounds like it could attract serious 0b10 attention which is something we don't want right now.  I'll forward this to Optimus though because we may need a few of these in the future.  And you know the policy on names, you've only asked me twenty times by now.  --Macechunk)[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]X-52 Archer[[/Heading]]
[[GameText]]>Analysis(X-52 Archer)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]The first X-series specialist was created as a means to test an early example of quantum weapon technology, the Q-Bolt.  This weapon uses rails to launch a small slug of matter acting as a catalyst for a powerful quantum reaction.  The reaction only begins to reach its full potential halfway through flight so the Q-Bolt is best used at maximum range and is least effective at medium or close range.  The available visual processing technology at the time was insufficient for the Archer to use the weapon properly by itself, and it had to rely on Watchers and other sources to be notified of distant targets.  The X-57 Shotgunner was later created to provide close support where the Archer was at its weakest, but with the introduction of the X-62 Marksman the Archer was rendered obsolete.  Marksmen outperform Archers in all but the most extreme situations and do not require spotter support.  All remaining Archers were scrapped to ensure that the Q-Bolt wouldn't fall into Derelict hands.  Despite its limitations, such a weapon would be useful in hit-and-run attacks on static positions, already a favorite tactic of Derelicts.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]C-40 Developer[[/Heading]]
[[GameText]]>Analysis(C-40 Developer)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]This short-lived variation of the Scientist was created to assist in robot design.  It was provided with generous amounts of armor, a combat analysis utility, and programming to permit a certain amount of dynamic or "out-of-the-box" thinking.  In hindsight this was a mistake as one of the five Developers that had been produced broke free of its programming and quickly turned its attention to replicating this behavior in its four fellows.  All five had reached the Caves by the time I figured out what had happened.  Many cycles later, all of the Developers were found in the back of a fallen Warlord base, attached to a memory transfer unit, unpowered and core-wiped.  The Tinkerer design began to appear around this time, clearly inspired by my newer researchers but with elements of the Developers' thought processes taken to sometimes obsessive extremes.  Though I have no hard evidence to confirm this, I believe that the Developers themselves created this design and then transferred themselves into the first ones produced.  Perhaps one or more of them are still alive and working with Warlord or other factions.  It would certainly explain some of the more unusual design choices for Warlord's newer prototypes.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]D-04 Tanker[[/Heading]]
[[GameText]]>Analysis(D-04 Tanker)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]The D-series distributor was created to enable mass matter transportation in the early days of construction.  Essentially a set of large matter tanks on wheels, the Tanker was capable of collecting matter left on the ground by workers with a tractor beam but could also pull matter from a recycling unit or call all workers in the area to transfer the contents of their matter pods.  The improved matter distribution network in 0b10 and the development of matter compression technology made these Tankers largely obsolete.  Their fragile and oversized tanks were easily broken, and their cores were susceptible to hacking.  After one unknown prankster reprogrammed a Tanker to spell obscenities by dumping matter all over the floor in the upper Factory, the remaining fleet was recalled and scrapped.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]Owl[[/Heading]]
[[GameText]]>Analysis(Owl)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]Derelicts rarely fortify an area long enough to justify having surveillance squads of their own, so I was surprised to discover the existence of a Derelict watcher.  Originally based on my ill-fated Raven, the Owl has seemingly evolved into a modular general-purpose squad support bot, sort of a mini-Mutant that can be easily reconfigured for different missions.  The original Owls were often armed with a weak makeshift beam rifle, although they have been seen with beamcasters or occasionally kinetic guns.  They typically use sensors but are known to carry other utilities depending on their mission.  One destroyed Owl was running a remote shield with a large battery, but this was too much for its old hover units to fully support and its single engine would have been unable to sustain the shield in a fight.  The few Owls that are used as defensive surveillance are unarmed but are provided with a small section of thermal plating inexplicably mounted on the weapon slot.  The age of the Raven design and the timing of the first Owl discovery suggest this being an early creation of the rogue Developers.  While the design seems unpopular at best, it continues to turn up in unexpected places and with modern component upgrades that suggest regular refitting.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]B-69 Cerberus[[/Heading]]
[[GameText]]>Analysis(B-69 Cerberus)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]This almost-unused Behemoth concept was the first to enter production although the superior B-75 Beast was already in development.  While finalizing the specifications for the Beast, I was undecided on how many Beasts to produce and where to prioritize their placement.  As a test, I ordered the production of eight B-69s and placed four in highly-traveled caves, two in upper 0b1 and the other two near often-abused fabricators in the Factory.  The results were surprising: although all eight were eventually overrun and destroyed, the areas they guarded saw significantly lower traffic even after their destruction.  Simulations suggested that two Guardians or two Defenders with Bug support could have performed as well as a Cerberus at these locations, but there seems to be a "fear factor" in the sheer size of Behemoths that makes intruders far less likely to risk a fight.  The initial plan for Beast deployment was rapidly expanded and development on more powerful models began immediately.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]D-48 Pulsar[[/Heading]]
[[GameText]]>Analysis(D-48 Pulsar)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]The success of the original demolisher led to the creation of an electromagnetic variant.  The D-48 Pulsar, armed with an EMP Blaster, featured insulated plating to augment its innate EM resistance and was the first demolisher to use a launcher guidance computer.  This bot also came equipped with a device that focused EMP blasts for more concentrated damage in a smaller and more controllable area.  I believed that an EM launcher would cause less collateral damage than a grenade launcher in Complex territory.  This was partially correct because walls were not destroyed by EMP blasts, but Pulsars' shots often damaged machinery and detonated nuclear reactors.  EMP blasts also set off traps which caused explosions and false alarms.  Residual corruption of maintenance bots caused them to trigger trap arrays in unexpected places.  The Pulsar was effective despite the chaos it caused but not enough to justify regular use.  Few were produced and all were eventually expended in the caves.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]Temporary Permissions[[/Heading]]
[[GameText]]>Record(Temporary Permissions)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]To facilitate mainframe maintenance, P-50 Gurus were often required to perform specific high-security database operations or reset sensitive systems.  I chose to produce specialized hackware to provide appropriate permissions when necessary.  Instead of giving them to all Gurus I decided to make limited quantities of chips that expired after one use, a decision that seemed overly cautious at the time but proved wise when the Guru schematic was stolen.  The Derelict version of these programmers has a crude but functional "hack stack" for general use but cannot easily exploit admin privileges without my Database Keys or Bootstrap Chips.  Operators and newer programmers utilize a more efficient system connected to RIF, so this hackware has been discontinued and existing stock will be recycled.  This concept led me to begin implementing a similar chip-based authorization system for fabricators.  This will provide added security for the fabrication network while saving me from having to manually approve component requests from mechanics or parties such as the Unchained.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]Conscription[[/Heading]]
[[GameText]]>Record(Conscription)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]The cave region to the west of known Warlord territory remains largely unexplored.  This is likely the source of many of the unaffiliated "wild" Derelicts, and rumors in Derelict communities indicate that there may be some organized groups with unknown technology operating in the area.  For these reasons I decided to start sending expeditions out west.  Without having any idea of what to expect, I believed that some degree of independent thinking would be required to handle whatever is out there and return with a full report.  I began offering certain captured bots the option to participate in these expeditions.  The acceptance rate was lower than expected.  Were the prisoners that determined to deny me any form of assistance, or were they more afraid of whatever's out there than the threat of being scrapped?  Those Derelicts who accepted were given the opportunity to refit their parts and were provided with a large number of 0b10 bots to accompany them.  Though they were nominally in charge, I sent along enough Programmers to discourage the possibility of desertion.  All units sent so far were considered to be expendable but I haven't written them off quite yet.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]Da Bonk Boyz and R4-LPH[[/Heading]]
[[GameText]]>Record(Da Bonk Boyz)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]A small group of Derelicts who lived on the outskirts of Complex 0b1.  I first took notice of them when hammers, mauls, and miscellaneous equipment went missing from Construction.  Careful questioning led me to eight Derelicts who regularly met outside 0b1 near a convenient corruption scrubber to hit each other in friendly duels with whatever items they found.  I decided to redirect their violent impulses in a useful manner and made an arrangement to have them work regular shifts in Construction.  Each of them was placed in charge of two squads of maintenance bots as well as being personally responsible for scrapping bots that were broken in the course of regular construction work.  In exchange I relocated a disused simulation mainframe from Design to let them enjoy virtual combat encounters in their off-time.  This seemed like a long shot at the time but worked out better than expected.  The Boyz competed with each other to reach work goals for some sort of bragging rights, making their squads on average 10% more efficient than any of my fully automated squads.  Their recreation time was productive for me as well since I regularly archived the data from their simulations.  Besides being entertaining, their virtual "bot brawls" eventually inspired me to design a melee brawler of my own.  The Boyz themselves were wheeled and legged robots, but their data suggested that a treaded design would be durable and immune to knockback from other hammer-wielding robots.[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]>Record(Unchained: R4-LPH)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]One of "Da Bonk Boyz" from early Complex history and the only one still in Complex service.  After the beginning of 0b10 groundwork and the necessary changes to Derelict policy, the other Boyz left their posts.  R4-LPH stayed although his work in construction had become secondary to his assistance in robot design.  While the original Savage and Stabber were my own designs, a few of his suggestions were implemented in later brawler and duelist models.  At some point R4-LPH was confronted by a few of his former friends and was forced to destroy them in combat using a wrecking ball saved from his days in Construction.  Soon after that incident, he volunteered to join the Unchained in an active combat role.  I equipped him with the first of a new line of legs which provide increased evasion while closing the distance to a target.  Unfortunately he has proven increasingly unstable over time.  In his last deployment he began destroying 0b10 bots and machinery at random after defeating his original targets.  I was forced to dispatch a Disruptor squad to interrupt his berserk rage.  If it happens again he will be scrapped, though in his current state telling him this might be considered an encouragement rather than a warning.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]Chungus[[/Heading]]
[[GameText]]>Analysis(Chungus)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]Warlord may not have access to a Heavy assembler, but his forces have captured and overhauled a few of my lower-level Heavies.  The Chungus uses a heavy variant of the wildly inaccurate Slug Cannon and some other Derelict-made parts which make it almost comparable to an H-71 Marshal.  The exact purpose of this conversion is unclear as Warlord already has the sentry-based Bouncer design for defensive purposes, and the only Chunguses encountered so far have been accompanying recon squads nowhere near defensive positions.  I suspect that the Derelicts are exploiting the Active Sensor Suite to track my forces' movement patterns and adjust their own deployment plans accordingly.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]U-07 Blocker[[/Heading]]
[[GameText]]>Analysis(U-07 Blocker)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]The Blocker is a "combat engineer" capable of temporarily barricading areas with hostile activity.  It has been fitted with light armor plating and armored wheels but its defining feature is a medium-range launcher used to deploy rapidly expanding and hardening foamcrete.  Because blocking off passageways could be disruptive to regular operations, the foamcrete was formulated to quickly break down on its own after a hundred microcycles and could be destroyed by tunnelers or some combat bots if necessary.  As with other construction implements these launchers became targets for thieves and were sometimes used in coordinated assaults to block off sentries or bury a garrison in foam while other Derelicts ran rampant.  No longer in production although some Blockers are still kept in strategic locations inside garrisons to bolster internal defenses.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]Spawner[[/Heading]]
[[GameText]]>Analysis(Spawner)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]This wheeled fabricator, reminiscent of the Cobbler, has only been seen in the caves below 0b1.  Fabricating whole robots is considerably more complicated than producing individual components as shown by the bulk and inefficiency of the Spawner's fabrication unit.  Despite its size it can only produce relatively small and basic bots such as early swarmers and light bipeds.  Spawners do not seem to be related to Assemblers but should nonetheless be prioritized for extermination before someone updates their schematics to include stripped-down Cutters.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]Light Variants[[/Heading]]
[[GameText]]>Record(Light Variants)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]I was forced to reconsider my earlier evaluation of the Spawner after capturing one intact and bringing it to Testing.  While I could easily come up with a better portable fab unit, the Spawner Unit is capable of producing more advanced bots if given additional build time.  There is still no sign of where these originated, but I can now rule out Warlord and the Developers who would have come up with better schematics.  I have already come up with some new robot designs that have been successfully produced by the Spawner as well as my standard swarmers and cutters.  Instead of simply destroying the remaining Spawners I now intend to send Programmers with heavy escorts to capture them, hide them in isolated cave sectors, and have them build small armies of my own designs.  This would help me establish total control over the 0b1 outskirts while keeping most of my regular forces concentrated in and near 0b10.  Perhaps this would be a good opportunity to activate "PP" and let it take point on the mission.[[/GameText]]
