Other.Name: FarCom
Other.Content:
[[Image]]FarCom Sensors.png|FarCom sensors revealing nearby hostiles[[/Image]]
[[Image]]FarCom.gif|Using the FarCom Aligner machine[[/Image]]
FarCom is one of the major faction [[Alignment|alignments]] available to Cogmind in most runs. Taking FarCom aligns Cogmind with the [[Exiles (Group)]] for the rest of the game. It provides a permanent 18 tile radius sensor for hostile [[0b10]] bots within 0b10 controlled map. This sensor cannot be jammed by [[Watcher|Watchers]] or masked by [[Heavy|Heavies]] unlike standard [[Sensor Arrays]]. The primary limitation of the FarCom sensor is that it doesn't work in any [[Caves]] branches. One other side-effect is that entering specific [[Research]] branches becomes much more dangerous. Occasionally the Exiles may have been abandoned or attacked, and FarCom is not an option in these runs.
[[Heading:2]]Gaining FarCom[[/Heading]]
Taking FarCom can be done in most runs in the [[Exiles (Location)|Exiles]] map off of either -10 or -9 [[Mines]]. After talking to [[EX-BIN]], walk into the FarCom Aligner machine. Cogmind can take up to 1 special vault item (or multiples of the same type). If Cogmind takes more than 1 type of item then the Exiles will notice you stealing when entering [[Factory]] and FarCom will be removed. Also, becoming hostile to the Exiles will result in instantly losing FarCom. If Cogmind takes FarCom, it is not possible to [[Imprint]]: [[Spoiler]]The [[Imprinter]] will be disappointed in Cogmind and warn you to leave right away. Attempting to use the Imprinting machine will result in turning all the bots at [[Zion]] hostile. Taking FarCom excludes cogmind from affiliating with the [[UFD|UFD]]. There are no other alignment restrictions with FarCom.[[/Spoiler]]
[[Heading:2]]Research Branch side-effect[[/Heading]]
When entering -3 Research, the Exiles will send a warning message to Cogmind indicating not to enter Research branches. If Cogmind does anyway, [[Spoiler]]immediately when entering [[Testing]], [[Quarantine]] [[Maximum Security]] will instantly be triggered. This will also lock the exits to [[Section 7]] and [[Protoforge]]. Note that this does not include [[Armory]] when it is on -3. The immediate response is machines shut down right after entering the level, 4 [[Sentry]] spawns at each [[Garrison]] and exit, and 6 Assault [[C-30 ARC|ARCs]] sent at Cogmind shortly after. Unless Cogmind is prepared to fight off large waves of enemies or outrun them, these maps should not be entered.[[/Spoiler]]

Other.Name: Game Mechanics
Other.Content: [[List]][[Alert]] - Semi-hidden number that represents Cogmind's perceived threat level. Has dangerous consequences when too high.|[[Allies]] - Bots friendly to [[Cogmind]].|[[Cave-ins]] - Mechanic that causes dug out walls to collapse and deal large amounts of damage.|[[Corruption]] - Stat that has various negative penalties and can result in death.|[[Energy]] - Stat that is used to power most parts in the game.|[[Heat]] - Stat that can cause overheating side-effects and deaths in non-immune bots.|[[Matter]] - Stat that is used as a resource to attach parts and shoot some types of weapons.|[[Overload]] - Mechanic that can increase effectiveness of parts with a possible downside.|[[Sneak Attack]] - Attack that does doubled melee damage in certain circumstances.[[/List]]

Other.Name: Garrison Access
Other.Content:
[[Image]]../game_sprites/Garrison.png|A Garrison Access machine[[/Image]]
Garrison Accesses are heavily armored [[0b10]]-controlled [[Interactive Machine|Machines]] that primarily serve as a dispatch point for 0b10 [[Squad|Squads]] and as an exit into the [[Garrison|Garrison map]]. Cogmind can open Garrisons Accesses to go inside of them or seal them to prevent further dispatches from that location. Garrison Accesses can appear in every main 0b10 map starting from -8 [[Materials]]. They can also appear in [[Storage]], [[Hub_04(d)]], [[Testing]], [[Quarantine]], [[Section 7]], and [[Protoforge]].

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Garrison Access[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Squad Dispatches[[/Heading]]
All standard 0b10 squad dispatches like [[Investigation Squad|Investigations]] and [[Reinforcement Squad|Reinforcements]] can come from a Garrison. A unique [[Garrison Squad]] can be dispatched when hostilities are reported nearby. Bots within a 20 tile radius can sometimes summon this squad when attacked. Hitting the Garrison machine itself and failing to destroy it can also summon this type of squad.

[[Heading]][[Relay Couplers|Relay Coupler]] restocking[[/Heading]]
Garrison Accesses typically have 3-4 Relay Couplers stored within them. Occasionally, they will disappear, presumably being retrieved for use within the Garrison. When this happens, a [[Coupling Squad]] will be dispatched to the Garrison. When it arrives, 3-4 new Relay Couplers will be deposited into the machine.

[[Heading]]Armor values[[/Heading]]
Garrisons are heavily armored against Kinetic and Explosive damage (30% and 67% resistance respectively), but are slightly weak to Thermal and Electromagnetic damage (-25% and -50% weakness respectively). The following table lists how much damage of each type is required to be able to break a Garrison machine.
[[Table]]
Security Level|Armor Value|Kinetic Damage|Thermal Damage|Electromagnetic Damage|Melee Damage||
1|25|36|20|17|25||
2|40|58|32|27|40||
3|50|72|40|34|50
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Destruction/Sealing[[/Heading]]
When a Garrison is either sealed or destroyed, it adds an additional 75 turns per average dispatch check to the [[Extermination Squad]] dispatch timer. For example, rather than a chance for Extermination to occur every 250 turns, it will occur every 325 turns instead when the first Garrison is destroyed/sealed. This effect is cumulative for multiple Garrisons.
When a Garrison is destroyed by any means while active, there will be an alert [[GameText]]ALERT: Garrison Access compromised, dispatching assault squad.[[/GameText]] and an [[Assault Squad]] will be dispatched to the Garrison's location. Cogmind's [[Alert]] will be increased by 150 when this happens. If the Garrison has already been sealed, neither of these effects occur. Additionally, there is a chance that installed Relay Couplers may be ejected onto the ground when a Garrison is destroyed. This chance is separate per coupler.

[[Heading]]Hacks[[/Heading]]
[[Hacks]]Garrison[[/Hacks]]
[[Heading:2]]Additional Details/Usage Tips[[/Heading]]If [[RIF]] is installed, all direct Garrison hacks have 100% success rate.
[[Spoiler]][[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Force(Eject)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
While using this hack does trigger a machine lockdown, the Garrison itself will remain open if opened beforehand. This allows for looting any Relay Couplers in the Garrison while still entering it.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Trojan(Reprogram)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
Like [[GameText]]Force(Eject)[[/GameText]], a Garrison can be opened preemptively and the Garrison won't seal itself when the effect triggers. This can be useful to take additional allies into the Garrison.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Trojan(Restock)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
Summons a Coupling Squad to the Garrison immediately, but only once. It's best to not hang around the immediate area since the [[Programmer]] may appear out of the Garrison itself and blow it up if it is a low security level. This hack can be used to obtain a [[Remote Datajack]] on -8 before Programmers typically spawn.[[/Spoiler]]

Other.Name: Garrison Squad
Other.Content:
[[Image]]Garrison Squads.png|3 Garrison Squads of Sentries roaming around[[/Image]]
Garrison squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are dispatched whenever hostilities are reported within a 20 tile radius around a [[Garrison Access]]. This can occur any time an 0b10 bot is attacked and survives to report it or if a Garrison is attacked by Cogmind or an ally. They patrol around the Garrison for about 200 turns, then return back into the Garrison. These squads only have a chance to spawn and are not guaranteed. Garrison squads can be Enumerated at a [[Terminal]].
[[Image]]Garrison Redeploying.png|A Garrison redeploying, unable to deploy squads for 34 turns[[/Image]]
[[Image]]Garrison Transmitting.png|A Garrison transmitting, soon to deploy another squad[[/Image]]
If the Garrison was activated by a nearby non-combat bot reporting an attack like a [[K-01 Serf]], a single squad will be dispatched from the Garrison, and a 100 turn cooldown will occur before the Garrison can dispatch another Garrison squad. If a combat bot reported the attack, three squads will be dispatched from the Garrison. Once is sent immediately, and two more after 100 and 200 turns. A 100 turn cooldown will occur after the third squad is dispatched. If the Garrison was damaged, one squad will be sent out immediately, with two more squads after 25 and 50 turns. A 50 turn cooldown follows in this case. The combat and non-combat bot versions of these squads can be entirely prevented by using [[Transmission Jammers]].
[[Signal Interpreters]] will indicate the timer between dispatches as a red number and the cooldown during which no squads can be dispatched as a yellow number. The Garrison will indicate that it is Transmitting when new squads are soon to arrive, and Redeploying when on cooldown. Keep in mind, the cooldown only prevents the Garrison from dispatching more Garrison squads and does not prevent other squad types like [[Reinforcement Squad|Reinforcements]] and [[Investigation Squad|Investigations]].

[[Heading]]Composition[[/Heading]]
If the Garrison squad was triggered by a non-combat bot reporting an attack or by the Garrison itself being attacked, the Garrison will only send out single [[Sentry|Sentries]] for the squads. If a combat bot reported an attack instead, the following squad compositions are possible:
[[List]]1 [[Brawler]] and 1 [[Duelist]]|1 [[Demolisher]], only if Cogmind has 1 or more allies|1-2 [[Grunt|Grunts]]|1-2 Sentries|2-3 [[Swarmer|Swarmers]][[/List]]

Other.Name: Heat
Other.Content:
[[Image]]https://i.ibb.co/61bVjz5/2024-08-13-14-47-43-Window.png|State / Current Heat / Heat Per Turn / Heat Per Turns Spent Moving[[/Image]]
Movement, firing weapons, and running power sources and some utilities generates heat, as does being hit by thermal weapons. Some of this heat is naturally dissipated by the core's own heat sinks, but not enough to deal with heat generated by numerous/large energy weapons. Heat sinks and cooling systems can be used to avoid overheating, which can have a wide range of negative effects. Heat is only a significant issue for robots that rely heavily on energy weapons. However, note that when firing a volley the heat produced is averaged over the volley's turn duration rather than being immediately applied all at once.

[[Heading]]Side Effects[[/Heading]]
Once heat reaches the "Hot" level (200+), active utilities and weapons may be temporarily disabled. At "Warning" levels (300+) power sources are likely to shut down. Many more serious (and permanent) effects are possible, especially at higher heat levels, [[B]]such as core damage[[/B]].

Disabled power sources automatically restart when possible, but other parts must be manually reactivated.

Heat effects are not calculated until after the dissipation phase, so heat can temporarily spike very high with no side effects as long as there are sufficient utilities to dissipate it.

[[Heading]]Cooling Resolution[[/Heading]]
Eventually you will discover a range of different mechanics that factor into heat management, especially with regard to cooling parts, thus knowing the specific order of operations between them may be of help for min-maxers seeking to optimize a build. Below is a list of heat-related processes that play out once per turn. Note that you most likely DO NOT need to know this stuff, but it may help answer a few specific questions min-maxers have about prioritization.

[[List:Ordered]]
Add heat from all sources, including that generated by active attached parts, gradual heat from an ongoing weapon volley, and any ambient heat. Spread combined volley heat across its duration, in other words a 3-turn volley which according to its weapon properties generates 100 heat adds 33 heat per turn until complete.|
If used the unique "ITN" artifact, automatically drop heat to 250 if above that value.|
Subtract innate heat dissipation.|
Subtract heat dissipation from direct cooling utilities such as Heat Sinks and Cooling Systems.|
If heat exceeds 200, apply dissipation effects of disposable cooling systems such as Coolant Injectors, up to that threshold. If more disposable systems than necessary, apply them in parts list order.|
If heat exceeds 200, apply self-damaging ablative cooling systems such as Mak. Ablative Armor. If using multiple ablative systems at once, dissipation is split into equal-sized chunks for each, where if one system fails, the entire chunk it is responsible for is still successfully dissipated.|
If heat exceeds 200, apply broad-effect ablative cooling systems such as Mak. Microdissipator Network.[[/List]]

Other.Name: High Security
Other.Content:
[[Image]]High Security Assaults.png|A wave of Assaults dispatched after Cogmind[[/Image]]High Security is an [[0b10]] response to Cogmind causing too much destruction on a floor. It can be triggered by having a very high [[Alert]] level (5X/1600 influence) and by killing further 0b10 bots. After being triggered, machines will be shut down, guards will be dispatched at exits, and increasingly large waves of [[Assault Squad|Assaults]] will be dispatched to Cogmind's position.
High Security can be triggered on the majority of 0b10-controlled maps, excluding [[DSF|DSFs]] and [[Garrison|Garrisons]]. Although 1600 influence is the start of the Alert range, there is only a chance of triggering. The higher Cogmind's alert gets, the more likely it is that High Security begins. Each kill of an 0b10 combat bot, whether by Cogmind, a Cogmind controlled ally, or even a neutral Derelict, can trigger it.
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|High Security[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Timeline of Events[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]High Security Garrison.png|Sentries dispatched to protect a Garrison[[/Image]]
[[Image]]High Security Exit.png|Sentires dispatched to protect an 0b10-controlled exit[[/Image]]
[[List]]0: Log message [[GameText]]ALERT: High security lockdown imminent, T-100.[[/GameText]]|
50: Machines shut down and Chute traps disappear, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Machine network offline.[[/GameText]] Note: [[Garrison Access|Garrisons]] that are already opened will remain open|
65: Trojans are removed from all machines, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Performing unscheduled system reset.[[/GameText]]|
80: 4 [[Sentry|Sentries]] dispatched at each 0b10-controlled exit and Garrison, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Lockdown in effect, collecting threat data.[[/GameText]]|
100: First assault wave dispatched, 4 assaults dispatched from nearby 0b10-controlled exits and Garrisons.|
200: Second wave, 4 assaults dispatched|
350: Third wave, 6 assaults dispatched including heavy assaults with stronger bots|
550: Fourth wave, 8 assaults dispatched including heavy assaults|
800: Fifth wave, 10 assaults dispatched including heavy assaults|
Etc. - Delay between assaults continues to increase by 50 and number of assaults per wave continues to increase by 2[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Exiting High Security[[/Heading]]
The only 2 ways to exit High Security are to trigger [[Sterilization]] after killing enough combat hostiles or to exit the map. Otherwise, an infinite number of Assaults will continue to be dispatched. One unique map [[Command]] has special behavior: [[Redacted]]Since there are a limited number of [[C-30 ARC|ARCs]] on the map, no more assaults will come for Cogmind after they have been depleted. However, the alerts that assaults are dispatched never stop coming.[[/Redacted]]

Other.Name: Imprint
Other.Content:
Imprint is one of the major faction [[Alignment|alignments]] available to Cogmind in a run. It closely allies Cogmind with the [[Imprinter]] and with Zionites as a whole, with Cogmind being determined to be the Zionites' savior. Imprinting majorly changes the game, as it disables all standard [[Terminal]] hacks except for limited access Terminal hacking. Instead, there are a new set of imprint-specific hacks that are available at all Terminals. After imprinting, there is a 10 tile "ping" radius on all standard Terminals which will tell Cogmind their location, even through walls. However, if an [[Operator]] is nearby when this happens, the Operator will shut down the Terminal and call for [[Reinforcement Squad|Reinforcements]]. After about 1200-1500 turns on an [[0b10]]-controlled map, the Terminal network will be shut down with an accompanying log [[GameText]]Terminal network compromised, cutting hard line.[[/GameText]]
[[Image]]Zion Imprinting.gif|Using the imprinting machine[[/Image]]
[[Heading:2]]Imprinting[[/Heading]]
Imprinting is performed on the [[Zion]] map by walking into the imprinting machine on the bottom left corner of the map. The UI will turn orange, and the 4 nearby [[Mutant (6)|Mutants]] will turn purple and follow Cogmind around.

[[Heading]]Special Terminal Hacks[[/Heading]]
There are 2 types of special Terminal hacks, roster and intel.
[[Image]]Imprint Hacks.png|A selection of special Imprint hacks[[/Image]]
[[Heading:2]]Roster Hacks[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Imprint Summoning.gif|Summoning 2 Zionites with a roster hack[[/Image]]
Roster hacks summon combat allies or special [[Z-Courier]] haulers containing part resupplies. The allies and hauler contents here are depth-dependent and will grow stronger at higher depths. The hauler contents can include [[Prototype Part|Prototypes]] which can be faulty, so having some way to identify prototypes like a [[Component Analysis Suite]] is very useful before equipping. Using a roster hack will destroy the Terminal when the reinforcements are teleported in after a few turns. There are a limited number of roster hacks available on a given map, starting at 2 slots on -6, increasing every floor up to the cap of 6 slots on -2. Roster hacks will occasionally be rerolled, which can add new roster types or reroll existing types. All roster allies summoned will appear as purple uncontrollable allies which contribute to [[Alert]]. The exception is any summonable [[Z-Hero|Z-Heroes]] which appear as pink, but otherwise behave as purple allies.
One thing to keep in mind about roster rallies is that they will not attack enemies unless Cogmind is close and within line of sight. This can be both a bad and good thing. It is often bad when hostiles are hanging just around a corner and the Zionites get stuck trying to get Cogmind back in line of sight and trying to turn around the corner to fight. When stuck in this case, try to get Cogmind's line of sight over the direction the allies are trying to go. However, it may be good if Cogmind doesn't want the roster allies to stick around long and get lots of kills, racking up lots of alert. It is possible to manipulate the bots to not attack back even when they are being attacked while standing around a corner.
If Cogmind is not careful about friendly fire, roster hacks can become temporarily disabled. The length of the lockout can vary depending on the amount of friendly fire. In extreme cases, Cogmind can be locked out for the remainder of the game. Killing imprint allies directly is not recommended for this reason. Instead, it is best to try to allow allies to be killed naturally if their loot is desired
The available ally-summoning roster hacks are as follows:
[[Table]]
Type|Depths|Summon||
Demo|-6 and -5|1-2 [[Martyr (5)]]||
|-4+|1-2 [[Martyr (7)]]||
Experimental|-3+|[[Z-Experimental (10)]]||
Hacker|-6 and -5|2-3 [[Wizard (5)]]||
|-4+|2-3 [[Wizard (7)]]||
Fire|-6 and -5|3-4 [[Fireman (5)]]||
|-4+|3-4 [[Fireman (7)]]||
Heavy|-6 and -5|1-2 [[Z-Heavy (5)]]||
|-4 to -3|1-2 [[Z-Heavy (7)]]||
|-2 and -1|1-2 [[Z-Heavy (9)]]||
Hero|-6+|A random [[Z-Hero]]||
Light|-6 and -5|2-3 [[Z-Light (5)]]||
|-4 and -3|2-3 [[Z-Light (7)]]||
|-2 and -1|2-3 [[Z-Light (9)]]||
Recon|-6+|A [[Z-Drone Bay]], not a bot directly
[[/Table]]
Resupply rosters are entirely delivered inside a single Z-Courier. The available resupply roster hacks are as follows:
[[Table]]
Type|Number of parts|Available parts||
Defense Resupply|8|Defensive Utilities including [[Point Defense Systems]], [[Armor]], [[Core Shieldings]], [[Graphene Brace|Graphene Braces]], [[Hardlight Generators]], [[Power Shieldings]], [[Propulsion Shieldings]], [[Resistance Devices]], [[Shield Generators]], [[Force Fields]], [[Utility Shieldings]], and [[Weapon Shieldings]]||
Explosive Resupply|2|Explosive [[Launchers]]||
Hacking Resupply|2|[[Hackware]]||
Heavy Resupply|4|[[Armor]], [[Hcp. Storage Unit|Hcp.]] and [[Huge Storage Unit|Huge Storage Units]], and [[Treads]]||
Hover Resupply|8|[[Hover Units]]||
Infowar Resupply|4|infowar Utilities including [[0b10 Decoder Chips]], [[Cloaking Devices]], [[ECM Suites]], [[Machine Analyzer]], [[Seismic Detector]], [[Sensor Arrays]], [[Signal Interpreters]], [[Terrain Scanners]], [[Terrain Scan Processors]], [[Transmission Jammers]], [[Trap Scanners]], [[Triangulator]], and [[Visual Processing Units]]||
Kinetic Resupply|8|[[Ballistic Cannons]], [[Ballistic Guns]], and offensive Utilities including [[Matter Filters]] and [[Recoil Stabilizers]]||
Melee Resupply|4|[[Impact Weapons|Impact]], [[Piercing Weapons|Piercing]], and [[Slashing Weapons|Slashing]] weapons, including unique Derelict weapons like [[Particle Cleaver|Particle Cleavers]] and [[CR-A16's Behemoth Slayer]], as well as offensive Utilities including [[Actuators]], [[Actuator Arrays]], [[Melee Analysis Suites]], and [[Force Boosters]]||
Offense Resupply|4|Offensive utilities including [[Armor Integrity Analyzers]], [[Core Analyzers]], [[Launcher Guidance Computers]], [[Kinecellerators]], [[Launcher Loader]], [[Melee Analysis Suites]], [[Particle Chargers]], [[Tactical Coordination Suite]], [[Target Analyzers]], [[Ranged Targeting Utilities]], [[Weapon Cyclers]], and [[Weapon Mount]]||
Resource Resupply|12|Storage or resource-related Utilities, including [[Energy Wells]], [[Field Recycling Units]], [[Matter Compressors]], [[Storage Unit|Storage Units]], and [[Tractor Beams]]. All resource-containing utilities will be filled.||
Thermal Resupply|8|Thermal [[Energy Cannons]], [[Energy Guns]], and offensive Utilities including [[Cooling Devices]], [[Coolant Injectors]], [[Energy Filters]], [[Particle Chargers]], and [[Quantum Capacitor|Quantum Capacitors]]||
Trap Resupply|16|[[Traps]] and a basic [[Trap Extractor]]||
Zionite Resupply|6|Zionite parts including [[Zio. Alpha Cannon]] and [[Zio. Alpha Cannon Mk. II|Mk. II]], [[Zio. Biocell]] and [[Zio. Biocell Array|Biocell Arrays]], [[Zio. Composite Leg I]], [[Zio. Composite Leg II|II]], and [[Zio. Supercomposite Leg]], [[Zio. Glidesys I]] and [[Zio. Glidesys II|II]], [[Zio. Laser-S]], [[Zio. Laser-M|M]], and [[Zio. Laser-H|H]], [[Zio. Light Carapace|Zio. Light]] and [[Zio. Heavy Carapace|Heavy]] Carapaces, [[Zio. Light DM Reactor|Zio. Light]] and [[Zio. Heavy DM Reactor|Heavy]] Reactors, [[Zio. Phaser-S]], [[Zio. Phaser-M|M]], and [[Zio. Phaser-H|H]], [[Zio. Shade Carapace]] and [[Zio. Shade Armor|Armor]], and [[Zio. Weapon Casing]]
[[/Table]]
[[Heading:2]]Intel hacks[[/Heading]]
Intel hacks provide Cogmind with different types of information about the current, and upcoming maps. Unlike roster hacks, intel hacks require two Terminals to use and are not instantaneous. Performing an intel hack locks the Terminal, but does not provide any information until the next Terminal is used to retrieve that intel. Retrieving intel does not lock the Terminal, however, so chaining intel retrieval with other hacks is still possible.
There are initially 4 intel hacks available per 0b10 floor. Performing intel hacks reduces the number available until there are only 2 hacks remaining. At that point, each intel hack will cause another random intel hack to become available. Unlike the fixed limit of roster hacks, intel hacks are not restricted on any given floor and are only limited by the total number of Terminals.
There are 2 categories of intel hacks: Repeatable and non-repeatable. Non-repeatable hacks can only be performed once per map. These types of hacks include map-specific intel and world map intel relating to the overall depth that certain locations occur on. Repeatable hacks can be performed an infinite number of times on any floor and tend to be longer-term types of information such as schematics and analyses. If trying to burn through intel for a specific piece of information, such as main or branch access, it is best to pick any non-repeatable hacks first. This will allow the pool of available hacks to get smaller, increasing the chances of getting the desired intel hack.
The available intel hacks are as follows:
[[Table]]
Hack Name|Repatable|Effect||
Active Garrisons|No|Reveals all [[Garrison Access|Garrisons]] on the current map||
Active Terminals|No|Reveals all Terminals on the current map||
Branch Access|No|Reveals all Derelict-known [[Branch]] exits on the current map[[Sub]]1[[/Sub]]||
Component Schematics|Yes|Gives 12-16 random non-Prototype [[Fabricator]] schematics||
Component Stockpiles|No|Reveals locations of all non-Prototype part stockpiles on the current map||
Depthwide Sectors/0|No|Reveals all Derelict-known maps on the current depth[[Sub]]1[[/Sub]]||
Depthwide Sectors/-1|No|Reveals all Derelict-known maps on the next depth[[Sub]]1[[/Sub]]||
Emergency Access|No|Reveals all emergency access doors on the current map||
Guard Positions|No|Reveals current locations (but not types) of all [[Behemoth]], [[Heavy]], and all [[Sentry]] bots on the map||
Main Access|No|Reveals all main exits on the current map||
Prototype Schematics|Yes|Gives 8-12 random Prototype Fabricator schematics||
Prototype Stockpiles|No|Reveals locations of all Prototype part stockpiles on the current map||
Trap Installations|No|Reveals positions and types of all traps on the current map||
Unaware Analyses|Yes|Gives 3 random 0b10 bot [[Robot Analysis|Analyses]]||
Unaware Schematics|Yes|Gives 3 random 0b10 bot Fabricator schematics
[[/Table]]
[[List:Ordered]]Derelicts are unaware of the following maps and map exits: [[Access_0]], [[Lab]], [[Protoforge]], [[Section 7]], and [[Zhirov (Location)]][[/List]]
[[Redacted]][[Heading]][[Command]] Cave Seals[[/Heading]]
Imprinting has special cave seal interactions. Instead of the standard wild cave Derelicts, friendly Zionites will appear from the seal instead. These allies will be purple and uncontrollable by default. However, if a Core Reset Matrix has been consumed, all of the Z-bots will turn blue and become controllable.[[/Redacted]]

[[Heading]]Alignment Incompatibilities[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:2]]Blocking Alignment[[/Heading]]
The following will prevent Cogmind from being able to Imprint:
[[List]][[RIF]]: Zion will become hostile to a Cogmind that has installed RIF|[[FarCom]]: The Imprinter distrusts the Exiles and will refuse to let Cogmind Imprint|[[UFD]]: The Imprinter needs more preparation and vetting before any UFD member is allowed to use the Imprinting machine[[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]Blocked Alignments[[/Heading]]
An Imprinted Cogmind loses the ability to receive help from a few NPCs. These effects apply even if Cogmind enters the [[Zion Deep Caves]] and loses the special Terminal hacks:
[[List]][[Revision 17 (Alignment)]]: [[Revision 17]] will distrust an Imprinted Cogmind and refuse to help|[[Warlord (Alignment)]]: [[Warlord]] will be disappointed in Cogmind and refuse to perform the -2 [[Research]] invasion[[/List]]

Other.Name: Interactive Machine
Other.Content:
Interactive machines are types of machines that Cogmind can hack for a variety of effects. They are most commonly found in [[0b10]]-controlled floors, although some machines, especially [[Terminal|Terminals]], can be found in many locations. 0b10 combat and non-combat bots will interact with each of these machines in different ways. Interactive machines have a security level between 1 and 3 that determines how difficult it is to hack at them.

[[Heading]]Types of Interactive Machines[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]../game_sprites/Fabricator.png|[[Fabricator]]: Create parts and bots from schematics|../game_sprites/Garrison.png|[[Garrison Access|Garrison]]: Dispatches 0b10 squads, also serves as an entrance into the [[Garrison|Garrison map]]|../game_sprites/Recycling.png|[[Recycling Unit]]: [[Recycler|Recyclers]] deposit parts into this machine and recycle them into matter|../game_sprites/Repair Station.png|[[Repair Station]]: Can repair parts, refit backup parts, and serves as a home point of [[Mechanic|Mechanics]]|../game_sprites/Scanalyzer.png|[[Scanalyzer]]: Scans parts in inventory to create schematics that can be used for fabricating|../game_sprites/Terminal.png|[[Terminal]]: Provides many miscellaneous hacks, sometimes are guarded by [[Operator|Operators]][[/Gallery]]

[[Heading]]Hacking[[/Heading]]
Each type of machine has a number of hacks that can be used that are listed in the hacking interface, labeled from A up to Y at most, called direct hacks. Hacks can be performed on Terminals specifically that are not listed by manually typing the name of the hack in. Performing a hack this way is called indirect hacking and has an additional penalty added to it. This penalty is an additional -15% per security level.
[[Heading:2]]Being Detected[[/Heading]]
As Cogmind hacks a machine, there is a chance of detection on each hack. The chance of detection can be reduced by [[Defensive Hackware]], but not lower than 10%. [[Spoiler]]Blowing up Hub machines in [[Hub_04(d)]] provides a stacking reduction along with defensive hackware.[[/Spoiler]] If detected on a hack that was successful, the machine's trace percent will start at 0%. If detected on a failing hack the trace percent will be anywhere from 1% to (100% - (hack success rate). The initial trace percent can also be reduced by defensive hackware. Once tracing has begun, subsequent hacks will increase the trace progress until reaching 100%. The amount of progress depends on the security level of the machine, whether a hack was successful or not, and the amount of defensive hackware equipped. Defensive hackware can reduce the trace percent gained per hack to no fewer than 15% on a successful hack and 25% on an unsuccessful hack.
[[Heading:2]]Being Fully Traced[[/Heading]]
If a machine's trace percentage reaches 100%, Cogmind will be fully traced. If this happens, the log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Suspicious activity at [machine name]. Dispatching Investigation Squad.[[/GameText]] will appear and there are three negative consequences:
[[List]]Machine lockout: The machine will become locked and further hacking will not be possible. [[Spoiler]]Trojans with effects over time will generally still remain operational when applied to the machine, with the exception of Trojan(Skim).[[/Spoiler]]|[[Investigation Squad]]: A squad is dispatched to the location of the machine.|Feedback: Feedback may inflict 1% [[Corruption]] on Cogmind and fry hackware attached to Cogmind. This feedback may be prevented with Defensive Hackware.[[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]Security level[[/Heading]]
Security level has different effects on machine hacking. Some are specific to certain kinds of machines, but the following effects are common between all machines:
[[List]]Hacking penalty: Direct hacks on security level 2 machines have a 50% success rate compared to level 1 machines, and level 3 machines have a 25% success rate compared to level 1 machines. Indirect hacks suffer an additional -15% success rate per security level.|Detection rate: The base chance of being traced is 20 or 25% on a level 1 machine, 50% on a level 2 machine, and 60, 70, or 80% on a level 3 machine.|Trace rate: Once detected at a machine, the trace rate is increased at a higher rate on higher rating machines.|Higher armor value: The exact value varies per machine type, but higher security level machines always have more armor than lower security level machines.[[/List]]
Security level frequency scales based on depth. At lower depths, the vast majority of machines are security level 1. By -1, nearly every machine is security level 3.
[[Heading:2]]Hacking Success[[/Heading]]
There are several major components of hacking success rates. The formula is [[GameText]](base success rate) + ([[Offensive Hackware] bonus) - (Cogmind's [[Corruption]] % / 3) + (Operator hack bonus) + ([[Spoiler]]Botnet hack bonus[[/Spoiler]])[[/GameText]].
[[Heading:3]]Operator bonus[[/Heading]]
Each allied Operators within 20 tiles provides a bonus to hacking success rate. The bonus varies depending on the total number of Operators. There is a +10% bonus to hacks for the first Operator, +5% for the second, +2% for the third, and +1% for all others.
[[Spoiler]][[Heading:3]]Trojan(Botnet)[[/Heading]]
Installing Botnet trojans on other Terminals within the same map provides a hacking bonus. There is a +6% bonus to hacks for the first botnet installed, +3% for the second, and +1% for all others. Note that a botnet will not affect hacking success chance on the terminal it is installed on.[[/Spoiler]]
[[Heading:3]]Base Hacking Success Rate Examples[[/Heading]]
Example hacking success calculations. All final values are truncated.
[[Table]]
Level 1 direct|Level 1 indirect|Level 2 direct|Level 2 indirect|Level 3 direct|Level 3 indirect||
80%|80% - (15% * 1)|80% / 2|(80% / 2) - (15% * 2)|(80% / 4)|(80% / 4) - (15% * 3)||
80%|65%|40%|10%|20%|-25%
[[/Table]]
[[Heading:2]]Unauthorized Hacks[[/Heading]]
There are certain unauthorized spoiler hacks can also be used on different machine types. These are a class of hacks known either as [[Spoiler]]Trojans or Force hacks[[/Spoiler]]. The names and effects of these hacks can be discovered from a variety of [[Derelict]] sources.
[[Spoiler]][[Heading:3]]Trojans[[/Heading]]
Generally, Trojan hacks have a permanent or long term duration effect. Trojans can only be applied once per machine. Other than that limitation, they are not dramatically different from most other hacks on machines.
[[Heading:3]]Force Hacks[[/Heading]]
Force hacks are much more dramatic in terms of effects compared to other hacks. They can only be used once on a machine, and if successful, they will immediately lock the machine and summon an [[Investigation Squad]] to the area. Most Force hacks have an additional [[Alert]] penalty that is unique per hack that can be found on the Alert page.[[/Spoiler]]

Other.Name: Intercept Squad
Other.Content:
[[Image]]Intercept Squad.png|2 Trackers and 2 Combat Programmers from Intercept squads chasing Cogmind[[/Image]]Intercept squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are dispatched when Cogmind gets detected and recognized in a few specific scenarios. They consist of one or more [[Tracker|Trackers]] that each summon an additional [[Combat Programmer]] upon visual contact with Cogmind. Intercept squads are dispatched depending on the number of tiles moved on a map. Once Cogmind takes enough moves, a squad will always be dispatched. They squads can be Enumerated at [[Terminal|Terminals]], although due to their high speed, this is relatively useless.
An alert will indicate whenever an an Intercept squad is dispatched. Additionally, the log will display a message like [[GameText]]ALERT: Reliable intel has pinpointed LRC-V3, intercept squad en route.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]How to get Intercepts[[/Heading]]
Intercept squads can start being sent after Cogmind if any of the following 3 scenarios occurs:
[[List]]Cogmind uses the Data Conduit in [[Data Miner (Location)]]|[[Redacted]]Cogmind gets scanned by the lasers in [[Lab]][[/Redacted]]|[[Redacted]]Cogmind gets scanned by a [[Researcher]] in [[Section 7]][[/Redacted]][[/List]]

[[Heading]]Frequency and number[[/Heading]]
Intercept squads can have a variable number of bots. Initially when entering a floor, they consist of 1-2 Trackers that summon Combat Programmers. Each further intercept has a chance of increasing the number of Trackers initially dispatched. For example, the third dispatch on a floor can have up to 4 Trackers dispatched at once, which will further summon up to 4 Combat Programmers.
Intercept squads will appear after a certain number of moves after entering the floor or after the previous dispatch. There are three possible move counts that can be chosen from, and the first two spawns are much more likely than the third one. Either the squad will spawn after n (depth-dependent) tiles moved 2 times n moves, or 2.5 times n moves. The following table shows the number of moves required for each spawn:
[[Table]]
Depths|Tiles for first spawn|Tiles for second spawn|Tiles for third spawn||
-6|500|1000|1250||
-4 and -5|400|800|1000||
-1 through -3|300|600|750
[[/Table]]
After an intercept is dispatched, the move counter is reset. There is no maximum number of intercepts dispatched per floor.

[[Heading]]Where Intercepts Appear[[/Heading]]
Intercepts appear in the majority of 0b10 controlled maps that also have [[Extermination Squad|Exterminations]]. Here is a comprehensive list of maps:
[[List]][[Factory]]|[[Hub_04(d)]]|[[Armory]]|[[Research]]|[[Quarantine]] Note: Intercepts even spawn when two Cryocooling Ducts have bee destroyed|[[Testing]]|[[Redacted]]Section 7[[/Redacted]]|[[Protoforge]]|[[Access]][[/List]]

Other.Name: Investigation Squad
Other.Content:
[[Image]]Investigation Squad.png|Two Grunts investigating a locked out Terminal[[/Image]]
Investigation squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are dispatched when a hostile presence is suspected in an area. They are very similar to [[Reinforcement Squad|Reinforcements]], but are triggered in slightly different scenarios, and do not stick around permanently. Investigation squads typically consist of a few [[Grunt|Grunts]] or [[Hunter|Hunters]]. Grunts are more common than Hunters in squads. They roam around the area that they were summoned to for 300-400 turns, then exit the map. Investigation squads can be both Enumerated and Recalled at [[Terminal|Terminals]].
An alert will indicate whenever an Investigation squad is dispatched. Additionally, the log will display a message like [[GameText]]ALERT: Suspicious activity at Terminal F014. Dispatching Investigation squad[[/GameText]]. Depending on the method triggering the Investigation, a different reason may be given in the alert.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]WAR.Sys Records|Investigation Squad[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]How to get Investigations[[/Heading]]
[[List]]Being detected using an [[Active Sensor Suite]]|Being traced at any [[Interactive Machine]], including [[Spoiler]]Force()[[/Spoiler]] hacks|Triggering an [[Alarm Trap]][[/List]]

[[Heading]]Investigation Contents[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Depth|Grunt Squad|Hunter Squad||
-10|1-2 [[G-34 Mercenary]]|N/A||
-9|1-3 G-34 Mercenary|N/A||
-8|2-3 [[G-47 Trooper]]|1 [[H-55 Commando]]||
-7|2-3 G-47 Trooper|1-2 H-55 Commando||
-6|3 [[G-50 Soldier]]|1-2 [[H-66 Slayer]]||
-5|3-4 G-50 Soldier|2 H-66 Slayer||
-4|3-4 [[G-67 Veteran]]|2 [[H-77 Assassin]]||
-3|4 G-67 Veteran|2 H-77 Assassin||
-2|4-5 [[G-73 Enforcer]]|2-3 [[H-88 Terminator]]||
-1|5 G-73 Enforcer|2-3 H-88 Terminator
[[/Table]]
[[Spoiler]][[Heading]][[Data Miner]] redirection[[/Heading]]
The Data Miner can redirect Investigations if his help is obtained by visiting his [[Data Miner (Location)|hideout]]. If redirected, Investigations will roam around a random area of the map rather than head to the location they were summoned to. The Data Miner has a 50% chance to direct each Investigation about 15 turns after one is dispatched. If a redirect happens, the alert [[GameText]]Higher priority target acquired, redirecting investigation.[[/GameText]] will be displayed.[[/Spoiler]]

Other.Name: Locations
Other.Content:
Locations in Cogmind are unique styles of maps to visit. The main floors (Scrapyard, Materials, Factory, Research, and Access) are always located on the same depths every run. These main floors often can be visited in multiple depths. Branches, on the other hand, are typically found on only a single depth per-run and are often mutually exclusive with other branches. For example, Mines can always be found on -9, but Storage may also appear on -9, forcing a decision about which branch to take, or whether to take one at all.
The majority of maps are randomly generated, meaning no two runs or two depths will have the exact same layout. However, the overall structure of each location type is very similar. Some maps tend to be more open with large rooms and wide corridors, while others are more maze-like with tiny rooms and many small corridors leading into dead-ends. A few branches are partially or entirely static in layout and tend to be much more predictable in contents than main floors.
Branches do not progress upward toward the exit and can often be harder than the main floors. However, branches can offer unique challenges and have similarly unique rewards that can dramatically change a run. This could be powerful unique items, special events, gameplay-altering alignment, or rare permanent buffs.
The following is a list of all locations in Cogmind:
[[AllLocations]]

Other.Name: Maximum Security
Other.Content:
[[Image]]Maximum Security Assaults.png|A wave of Assaults and Sentries dispatched during Maximum Security[[/Image]]
Maximum Security is a special [[0b10]] response to a few specific threats that results in immediate shutdown of machines and increasingly large waves of [[Assault Squad|Assaults]] dispatched to Cogmind's position. Unlike the similar-behaving [[High Security]], Maximum Security is unrelated to [[Alert]] mechanics. Maximum Security can be triggered on most main and branch 0b10-controlled floors, excluding [[Command]], [[DSF|DSFs]], and [[Garrison|Garrisons]]. It can be triggered only by the following scenarios:
[[List]]
Cogmind has taken [[FarCom]] and enters [[Quarantine]] or [[Testing]]|
The [[Sigix Containment Pod]] is inserted into the [[Sigix Exoskeleton]] (instant)|
Cogmind attaches the [[Sigix Exoskeleton]] and is spotted by an 0b10 combat bot|
All the [[Garrison Access|Garrisons]] in [[Access]] have either been shut down or destroyed
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Timeline of Events[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
0: Log message [[GameText]]ALERT: [reason for Max Security]. Maximum security lockdown in progress.[[/GameText]]|
1: Machines shut down, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Machine network offline[[/GameText]]|
2: Log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Performing unscheduled system reset.[[/GameText]]|
3: 4 [[Sentry|Sentries]] dispatched at each 0b10-controlled exit and Garrison, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Lockdown in effect, collecting threat data.[[/GameText]]|
5/100: First assault wave dispatched, 6 assaults dispatched from nearby 0b10-controlled exits and [[Garrison Access|Garrisons]]. The first wave will be dispatched after 100 turns for FarCom-triggered Maximum Security and 5 turns for other reasons.|
105/200: Second wave, 6 assaults dispatched|
255/350: Third wave, 8 assaults dispatched including heavy assaults with stronger bots|455/550: Fourth wave, 10 assaults dispatched including heavy assaults|
705/800: Fifth wave, 12 assaults dispatched including heavy assaults|
Etc. - Delay between assaults continues to increase by 50 and number of assaults per wave continues to increase by 2
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Exiting Maximum Security[[/Heading]]
The only 2 ways to exit Maximum Security are to trigger [[Sterilization]] after killing enough combat hostiles or to exit the map. Otherwise, an infinite number of Assaults will continue to be dispatched.

Other.Name: Mechanics Achievements
Other.Content:
Mechanics [[Achievements]] are earned by interacting with and/or using many of the mechanics of the game. They are largely used as a way to teach players about some of said mechanics. Most of them will be simply eventually be obtained by players as they make mistakes and/or learn new mechanics. 15 of the 72 Mechanics Achievements have hidden descriptions that are only revealed after completing them. The borders of Mechanics Achievement indicate their difficulty compared to other achievements of the same sub-type, with more "intense" borders meaning higher difficulty.

[[Comment]]This warning is supposed to be there for all articles about achievement types, including those that do not have any Redacted-level spoilers.[[/Comment]]
(The visibility for the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements is set to at least "Spoilers", and may be set to "Redacted" for achievements where that would be relevant. Remember to change your spoilers settings to "None" if you do not wish to see the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements you have not yet obtained!)

[[Comment]]I don't know how to best categorize "Various"-type achievements.
They're still somewhat grouped, like "Part-time Excavator" and "Unlikely Earthworm", but making a heading for just two achievements seems like a bit much.
I also don't want to just bundle all "Various" achievements together, because that would disrupt the achievement order given by the game when using the "grouped" sorting option.
[[/Comment]]

[[Heading]]Various[[/Heading]]
[[List]]Close Call: [[Spoiler]]Evolve after being reduced to less than 10% of core integrity.[[/Spoiler]]
|Universal Adapter: [[Spoiler]]Use every form of propulsion across an entire run.[[/Spoiler]]
|Hehehe: Reprogram a [[Traps|trap]] using a [[Datajack]].
Strategy: Find some hostile Traps, attach a melee Datajack, and attempt to move into one of the Traps with the Datajack active. This won't actually cause you to move onto them, and will instead attempt to hack the Trap. On a successful attempt, the Trap will either be disarmed or reprogrammed. Only the latter will trigger the Achievement.
|Wheee!: Manually trigger a [[Chute Trap]].
Strategy: Find some Chute Traps in [[Factory]] either through luck or by using the [[GameText]]find_chute[[/GameText]] [[Datajacks|Datajack]] hack on a [[K-01 Serf]]. Note that the Achievement requires [[I]]manually[[/I]] triggering the Chute Trap, which means pressing '>' while on top of a known Chute Trap (or left-click on self) to force it to trigger. Triggering a Chute Trap by moving into a known one is not enough. If possible, reprogram the Traps using a melee Datajack or a nearby Terminal. When using [[Treads]] or while overweight, the Chute Traps will need to have been reprogrammed, as it is otherwise impossible to move onto them without triggering them.
|It Was An Accident, I Swear: [[Spoiler]]Destroy 10 machines in a single turn.[[/Spoiler]]
Strategy: [[Spoiler]]Find a large array of explosive machines, most likely in [[Factory]], and destroy one of them through either destabilization or a powerful cannon to start a chain reaction. A melee weapon also works, but at the cost of taking damage. Alternatively, this Achievement can also be unlocked by accident.[[/Spoiler]]
|Part-time Excavator: Use a melee weapon to dig through 10 walls or earth.
|Unlikely Earthworm: [[Spoiler]]Get crushed by a [[Cave-ins|cave-in]].[[/Spoiler]]
|Hey, That's Mine!: Attack 5 [[Recycler|Recyclers]] attempting to collect parts.
|Loot Pinata: Destroy a [[Hauler]].
|Treasure Hunter: Destroy 20 [[Hauler|Haulers]].
|Use The Force: [[Spoiler]]Collect 100 [[Matter|matter]] via [[Tractor Beams|Tractor Beam]].[[/Spoiler]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Attaching parts[[/Heading]]

[[List]]
Risk Taker: Attach an unidentified prototype.
|Ooh, Shiny!: [[Spoiler]]Attach 20 unidentified prototypes.[[/Spoiler]]
|Alien Tech: [[Spoiler]]Attach or use an [[Alien Artifacts|alien artifact]].[[/Spoiler]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Corruption[[/Heading]]

[[List]]
System Compromised: Reach 10% system [[Corruption|corruption]].
|Z1$+NX3F=JRE3_ZNQR: [[Spoiler]]Reach 50% system [[Corruption|corruption]].[[/Spoiler]]
|Maybe Next Time I'll Detach My [[Launchers|Launcher]]: [[Spoiler]]Misfire an explosive launcher.[[/Spoiler]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Various 2[[/Heading]]

[[List]]
Backstab: [[Spoiler]]Murder a friendly NPC.[[/Spoiler]]
|Short-term Sacrifices: Escape a [[Stasis Trap]] with help from an explosion.
Strategy: Find and trigger a Stasis Trap, preferably while using non-[[Treads|threaded]] propulsion, then blow up the Trap with a [[Launchers|Launcher]] or nearby explosive machine. Note that the Achievement will only be unlocked if the Trap itself is destroyed; If the stasis field gets depleted by the explosion first, the Trap will disappear, preventing it from being destroyed by the explosion. This Achievement is there to teach players that destroying a Stasis Trap causes the stasis field to disappear. Getting rid of a stasis field this way is rarely a good idea, but in some situations, taking a bit of damage to avoid getting spotted by powerful hostiles may be run-saving. 
|Just Shoot The [[Terminal]]: [[Spoiler]]Open a locked door by destroying its Terminal with an electromagnetic weapon.[[/Spoiler]]
|Release The Drones!: Have 6 drones at once.
|Subspace Traveler: Find a way to teleport.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Fighting[[/Heading]]

[[List]]Storm Trooper: Miss 5 shots in a row.
Strategy: You'll earn it eventually, probably more times than you would like. 
|Crack Shot: Hit 10 shots in a row.
|Please Form A Line: Hit 2 robots with a single projectile.
Strategy: Requires a weapon with penetrative capabilities, such as a [[Gauss Rifle]]. It is easiest to earn this Achievement by shooting robots in a small corridor, where robots would be naturally aligned.
|Quick And Dirty: Destroy 5 hostiles via explosions in a single turn.
Strategy: Use [[Launchers]] or nearby explosive machines. Especially easy against [[Assembled]] or [[Swarmer|Swarmers]], as they are both weak to explosions and easy to find in groups.
|Power Corrupts: Terminally [[Corruption|corrupt]] a robot.
|It's Just You: Cause a robot to [[Meltdown|meltdown]].
|Fist Fight: Destroy a hostile by ramming.
|Overkill: Fire 10 [[Overload#weapons|overloaded shots]].
|Batter Up: Knock a hostile robot into an explosive machine via melee impact damage.
|Watch This!: Sneak attack a [[Watcher]] and destroy it in one hit.
|Deadly Force: Melee attack a hostile using 4 [[Momentum|momentum]].
Strategy: The only way to attain 4 momentum is with the help of a [[Reaction Control Systems|Reaction Control System]], which does not work if overweight. Move three times in the same direction (to attain the base maximum of 3 momentum) while you have a Reaction Control System (+1 momentum), then attack a hostile robot. [[Comment]]Maybe there should be an explanation here for why momentum is useful for melee attacks?[[/Comment]]
|Ambidextrous: Destroy 2 hostiles with one melee volley.
|Oops: [[Spoiler]]Attempt to fire a [[Matter|matter]]-consuming volley without enough matter.[[/Spoiler]]
|No Explosion For You: Shoot down a [[Launchers|launcher]] projectile with a [[Point Defense Systems|defensive utility]].
|Oh No You Don't!: Destroy a [[E-15 Imp|Saboteur]] before it succeeds.
|Ride The Lightning: Use a [[Fabricator]] to destroy an enemy.
Strategy: [[Spoiler]]While hostiles are approaching or are already close to a Fabricator, use Force(Overload) on said Fabricator. Consider moving away to avoid becoming one of the Fabricator's targets.[[/Spoiler]]
|Let's See Who's Tougher: [[Spoiler]]Fire a [[Launchers|launcher]] at an enemy at point blank range.[[/Spoiler]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Stealth[[/Heading]]

[[List]]
Uninvited Guest: Be spotted by an [[Operator]] that then summons [[Reinforcement Squad|reinforcements]] from its [[Terminal]].
|One Hack Too Far: Trigger an [[Investigation Squad|investigation]] by being traced to a [[Terminal]].
|Troublemaker: Cause a robot to call for [[Garrison Squad|help or reinforcements]] from a nearby [[Garrison|Garrison Access]].
|Party Time: [[Spoiler]]Cause 3 active [[Investigation Squad|investigation squads]] at once.[[/Spoiler]]
|Significant Disruption: Raise [[Alert|alert]] high enough to trigger an [[Assault Squad|assault dispatch]].
|Slippery One: [[Spoiler]]Go from being tracked by 10 hostiles to having no pursuers without destroying any of them.[[/Spoiler]]
|Hunted: Simultaneously tracked by 20 hostiles.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Hacking[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
My Command Is Your Wish: Build an ally via [[Fabricator]].
|Just What I Needed: Build a part via [[Fabricator]].
|Part-time Mechanic: Repair a part via [[Repair Station]].
|Safety First: Identify a prototype via [[Scanalyzer]].
|Dynamic Key: Use an [[Operator]] [[Data Core]] before it expires.
|Novice Programmer: Hack 10 machines.
|Librarian: Hack 10 different [[Terminal]] records.
|Armchair Analyst: Download 3 robot analyses from [[Terminal|Terminals]].
|Everything Is Under Control: Lower alert using a [[Terminal]]'s Purge Threat hack.
|GoHome(): Use a [[Terminal]] to recall an active squad.
|Shopping List: Hack [[Hauler]] Manifests at a [[Terminal]].
|Brute Force: Use a Force() hack.
|True Hacker: Install a Trojan().
|Quantum Hacking: Set up a three-[[Terminal]] botnet.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Bothacking[[/Heading]]

[[List]]
A New Friend: Rewire a robot.
|Factory Defaults: Reset a hostile robot using the reboot_system hack.
|Error 47: Cause a hostile robot's power to go critical with an overload_power or amplify_resonance hack.
|Assimilation Complete: Assimilate a hostile robot using the format_system hack.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Infowar[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
No Signal: Block an [[Alarm Trap]] transmission.
|Total Silence: Jam 10 [[Distress Signals|distress signals]] or other communications.
|I Spy: Use an [[Imp. Sensor Array]] (or better) with [[Imp. Signal Interpreter]] (or better).
|Omniscient Cartographer: Use an [[Imp. Terrain Scanner]] (or better) with [[Imp. Terrain Scan Processor]] (or better).
|Knowing Is Half The Battle: Enter 10 identified exits.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Various 3[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Can't Catch Me: Reach a speed of FASTx3, or 4 spaces per turn.
|Cya!: Fly over a row of 3 robots.
|The More The Merrier: Have 5 allies.
[[/List]]

Other.Name: Non-empty Pages
Other.Content: [[NonEmptyPages]]

Other.Name: Overload
Other.Content:
Overloading is a [[Game Mechanics|Game Mechanic]] available on [[Overloadable Parts]], primarily cooled (Cld.) parts, that allows for a temporary increase in effectiveness with additional heat costs and potential downsides based on the stability of the part. It is possible to perform for Power, Propulsion, and Weapon type items.

[[Heading]][[Overloadable Power|Power]][[/Heading]]
Some power parts (e.g. [[Cld. Ion Engine]]) support overloading. Overloading power causes the following changes:
[[List]]Doubled energy generation|Doubled heat generation|Chance to shut down for ~5-10 turns and be damaged ~30-40% of the maximum integrity, based on the Stability % stat[[/List]]

[[Heading]][[Overloadable Propulsion|Propulsion]][[/Heading]]
Some propulsion types (mainly [[Flight Units]] and [[Hover Units]]), e.g. [[Cld. VTOL Module]], support overloading. Overloading propulsion causes the following changes:
[[List]]Doubled energy cost|Tripled heat generation|50% additional support|Speed is calculated as if there are twice the number of active Flight/Hover units (e.g. an overloaded Cld. VTOL Module will gain an additional -3 speed modifier)|Overload propulsion has a chance to suffer 1 point of damage each move that the part is active or each melee attack, based on the Burnout % stat[[/List]]
One special case, the [[Potential Leg]], does not have any of the above effects except for the burnout damage. Overloaded Potential Legs instead have their base speed halved.

[[Heading]][[Overloadable Weapons|Weapons]][[/Heading]]
Some energy weapons (e.g. [[Cld. Pulse Rifle]]) support overloading. Overloading weapons causes the following changes:
[[List]]Double damage|Doubled energy cost|Tripled heat generation|Additional level of heat transfer (e.g. Medium (+37) is turned into High (+50)|Chance of negative effect based on Shot Stability %.[[/List]]
If an overload side effect occurs, one of the following effects will occur:
[[List]]Energy Bleed (~40% chance): Cogmind loses anywhere from 10-50% of total energy capacity|Heat Surge (~40% chance): Cogmind gains between 100 and 200 heat|Short Circuit (~20% chance): A random part breaks[[/List]]

Other.Name: Partial Spot
Other.Content: Partial spotting is when you move through a (hostile) bots field of vision while its not its turn. The bot will investigate where it saw you, look a few tiles further then head back to whatever it was doing.

Other.Name: Patrol Squad
Other.Content:
[[Image]]Patrol Squad.png|A patrol squad of Swarmers[[/Image]]
Patrol squads are typically [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that patrol between points on the majority of 0b10-controlled maps, as well as [[Caves]]. They can be composed of a variety of bot types, all with slightly different patrolling behavior. Most patrol squads appear at the start of the map and will not appear over time, with the exception of [[Search Patrol|Search Patrols]]. Their presence is generally unrelated to [[Alert]]. Patrols can be Enumerated at [[Terminal|Terminals]]. Their frequency varies based on the type of map, but generally they are more common the higher up in the complex Cogmind goes.

[[Heading]]Patrol Contents[[/Heading]]
The following are the possible contents of patrol squads. At -9 and above, a [[C-30 ARC]] can also make up a single patrol squad. If it encounters a hostile, it will open up to reveal the contents of any other random patrol squad composition listed below:
[[Table]]
Depth|[[Grunt]]|[[Hunter]]|[[Programmer]]|[[Swarmer]]||
-10|1 [[G-47 Trooper]] squad leader and 1 [[G-34 Mercenary]]|N/A|N/A|3 [[S-10 Pest]]||
-9|1 [[B-36 Bruiser]], [[L-31 Rogue]], or G-47 Trooper squad leader and 1-2 G-34 Mercenary|N/A|N/A|3-4 S-10 Pest||
-8|1 B-36 Bruiser, L-31 Rogue, or [[G-50 Soldier]] and 2 G-47 Trooper|1 [[H-55 Commando]]|N/A|3-4 S-10 Pest||
-7|1 [[B-48 Gladiator]], [[L-41 Fighter]], or G-50 Soldier squad leader and 2-3 G-47 Trooper|1 H-55 Commando|1 [[P-60 Hacker]]|3-4 [[S-27 Virus]]||
-6|1 B-48 Gladiator, L-41 Fighter, or [[G-67 Veteran]] squad leader and 2-3 G-50 Soldier|1-2 [[H-66 Slayer]]|1 P-60 Hacker|3-4 S-27 Virus||
-5|1 [[B-60 Warrior]], L-41 Fighter, or G-67 Veteran squad leader and 2-4 G-50 Soldier|1-2 H-66 Slayer|1-2 [[P-70 Sage]]|4-5 S-27 Virus||
-4|1 B-60 Warrior, [[L-61 Swordsman]], or [[G-73 Enforcer]] squad leader and 2-3 G-67 Veteran|2 [[H-77 Assassin]]|1-2 P-70 Sage|4-5 S-27 Virus||
-3|1 [[B-74 Champion]], L-61 Swordsman, or G-73 Enforcer squad leader and 3 G-67 Veteran|2 H-77 Assassin|1-2 [[P-80 Master]]|3-5 [[S-43 Plague]]||
-2|1 B-74 Champion, L-61 Swordsman, or G-73 Enforcer squad leader and 3 G-73 Enforcer|2 [[H-88 Terminator]]|1-2 P-80 Master|4-5 S-43 Plague||
-1|1 B-74 Champion, L-61 Swordsman, or G-73 Enforcer squad leader and 3-4 G-73 Enforcer|2 H-88 Terminator|1-2 P-80 Master|4-6 S-43 Plague
[[/Table]]
[[Heading:2]][[Armory]] Patrol Contents[[/Heading]]
[[Spoiler]]Armory has additional patrol types that can appear:
[[/Spoiler]]
[[Table]]
Depth|Demolisher Squad|Duelist Squad|Specialist Squad||
-4|1 [[D-63 Destroyer]] squad leader and 2 G-67 Veteran|3 L-61 Swordsman and 1 [[I-47 Archangel]]|2 [[X-72 Disruptor]], [[X-77 Beamer]], or [[X-82 Rainmaker]] and one [[E-15 Imp]]||
-3|1 D-63 Destroyer squad leader and 2 G-67 Veteran|3 L-61 Swordsman and 1 I-47 Archangel|2 X-77 Beamer, X-82 Rainmaker, [[X-87 Electro]], and one E-15 Imp
[[/Table]]
[[Redacted]]
[[Heading:2]][[Protoforge]] Patrol Contents[[/Heading]]
Protoforge has additional patrol types that can appear:
[[List]]4 [[Decapitator]]|
4-5 [[Hotshot]]|
4 [[Immortal]][[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]Advanced Fortification Protocols[[/Heading]]
When [[Superfortress]] is destroyed or the [[UFD]] assault is started against Protoforge, subsequent maps will have more patrols (50%) and stronger patrol makeups. The following new patrols are possible:
[[List]]4-6 [[C-57 Dissector]]|
1-2 [[D-83 Annihilator]]|
2 [[Executioner]]|
2 [[Striker]]|
4-5 X-87 Electro[[/List]]
[[/Redacted]]

[[Heading]]Patrol behavior[[/Heading]]
There are essentially 2 types of patrol behaviors. ARC and Hunter squads are fast patrollers, which navigate between their patrol points at max or near max speed. They quickly move in and out of areas so they can be hard to avoid if in the way, but are easier to navigate around without waiting long periods of time. Grunts, Programmers, and Swarmer squads all patrol much slower. They meander along the way and spend far more turns resting than moving forward along their route. It is easier to run away form these types of patrols if you know they are coming, but they can clog rooms or hallways for long periods of time.

[[Heading]]Frequency[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Map|Number of patrols||
-10 [[Materials]]|3||
-9 Materials|5||
-8 Materials|5||
-7 [[Factory]]|8||
-6 Factory|10||
-5 Factory|12||
-4 Factory|14||
-3 [[Research]]|14||
-2 Research|16||
-1 [[Access]]|20||
[[Storage]]|2||
[[Extension]]|2||
[[Hub_04(d)]]|2||
[[Armory]]|10-18||
[[Testing]]|2||
[[Quarantine]]|2||
[[Section 7]]|5||
[[Protoforge]]|10||
[[Command]]|12
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Special patrol-summoning events[[/Heading]]
There are a few special events that can trigger patrol dispatches when already on a level.
[[Heading:2]][[Search Patrol|Search Patrols]][[/Heading]]
Search Patrols are a special type of patrol that is related to Alert. These squads can be dispatched if Cogmind generates a lot of non-combat Alert. They consist of a single [[C-30 ARC]] that roam across the entire map instead of just between two points like most patrols.
[[Spoiler]][[Heading:2]][[Lightning]] squads[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Lightning Squad.png|A Lightning squad patrolling Quarantine[[/Image]]
Lightning squads consist of 3 Lightnings and an [[I-47 Archangel]]. They can be summoned in one of two ways:
[[List]]Destroying a Hub machine in [[Hub_04(d)]]: 3 Lightning patrols will be dispatched to the map out of exits and Garrisons. They will roam in the general area of each remaining Hub.|Opening the [[Sigix Containment Pod]] chamber: A single Lighting patrol will be dispatched to the map if Cogmind breaches the Sigix chamber. It will patrol around the location of the Sigix room.[[/List]][[/Spoiler]]

Other.Name: Perfect Tracking
Other.Content: Bots with perfect tracking will know where [[Cogmind]] is at all times. Most bots with this will lose it upon sighting Cogmind.

Other.Name: Progress Achievements
Other.Content:
Progress [[Achievements]] are earned by accomplishing actions that demonstrate the player's progress and experience with the game. Most of them will simply eventually be obtained by players as they explore the game world and get better at surviving and exploring it. 2 of the 33 Progress Achievements have hidden descriptions that are only revealed after completing them. The borders of Progress Achievement indicate their difficulty compared to other achievements of the same sub-type, with more "intense" borders meaning higher difficulty.

[[Comment]]This warning is supposed to be there for all articles about achievement types[[/Comment]]
(The visibility for the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements is set to at least "Spoilers", and may be set to "Redacted" for achievements where that would be relevant. Remember to change your spoilers settings to "None" if you do not wish to see the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements you have not yet obtained!)

[[Heading]]Uncategorized[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
First Step to Greatness: [[Spoiler]]Get terminated.[[/Spoiler]]
Strategy : [[Spoiler]]You'll likely get this one eventually.[[/Spoiler]]
|Back For More: Complete 50 runs.
Strategy : You'll get this one eventually. The relevant scoresheet statistic is "Game No."
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Earning points[[/Heading]]
Earning points is done in a variety of ways, including :
[[List]]Ascending through each floor (500 points for every evolution threshold crossed)|
Visiting regions (200 per map entered)|
Destroying robots (5 points per robot destroyed)|
Destroying stuff in general (depends on the value of what was destroyed)|
Obtaining [[Prototype Part]] IDs (20 points per unique Prototype Part ID, including any that might have been forgotten due to reasons like component data loss)|
[[Spoiler]]Attaching alien technology (200 points per unique alien part attached)[[/Spoiler]]|
Bonus points, which are earned through a large variety of reasons, including some like meeting important characters, aligning with certain factions, and more. There is also one source of negative bonus points, "Friendly Fire", which is earned by damaging/destroying friendly robots and is dependent on the value of those robots.[[/List]]

The relevant scoresheet statistic is "TOTAL SCORE". These Achievements are awarded at the end of a run that meets their criteria.

[[List]]
5k Club: Earn 5,000 points.
|10k Club: Earn 10,000 points.
|20k Club: Earn 20,000 points.
|30k Club: Earn 30,000 points.
|40k Club: Earn 40,000 points.
|50k Club: Earn 50,000 points.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Lore collection progress[[/Heading]]
The lore collection contains all lore records, dialogues and their source, as well as all analyses and the general robot type they are about. All start out hidden, and are revealed in the collection when found within the game world.
[[List]]
Records - There are two types of lore records : [[0b10]] database records, which can be access on any 0b10 [[Terminal]] with proper database authorization, and all other lore records, which will only ever appear in one prefab, on one specific Terminal. There are also a few records that are not part of the lore collection, mostly non-unique records from [[Caves|Cave]] outposts that contain Terminals.|
Dialogues - The only dialogues that matter for the lore collection are textbox dialogues. Dialogue lines that only appear in the log and at the bottom of the screen with no textbox (like [[Operator|Operators]]' IFF handshake text) do not count towards the lore collection.|
Analyses - There are three types of analyses : "Common" for common 0b10 bots, "Derelict" for non-0b10 bots, and "Prototype" for prototype 0b10 bots. Mechanically speaking, there are many to obtain analyses, but the only way to get them in the lore collection is to hack them on Terminals.
[[/List]]
The lore collection orders its contents first by type, then by alphabetical order. However, when viewing the lore collection in-game, it is possible to export it as a txt, html or csv file. The resulting file orders its contents differently : Type first, then source (or robot type for analyses), then by alphabetical order. Except for csv files, this includes undiscovered records, making it possible to view how many records and dialogues remain to be found from certain sources. Note that if no records/dialogues have been found from one source, then the undiscovered records/dialogues from that source will not be included within the exported file.
The relevant scoresheet statistic is "Lore%".
[[List]]
This Is Interesting...: Reach 25% lore collection.
|I Think I Know What's Going On: Reach 50% lore collection.
|I Was Wrong!: Reach 75% lore collection.
|I Wish There Was More: Reach 100% lore collection.[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Gallery collection progress[[/Heading]]
The gallery collection contains all parts that have ASCII art. All parts start out as "Undiscovered Components", and each one is "discovered" and revealed upon either being attached to Cogmind or when using the [[GameText]]parse_system[[/GameText]] [[Datajacks|Datajack]] hack on any robot that currently has it attached. Inventory items are added to the collection upon being picked up. Gallery collection progress is based on how many parts have been discovered. Current gallery progress can be seen in the gallery collection.

While the majority of parts are fairly common and are relatively easy to just stumble upon or find on robots in multiple different areas, some parts are more difficult to find and add to the gallery collection :
[[List]]
A lot of parts can only be found in specific prefabs in specific [[Branch|branches]], sometimes in well-guarded, dangerous-to-access places.
|A bunch of parts can only be obtained from rare/unique robots, sometimes because the robots are carrying them in their inventory.
|Some parts can only be found on robots that will never drop them upon destruction, requiring the use of a [[GameText]]parse_system[[/GameText]] hack to add them to the gallery collection.
|Some parts cannot be found anywhere, requiring the player to instead obtain their schematic and fabricate them.
|Some parts cannot be found anywhere and have no schematics, requiring them to be created through other means.
[[/List]]

The relevant scoresheet statistic is "Gallery%".
 
[[List]]
Just Browsing: Reach 25% gallery collection.
|Tester: Reach 50% gallery collection.
|Collector: Reach 75% gallery collection.
|Curator: Reach 100% gallery collection.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Exploration[[/Heading]]

[[List]]
Made in Tau Ceti IV: Enter [[Factory]].
|Dangerous Findings: Enter [[Research]].
|Denied?: Enter [[Access]].
|\\IAMDERELICT: [[Spoiler]]Enter [[Recycling]] via [[Storage]].[[/Spoiler]]
|I'm Back, Baby!: Exit [[Caves|Proximity Caves]].
|Tourist: Visit 3 branch areas.
|Adventurer: Visit 2 special cave areas.
|Explorer: Visit 10 branch areas.
|Great Explorer: Visit 35 areas.[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Reaching a high peak rating[[/Heading]]
These Achievements require Cogmind to reach a high rating, which is mostly determined by the rating of currently attached parts. Current rating is visible when examining Cogmind. The relevant scoresheet statistic is "Peak Build Rating".

[[List]]
Serviceable Loadout: Reach a peak rating of 50.
|Respectable Loadout: Reach a peak rating of 100.
|Rockin' Loadout: Reach a peak rating of 150.
|Ultimate Loadout: Reach a peak rating of 200.[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Achievement collection progress[[/Heading]]

[[List]]
Achiever: Earn 25% of achievements.
Requires 64 Achievements.
|Overachiever: Earn 50% of achievements.
Requires 128 Achievements.
|Superachiever: Earn 75% of achievements.
Requires 192 Achievements.
|Perfect Achiever: Earn all other achievements.
Requires all other 255 Achievements.[[/List]]

Other.Name: Recycling Unit
Other.Content:
[[Image]]../game_sprites/Recycling.png|A Recycling Unit[[/Image]]
Recycling Units are [[0b10]]-controlled [[Interactive Machine|Machines]] that are primarily used by [[Recycler|Recyclers]] to recycle discarded parts into [[Matter]]. Parts are temporarily stored within the machine until full (10/15/20 total inventory depending on security level), then Recyclers process the parts one at a time to make room for new parts. Cogmind can also insert and recycle parts, then retrieve the Matter generated by hacking the machine.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Recycling Unit[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Destruction[[/Heading]]
WHen a Recycling Unit is destroyed, parts that were in the inventory may sometimes be ejected by the destroyed machine. Each machine tile destroyed has a chance of ejecting one of the parts in inventory at the time of destruction.

[[Heading]]Rigged Engines[[/Heading]]
If a Recycler inserts a rigged engine created by a [[PSU Rigger]] into a Recycling machine, the engine's explosion will immediately go off and blow up the machine.

[[Heading]]Armor Values[[/Heading]]
The armor of a Recycling Unit will indicate what security level it is:
[[Table]]
Security level|Armor||
1|22||
2|32||
3|35
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Hacks[[/Heading]]
[[Hacks]]Recycling[[/Hacks]]
[[Heading:2]]Additional Details/Usage Tips[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:3]]Retrieving Matter[[/Heading]]
Retrieving Matter from a Recycling Unit is a multi step process. First, parts must be inserted with [[GameText]]Recycle([Part Name])[[/GameText]]. Then, the [[GameText]]Recycling(Process)[[/GameText]] hack must be used to turn all parts in inventory into matter. Finally, the [[GameText]]Retrieve(Matter)[[/GameText]] hack must be used to obtain the recycled matter. All parts are processed at 50% efficiency such that 2 part integrity = 1 matter.
[[Spoiler]]
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Force(Fedlink)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This hack has no practical effect if Cogmind is not [[UFD]] aligned. See the UFD page for more details.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Force(Scraphulk)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This hack has no effect if Cogmind is not UFD aligned. See the UFD page for more details.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Force(Scrapoids)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This hack has no practical effect if Cogmind is not UFD aligned. See the UFD page for more details.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Force(Tunnel)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This hack is most valuable in early floors like [[Materials]]. It can reveal the locations of all 0b10 [[Branch]] maps which can be useful in planning a route through the game.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Trojan(Mask)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
Trojan(Mask) can be used in order to stockpile large numbers of parts on the ground. This is especially useful if planning a flight to grounded propulsion transition, as it is easy to bring parts back to this location and there is no risk of losing the parts due to Recyclers. [[GameText]]Trojan(Mask)[[/GameText]] can also be good if hunting [[Cargo Convoy|Cargo Convoys]] that are heading through the area to avoid the risk of Recyclers picking up the loot.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Trojan(Reject)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This hack has the effect of piling up a large number of parts in the area where the Recycler is located because parts that are ejected will not be re-inserted into the machine.[[/Spoiler]]

Other.Name: Reinforced Walls
Other.Content:
Many areas are sealed off by various types of Reinforced Walls. These walls all have much higher than typical armor values and resistances to most common damage types. The common theme between them all is that they do not have any Thermal resistance. As such, Cld. thermal [[Energy Cannons]] are the ideal way to cut through many of these barriers. Unlike basic walls, reinforced walls will not collapse due to penetrating weapons.
There are two primary types of reinforced walls. Though they have different names, they behave functionally similarly. Orange doors block the main access to the blocked off area. These doors have a higher than normal armor value, but they tend to be lower than reinforced barriers. Reinforced barriers typically surround the remainder of the area to prevent digging in from the back side. In most maps, these have two times the normal armor level of walls. For example, an average Storage wall has an armor value of 24, so the reinforced barriers have an armor value of 48 on this map.
