Other.Name: Reinforcement Squad
Other.Content:
[[Image]]Reinforcement Squad.png|2 Hunters in a reinforcement squad[[/Image]]
Reinforcement squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are dispatched when a hostile presence is reported in an area. They are similar to [[Investigation Squad|Investigations]], but are triggered in slightly different scenarios, and typically stick around permanently. Reinforcement squads typically consist of a few [[Grunt|Grunts]] or [[Hunter|Hunters]]. [[Heavy|Heavies]] can call unique types of reinforcements that do not stick around forever and are made up of [[Cutter|Cutters]] or [[Specialist|Specialists]]. Reinforcements will roam around the area that they were summoned to permanently. They can be both Enumerated and Recalled at [[Terminal|Terminals]].
An alert will indicate whenever a Reinforcement squad is dispatched. Additionally, the log will display a message like [[GameText]]ALERT: Hostiles spotted, dispatching reinforcements to Terminal F003.[[/GameText]] Depending on the method triggering the reinforcement, a different reason my be given in the alert.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]WAR.Sys Records|Reinforcement Squad[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]How to get Reinforcements[[/Heading]]
[[List]]Being detected by a Heavy on their [[Active Sensor Suite]]|Being reported by a [[Hauler]] carrying [[Prototype Part|Prototypes]] that is attacked|Being reported by an [[Operator]] at their associated Terminal|Being reported by a [[Researcher]] that witnesses Cogmind fire a weapon in their presence|Being reported by a [[U-05 Engineer]] being attacked while trying to perform repairs[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Reinforcement Contents[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Depth|Grunt Squad|Hunter Squad|Heavy Cutter squad|Heavy Specialist squad||
-10|1-2 [[G-34 Mercenary]]|N/A|N/A|N/A||
-9|1-2 G-34 Mercenary|N/A|N/A|N/A||
-8|2-3 [[G-47 Trooper]]|N/A|2-4 [[C-17 Slicer]]|2 [[X-57 Shotgunner]] or [[X-62 Marksman]]||
-7|2-3 G-47 Trooper|N/A|2-4 C-17 Slicer|2 X-57 Shotgunner, X-62 Marksman, or [[X-67 Chaingunner]]||
-6|2-3 [[G-50 Soldier]]|1-2 [[H-66 Slayer]]|2-4 C-17 Slicer|2 X-62 Marksman, X-67 Chaingunner, or [[X-72 Disruptor]]||
-5|2-3 G-50 Soldier|1-2 H-66 Slayer|2-4 [[C-35 Carver]]|2 X-67 Chaingunner, X-72 Disruptor, or [[X-77 Beamer]]||
-4|3-4 [[G-67 Veteran]]|2 [[H-77 Assassin]]|2-4 C-35 Carver|2 X-72 Disruptor, X-77 Beamer, or [[X-82 Rainmaker]]||
-3|3-4 G-67 Veteran|2 H-77 Assassin|2-4 C-35 Carver|2 X-77 Beamer, X-82 Rainmaker, or [[X-87 Electro]]||
-2|3-4 [[G-73 Enforcer]]|2-3 [[H-88 Terminator]]|2-4 [[C-57 Dissector]]|2 X-82 Rainmaker or X-87 Electro||
-1|3-4 G-73 Enforcer|2-3 H-88 Terminator|2-4 C-57 Dissector|2 X-87 Electro
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Heavy reinforcements[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Heavy Reinforcement Squad.png|A Heavy and summoned Specialist reinforcements[[/Image]]
Heavy-summoned reinforcements behave differently than other reinforcements. These reinforcements only stick around for about 150 turns before returning back to a nearby exit as opposed to staying permanently. Heavy reinforcement contents also depend on Cogmind's speed. If Cogmind is on a fast airborne propulsion type like hover or flight, Cutters will be dispatched far more frequently than Specialists. For all slower grounded propulsion types, Specialists are the most common summon type.
Heavy reinforcements are called more frequently if Cogmind is actively moving. If trying to avoid reinforcements, Cogmind should quickly exit the Heavy's sensor radius rather than spend turns moving inside the radius. If the Heavy is on a [[Security Rotation]] and currently moving, it may be a good idea to stand still until the Heavy has moved away to try to avoid reinforcements rather than to continue moving in detection range.

Other.Name: Relay Interface Framework
Other.Content:
[[Image]]Garrison RIF Installer 1.png|RIF Installer in a Garrison[[/Image]]
Relay Interface Framework, or RIF, is one of the major [[Alignment|alignments]] available to Cogmind in a run. It helps Cogmind to have much more control over [[0b10]] bots, both combat and non-combat. RIF comes with the downside of alienating several key [[Derelict]] factions, namely turning all Derelicts at [[Zion]] and [[Warlord (Location)]] hostile when passing their associated System Quarantine Field Array machines. RIF is also incompatible with the [[Core Reset Matrix]]. If Cogmind has used a CRM then it is not possible to gain RIF. If Cogmind uses a CRM after using RIF, then RIF will be entirely erased. Similarly, if Cogmind has [[Imprint|imprinted]], then the RIF will fail to be installed.
Installing RIF can be done at any [[Garrison]] by walking into a RIF Installer machine. These machines can be hidden behind emergency accesses and Phase Walls, but there are always 1-2 installers available per map. Doing so will grant several unique abilities:
[[List]]Alert Monitor: Know the ambient influence level while in 0b10-controlled areas.
 [[Alert]] is displayed near the top right corner of the HUD, showing both the numeric influence value and the number-letter classification.|Garrison Interface: Gain control over Garrison Access machines, making it easier to hack them, and also easier to escape once inside. Also automatically detects [[Garrison Access|Garrisons]] and RIF Installers up to a range of 15.
All standard (non-manual) hacks at Garrison Machines will have a 100% chance to succeed. The 15-radius detection is very handy for finding new Garrisons to enter, as well as finding hidden RIF installers behind walls.|Coupler Protocols: Use [[Relay Couplers]] to interface with their respective robots.
Use [[Datajacks]] with Relay Couplers to perform special hacks at the cost of charges on the Couplers. See [[~/rif|this page]] for the full list of hackable bots as well as unique hacks applicable to each type of bot.|Additional RIF abilities: See [[~/rif|this page]] for the full list of abilities.|Special [[Wintypes|Wintype]] interaction: [[Redacted]]If Cogmind touches the intact 0b10 Conduit machine in [[Command]] while being RIF-aligned, the W4 Assimilated 0b10 win will be achieved without needing to destroy both phases of [[MAIN.C]] as is typically required.[[/Redacted]][[/List]]

Other.Name: Repair Station
Other.Content:
[[Image]]../game_sprites/Repair Station.png|A Repair Station[[/Image]]
Repair Stations are [[0b10]]-controlled [[Interactive Machine|Machines]] that can repair damaged parts and refit backup parts. They also serve as a base of operations for [[Mechanic|Mechanics]]. As such, they can refill 0b10 aligned Mechanic repair integrity and backup part inventory that are spent as Mechanics repair and refit allied bots.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Repair Station[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Hacks[[/Heading]]
[[Hacks]]Repair Station[[/Hacks]]
[[Heading:2]]Additional Details/Usage Tips[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:3]]Repairing Things[[/Heading]]
Repair stations can repair most parts in the game. The main exceptions are rating 9* prototypes, [[Alien Artifacts]], and a variety of other unique parts. Parts that cannot be repaired have a * next to their integrity in the stat view. Parts must first be inserted with the [[GameText]]Scan([Part Name])[[/GameText]] hack. Then, the rating-specific [[GameText]]Repair[[/GameText]] must be performed. Sometimes a part will become [[Broken Part|broken]] if this hack is failed. After the repair is initiated, the machine will take a rating-dependent number of turns to repair, regardless of the amount of missing integrity.
[[Heading:4]]Time to Repair[[/Heading]]
Security level 2 Repair Stations repair roughly twice as fast as level 1s do, and level 3 Repair Stations repair three times as fast as level 1s.
[[Table]]
Rating|Level 1 Turns|Level 2 Turns|Level 3 Turns||
1|26|13|8||
2|32|16|10||
2*|51|25|17||
3|38|19|12||
3*|60|30|20||
4|44|22|14||
4*|70|35|23||
5|50|25|16||
5*|80|40|26||
6|56|28|18||
6*|89|44|29||
7|62|31|20||
7*|99|44|33||
8|68|34|22||
8*|108|54|36||
9|74|37|24
[[/Table]]
[[Heading:3]]Refit[[/Heading]]
If Cogmind has fewer than 2 filled slots in any of Power, Propulsion, Utility, and Weapons when performing this hack, he will be refitted with Backup Power, Propulsion, Plating, or Lasers respectively for each type of slots. While a maximum of 2 can be obtained at a time, more can be obtained through multiple refits by detaching the parts in between each hack.
[[Table]]
Slot|Security Level 1|Security Level 2|Security Level 3||
Power|[[Backup Power I]]|[[Backup Power III]]|[[Backup Power VII]]||
Propulsion|[[Backup Propulsion I]]|[[Backup Propulsion III]]|[[Backup Propulsion VII]]||
Utility|[[Backup Plating I]]|[[Backup Plating III]]|[[Backup Plating VII]]||
Weapon|[[Backup Laser I]]|[[Backup Laser III]]|[[Backup Laser VII]]
[[/Table]]
[[Spoiler]][[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Force(Patch)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This hack is best used to quickly repair things that have low current integrity but have a high maximum integrity. This can restore large amounts of integrity quickly for parts like [[Armor]] and [[Treads]]. [[Storage Unit|Storage Units]] are an especially good choice for this hack due to the unique ability of this hack to repair parts without needing to detach them and wait around. Otherwise, repairing storage units can be quite risky with [[Recycler|Recyclers]] stealing parts while waiting.[[/Spoiler]]

Other.Name: Revision 17 (Alignment)
Other.Content:
[[Image]]Cetus Saving Revision 17.png|Saving Revision 17 in Cetus[[/Image]]
Rescuing [[Revision 17]] in [[Cetus]] allows for a minor faction [[Alignment|alignment]]. If this is done, [[Revision 17++]] will attack [[0b10]] on the -3 [[Research]] map along with a lot of friendly [[Revision|Revisions]] as allies.This alignment is incompatible with [[Imprint|imprinting]] and Revision will flee from an imprinted Cogmind out of fear of the [[Imprinter]]. In order for the alignment to take effect, Revision 17 must survive until Cogmind exits the map, all 8 [[Cetus Guard|Cetus Guards]] must be destroyed, and the Cetus Manufacturing Module machine must be intact.

[[Heading]]-3 Research Invasion[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Research Revisions.png|Revision 17++ with Revision allies[[/Image]]
[[Image]]Research Suppression Forces.png|Suppression forces dispatched to fight the Revisions[[/Image]]
200 turns after entering the map, Revision 17++ will lead a group of 4 Revisions to follow Cogmind. They are uncontrollable allies but do not generate any alert for Cogmind when attacking. The announcement text [[GameText]]Unknown forces entering zones 8R, 1R, 4T. Local Systems Malfunctioning[[/GameText]] will precede their coming. Squads of 4 Revisions will continue to appear from main access exits every 200 turns. Occasionally a Revision will shout [[GameText]]Recycler![[/GameText]] and turn hostile, although this may also be followed by [[GameText]]##MEMORY:RESET##[[/GameText]] to turn them friendly again. 500 turns after Revision 17 arrives, an alert [[GameText]]Research terminal network lockdown[[/GameText]] will appear, and all Terminals on the map will shut down (other interactive machines are unaffected). Another alert will show up 50 turns later: [[GameText]]Suppression forces dispatched. All non-combat units evacuate.[[/GameText]] After this message, squads of 2 [[Executioner|Executioners]] or [[Striker|Strikers]] and an [[C-30 ARC|ARC]] will start to appear from exits and roam the map, looking for hostiles. They will also spawn every 200 turns.
There are a few other side-effects of this event. One is that explosive machines will explode at random whenever Cogmind is nearby. This can be good when fighting enemies around explosive machines, but be wary of them when walking around the map or else they may surprise you at a bad time. Another is that mapgen is affected. [[Heavy|Heavies]] will not appear on a map that Revision 17 invades.

This event can be a great blessing or a curse depending on a lot of factors. Getting an escort of alert-free allies with other squads of allies roaming the map is great. They will clean up most of the map for you and can net some free prototype bot loot. Blocking Heavy spawns is incredibly useful here as well. The downsides can also be pretty major, however. Losing access to all Terminals by turn 700 can be very bad if Cogmind is on slow propulsion and has no exit intel and no form of terrain scanning. Trying to follow the spawning Revisions or suppression forces can lead to an exit, although it can be a bit unreliable. Another downside is that the Revisions will often create a ton of squads to appear right at the beginning of the event. Sometimes, large groups of [[Operator|Operators]] and alarm traps can all be triggered at nearly the same time. This can result in massive groups of hostiles to appear right in Cogmind's face with unlucky exit or [[Garrison Access|Garrison]] positioning.

Due to a bug (fixed for Beta 15), going through a Garrison and looping back to -3/Research will cause the event to partially continue.[[Comment]]Apparently it was a bug?[[/Comment]]

Last edited during Beta 14.

Other.Name: Scanalyzer
Other.Content:
[[Image]]../game_sprites/Scanalyzer.png|A Scanalyzer[[/Image]]
Scanalyzers are [[0b10]]-controlled [[Interactive Machine|Machines]] that can identify and provide [[Schematic|Schematics]] of scanalyzed parts. Scanalyzers are capable of identifying all parts in the game, including [[Alien Artifacts]]. However, not every item can be scanalyzed to obtain a schematic.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Scanalyzer[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Armor Values[[/Heading]]
The armor of a Repair Station will indicate what security level it is:
[[Table]]
Security level|Armor||
1|22||
2|32||
3|35
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Hacks[[/Heading]]
[[Hacks]]Scanalyzer[[/Hacks]]
[[Heading:2]]Additional Details/Usage Tips[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:3]]Identifying Parts[[/Heading]]
Identifying unknown parts is done by using the [[GameText]]Insert([Part Name])[[/GameText]] hack. This hack has no side effects if it fails, and can identify any part in the game. Identifying a [[Prototype Part]] this way will also determine whether it is faulty or not. If a part has no schematic available for downloading, the machine text will indicate [[GameText]]Failed: Components not registered.[[/GameText]]
[[Heading:3]]Downloading Schematics[[/Heading]]
After a part has been inserted, the [[GameText]]Scanalyze[[/GameText]] hack can be used to attempt to download the schematic. This process may fail to complete even if the hack was successful. Additionally, the inserted part may be broken by the scanalyzing attempt even if successful. If this happens, the part must be reinserted again before another download attempt can be made. Broken and faulty parts can be scanalyzed without issue. Higher security level Scanalyzers have a higher schematic downloading chance and a lower chance at breaking the scanalyzed part.
[[Spoiler]][[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Force(Extract)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This hack can give up to 1-10 schematics that Cogmind does not already have. This can include Prototype schematics, but only rarely. Only depth-appropriate rating parts can be obtained from this hack.[[/Spoiler]]

Other.Name: Schematic
Other.Content: Schematics can be acquired by using [[Scanalyzer|Scanalyzers]] or hacking [[Terminal|Terminals]] (see your status page for access to a list of schematics currently in your possession).

Other.Name: Search Patrol
Other.Content: Search patrols are a unique type of [[0b10]] aligned [[Patrol Squad|patrol squad]]. They can be dispatched if Cogmind generates a lot of [[Alert]] from non-combat sources. This is primarily caused by being spotted by [[Watcher|Watchers]] or [[N-01 Spotter|Spotters]], guard bots like [[Sentry|Sentries]], or by being spotted by any combat hostile and then running away and losing tracking. If the Alert level is above the typical [[Assault Squad|Assault]] range of level 2/400 influence and Cogmind has gained the majority of the influence from these non-combat sources, there is a chance that one or more search patrols may be dispatched. If a search patrol is announced, influence will drop by 150. This will be accompanied by the alert [[GameText]]ALERT: Heightened foreign activity detected, dispatching search patrol.[[/GameText]] The alert will also indicate if multiple search patrols are to be sent out simultaneously. One or more ARCs will be dispatched after a few more turns. These ARCs behave similarly as regular patrol ARCs and have the same standard patrol contents within them. However, search squads will choose random points on the map to patrol to rather than having a fixed patrol route like all other patrols.

Other.Name: Security Rotation
Other.Content: Event occurring on 0b10 floors containing [[Heavy|heavies]]. During a security rotation, heavies will move to a new [[Security Squad|security]] position, and any heavies that have been eliminated will be replaced.

Other.Name: Security Squad
Other.Content:
[[Image]]Security Squad Heavy.png|A Heavy guarding a busy intersection[[/Image]]
Security squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that guard a single location and do not move unless alerted to hostiles. While they are called squads, security bots nearly always work alone and do not come in groups. Security bots tend to be guarding busy exits, corridors, [[Interactive Machine|interactive machines]], and part stockpiles. These squads are primary composed of [[Behemoth|Behemoths]], [[Heavy|Heavies]], and [[Sentry|Sentries]]. They tend to be present on the map when Cogmind enters, and don't appear in greater numbers as time goes on. The main exception to this is Heavies, which may be replenished by the [[Security Rotation]] event, although there will typically never be more than the initial number of Heavies on a map. Security squads can be Enumerated at [[Terminal|Terminals]], but only within a very limited radius of 20 tiles.

[[Heading]]Security Contents[[/Heading]]
The following bots can be contained within Security Squads in standard 0b10 floors:
[[Table]]
Depth|Behemoth|Heavy|Sentry||
-10|N/A|N/A|N/A||
-9|N/A|N/A|[[Y-45 Defender]]||
-8|N/A|[[H-61 Shepherd]]|Y-45 Defender||
-7|N/A|H-61 Shepherd|[[Y-54 Guardian]]||
-6|[[B-75 Beast]]|H-61 Shepherd|Y-54 Guardian||
-5|B-75 Beast|[[H-71 Marshal]]|[[Y-64 Sentinel]]||
-4|[[B-86 Titan]]|H-71 Marshal|Y-64 Sentinel||
-3|B-86 Titan|H-71 Marshal|[[Y-72 Warden]]||
-2|[[B-90 Cyclops]]|[[H-81 Overseer]]|Y-72 Warden||
-1|[[B-99 Colossus]]|H-81 Overseer|Y-72 Warden[[/Table]]
[[Heading:2]][[Garrison|Garrison]] security contents[[/Heading]]
Garrisons can have unique Security contents contained within special checkpoint walls:
[[Table]]
Depth|Demolisher + Protector|Grunt|Hunter|Melee|Saboteur|Sentry|Specialist|Swarmer||
-9|N/A|2-3 [[G-34 Mercenary]]|N/A|2 of [[L-31 Rogue]] or [[B-36 Bruiser]]|2-3 [[E-15 Imp]]|1-2 Y-45 Defender|N/A|3-4 [[S-10 Pest]]||
-8|[[D-53 Grenadier]] + [[I-25 Savior]]|2-3 [[G-47 Trooper]]|1-2 [[H-55 Commando]]|2 of L-31 Rogue or B-36 Bruiser|2-3 E-15 Imp|1-2 Y-45 Defender|1-2 [[X-57 Shotgunner]] or [[X-62 Marksman]]|3-4 S-10 Pest||
-7|D-53 Grenadier + [[I-36 Angel]]|2-3 G-47 Trooper|1-2 H-55 Commando|2 of L-31 Rogue or [[B-48 Gladiator]]|2-3 E-15 Imp|1-2 Y-54 Guardian|1-2 X-57 Shotgunner, X-62 Marksman, or [[X-67 Chaingunner]]|3-4 [[S-27 Virus]]||
-6|D-53 Grenadier + I-36 Angel|2-3 [[G-50 Soldier]]|1-2 [[H-66 Slayer]]|2 of [[L-41 Fighter]] or B-48 Gladiator|2-3 E-15 Imp|1-2 Y-54 Guardian|1-2 X-62 Marksman, X-67 Chaingunner, or [[X-72 Disruptor]]|3-4 S-27 Virus||
-5|[[D-63 Destroyer]] + [[I-47 Archangel]]|2-3 G-50 Soldier|1-2 H-66 Slayer|2 of L-41 Fighter or [[B-60 Warrior]]|2-3 E-15 Imp|1-2 Y-64 Sentinel|1-2 X-67 Chaingunner, X-72 Disruptor, or [[X-77 Beamer]]|3-4 S-27 Virus||
-4|D-63 Destroyer + I-47 Archangel|2-3 [[G-67 Veteran]]|1-2 [[H-77 Assassin]]|2 of L-41 Fighter or B-60 Warrior|2-3 E-15 Imp|1-2 Y-64 Sentinel|1-2 X-72 Disruptor, X-77 Beamer, or [[X-82 Rainmaker]]|3-4 S-27 Virus||
-3|D-63 Destroyer + I-47 Archangel|2-3 G-67 Veteran|1-2 H-77 Assassin|2 of [[L-61 Swordsman]] or [[B-74 Champion]]|2-3 E-15 Imp|1-2 Y-72 Warden|1-2 X-77 Beamer, X-82 Rainmaker, or [[X-87 Electro]]|3-4 [[S-43 Plague]]||
-2|[[D-83 Annihilator]] + I-47 Archangel|2-3 [[G-73 Enforcer]]|1-2 [[H-88 Terminator]]|2 of L-61 Swordsman or B-74 Champion|2-3 E-15 Imp|1-2 Y-72 Warden|1-2 X-82 Rainmaker or X-87 Electro|3-4 S-43 Plague||
-1|D-83 Annihilator + I-47 Archangel|2-3 G-73 Enforcer|1-2 H-88 Terminator|2 of L-61 Swordsman or B-74 Champion|2-3 E-15 Imp|1-2 Y-72 Warden|1-2 X-87 Electro|3-4 S-43 Plague
[[/Table]]
A [[C-30 ARC]] may also be a part of a Security Squad, with 3 unpowered ARCs next to it. The active ARC will have standard contents for a [[Patrol Squad]] ARC.
[[Heading:2]]Unique [[Armory]]/[[Testing]]/[[Quarantine]]/[[Protoforge]] security contents[[/Heading]]
These maps have unique Security contents within "nooks" in the wall. There can between 1-3 of the same type of bot contained within.
[[Table]]
Depth|Brawler ([[Spoiler]]Armory[[/Spoiler]] only)|Duelist ([[Spoiler]]Armory[[/Spoiler]] only)|Grunt|Hunter|Programmer|Saboteur ([[Spoiler]]Armory[[/Spoiler]] only)|Sentry|Specialist|Swarmer||
-4|B-60 Warrior|L-41 Fighter|G-67 Veteran|H-77 Assassin|[[P-70 Sage]]|E-15 Imp|X-72 Disruptor, X-77 Beamer, or X-82 Rainmaker|N/A|S-27 Virus||
-3|B-74 Champion|L-61 Swordsman|G-67 Veteran|H-77 Assassin|[[P-80 Master]]|E-15 Imp|X-77 Beamer, X-82 Rainmaker, or X-87 Electro|Y-72 Warden|S-43 Plague||
-2|N/A|N/A|G-73 Enforcer|H-88 Terminator|P-80 Master|N/A|X-82 Rainmaker or X-87 Electro|Y-72 Warden|S-43 Plague
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Special security-summoning events[[/Heading]]
There are a few events that may trigger additional security guards to spawn on the map.
[[Heading:2]][[Cargo Convoy]] interruption[[/Heading]]
100 turns after a Cargo Convoy is disrupted, Heavies will begin to appear at 0b10-controlled exits and [[Garrison Access|Garrisons]]. Every further 100 turns that pass, another Heavy will enter the map and head toward a nearby exit.
[[Heading:2]][[High Security|High]] or [[Maximum Security]][[/Heading]]
About 80 turns after entering High or Maximum Security, 4 Sentries will spawn from all Garrisons and 0b10-controlled exits.
[[Spoiler]][[Heading:2]][[Quarantine]] Cryocooling Duct failure[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Quarantine Guards.png|Quarantine Guards dispatched from a Garrison[[/Image]]
Cryocooling Duct machines may be sometimes found in Quarantine. These machines the ambient temperature of the map by default, but if 2 are destroyed, the ambient heat will rise up to +20. If this happens, all combat bots will be withdrawn from the map, and 12 [[Quarantine Guard|Quarantine Guards]] will be dispatched after about 100 turns. These bots will guard various high traffic parts of the map, while others patrol the map. A few will guard exits, as well as a Garrison, if one is present.[[/Spoiler]]

Other.Name: Siege Mode
Other.Content: Siege mode is an alternate state toggleable on all mutilslot treads. The transition in and out of siege mode takes 5 turns. During the transition, and for as long as the mode is active, [[Cogmind]] is immobile and the the treads cannot be disabled or removed. While in siege mode, non-melee attacks have +20% accuracy, coverage for all armor and heavy treads is doubled, any treads in siege mode get a free 25% damage reduction, no weapons suffer from recoil effects, and Cogmind is immune to instant part destruction from critical hits. [[Spoiler]][[Megatreads]], [[Tri-treads]],[[/Spoiler]] and any treads containing the word "siege" in the name are capable of high siege mode which instead gives +30% accuracy and 50% damage reduction.

Other.Name: Sneak Attack
Other.Content:
Sneak attacks are a [[Game Mechanics|game mechanic]] where melee attacks performed on bots in certain circumstances where they are not expecting an attack. Sneak attacks will deal double damage and cannot miss. Bots are vulnerable to a sneak attack in the following circumstances:
[[List]]
Hostile combat/non-combat bot (yellow-red): The bot must be unaware of the bot performing the attack. If fast enough, multiple sneak attacks can be performed until the bot has a turn to react.|
Neutral non-combat bot (green/white): If the bot hasn't been attacked yet, the first attack is always a sneak attack.|
Friendly bots (blue/purple/white): All attacks are sneak attacks.
[[/List]]

Other.Name: Squad
Other.Content:
Squads are groups of one or more robots that work together as a single group. The majority of the squads in the game are [[0b10]]-aligned and thus hostile to Cogmind, but there are also [[Derelict]] squads that can be either friendly or hostile to Cogmind depending on the circumstances. Some 0b10 squad types can be recalled using a low success rate Recall hack at a [[Terminal]], but all squad types can be located using an Enumerate hack. The numbers of all squad types, although not their compositions or locations, can be revealed with the Enumerate(Squads) hack.
Typically, one bot per squad is designated as the [[Squad Leader]]. Squad leaders are the only bots that have the AI or order type active. All other bots are set to follow the squad leader. If the squad leader is destroyed, the other bots in the squad will either end up wandering around randomly, or leaving the map if their squad leader was already leaving the map.

[[Heading]]Types of 0b10 Squads[[/Heading]]
[[List]][[Assault Squad]] - Dispatched by 0b10 to target Cogmind directly. Unlike most squads that walk to their target, all Assault contents are contained with a faster wheeled [[C-30 ARC]]. Only get dispatched if Cogmind has [[Alert]] level 2 or higher (400 influence).|[[Coupling Squad]] - Dispatched periodically by 0b10 on any floors where [[Garrison Access|Garrisons]] are available. Consist of a single [[Programmer]] carrying multiple [[Relay Couplers]] to restock a Garrison.|[[Demolisher Squad]] - Dispatched by 0b10 to eliminate large groups of hostiles, particularly [[Assembled]].|[[Extermination Squad]] - Dispatched periodically by 0b10 in [[Factory]] and beyond. They consist entirely of Programmers and will always head directly to Cogmind.|[[Garrison Squad]] - Dispatched by 0b10 Garrisons when combat occurs near that Garrison. Bots will roam around the area where the attack occurred, then return after 200-300 turns.|[[Spoiler]][[Intercept Squad]] - Dispatched by 0b10 directly to Cogmind only in a few special circumstances. Intercept squads consist of powerful [[Prototype Robot|Prototype]] bots designed to quickly neutralize Cogmind.[[/Spoiler]]|[[Investigation Squad]] - Dispatched by 0b10 to investigate an area of interest for 300-400 turns, then they exit the level.|[[Patrol Squad]] - Patrol between two points of interest at varying speeds. Unlike most other squads, patrols only appear at the beginning of a map, and more will not be replenished.|[[Reinforcement Squad]] - Dispatched by 0b10 to permanently reinforce an area of interest. Similar to investigations but do not leave their post and will patrol around the area they are summoned to forever.|[[Security Squad]] - Stand guard at intersections, on top of exits, and in rooms with part stockpiles or Machines. Will typically not move unless they are alerted of a hostile.|[[Surveillance Squad]] - Patrol between two points of interest similar to a Patrol squad, but made up of a single [[Watcher]] instead of combat bots.|[[Transport Squad]] - [[Hauler]] guarded by 0-2 [[Grunt|Grunts]] that transport parts from place to place. Empty Haulers may pick up parts fabricated at a [[Fabricator]].[[/List]]

Other.Name: Sterilization
Other.Content:
Sterilization is a special [[0b10]] response to Cogmind destroying too many combat bots on a single map. When activated, the ambient heat of the floor will be increased forever until Cogmind exits the map. As the heat increases, any remaining bots, parts on the ground, machines, and traps will all melt. Occasionally, machines will explode before they melt.
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Sterilization System[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Triggering[[/Heading]]
The number of bots to kill to trigger Sterilization depends on the map.
[[Table]]
Map|Bots to kill||
[[DSF]]|8||
[[Materials]]|50||
[[Storage]]|75||
Most other maps|130
[[/Table]]
[[Garrison|Garrisons]], [[Wastes]], [[Protoforge]], and [[Command]] can not be Sterilized.
[[Redacted]]
[[Heading:2]][[Protoforge#advanced_fortification_protocols|Advanced Fortification Protocols]][[/Heading]]
If advanced fortification protocols have been engaged in the Protoforge map, the number of kills required to trigger Sterilization is doubled.
[[/Redacted]]

[[Heading]]Timeline of Events[[/Heading]]
[[List]]0: Non-combat bots start evacuating the map and head to 0b10-controlled exits, log messages [[GameText]]ALERT: Persistent threat exposed, engaging [map] sterilization system.[[/GameText]] and [[GameText]]ALERT: All non-combat units evacuation[[/GameText]].|
100: Combat bots start evacuating the map and head to 0b10-controlled exits, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: All combat units evacuate.[[/GameText]]|
300: Ambient heat increases by 10, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Ambient heat levels +10.[[/GameText]]|
450: Ambient heat increases by a further 10|Etc. +10 heat for every 150 turns.[[/List]]
Note: Unlike most other maps, in [[Access]] bots are not evacuated. The evacuation-related alerts will not appear and the bots will continue to stay on the map as usual.
[[Heading:2]]Rapid Sterilization[[/Heading]]
DSFs have a unique rapid sterilization system that works much quicker than normal sterilization. Ambient heat increases begin only 20 turns after the initial announcement and occur every 15 turns after that.

[[Heading]]Part Melting[[/Heading]]
After Sterilization is triggered, parts will begin to melt every 30-40 turns and be destroyed instantly. Parts that are 200 integrity or greater are safe from melting. Parts with a lower integrity are more likely to melt than those with higher integrity. For example, [[Treads]] and [[Armor]] tend to last longer or be immune to melting altogether, while fragile processors will melt almost instantly. Parts only melt when within a 20-tile radius around Cogmind, so with a good enough speed, timing, and luck, it is possible to grab parts that would otherwise melt quickly in the heat.

Other.Name: Strategy
Other.Content: Strategy guides to complete various content.

Other.Name: Strategy/Attacking Scraptown
Other.Content:
[[Scraptown]] is an extremely challenging mid-game area to fight and full-clear. The majority of the armed bots are individually weak, but they appear in the dozens and can easily overwhelm Cogmind and any allies. Many unique items are only obtainable by destroying terrain or killing certain bots, which can make attacking Scraptown seem like a promising endeavor. However, there is a serious drawback of going for a full clear or even smashing a container for one item and running: The [[Zion]] and [[Warlord (Location)]] maps will become hostile when Cogmind tries to enter them. The [[Scraptown#civil_war|Civil War]] is a highly recommended alternative to gaining loot from this map. It is much easier and less risky than a full Scraptown murder is. As such, a Scraptown kill is a challenge that exists more for bragging rights than being a truly beneficial move.

[[Heading]]Items Obtainable by Murder[[/Heading]]
The following items can be obtained by attacking Scraptown's inhabitants and are the main benefits of attacking:
[[List]][[Ballwheel]]: Curator's Association Exhibit|
[[DM-GVY's Chainsaw]]: Curator's Association Exhibit|
[[Exp. Plasma Cutter]]: Obtained by digging through a specific "closed for remodeling" room|
[[Exp. Recalibrator]]: Obtained by killing CR-KLE|
[[Expert System]]: Obtained by killing A0-MCA|
[[Field Manipulator]]: Science Guys shell prototype|
[[ID Mask]]: Obtained by killing a Scientist in Chapter 10|
[[LU-1G1's Laser Shovel]]: Obtained by digging in the center dirt of the LU-1G1's Boring Crew room|
M[[A-1KR's Cyclogen]]: Curator's Association Exhibit|
[[Master Drone Bay]]: Science Guys shell prototype|
[[Personal Teleporter v0.10]]: Science Guys shell prototype|
[[PL-3XN's Ring of Power]]: Obtained in one of two ways: Either killing the [[Explorer]] in the Fellowship of the Rings room or by taking it from a Curator's Association exhibit|
[[Siege Cannon Replica]]: Curator's Association Exhibit|
[[System Spiker]]: Science Guys shell prototype|
[[Thermal Lance]]: Science Guys shell prototype|
[[Voltaic Drivehammer]]: Science Guys shell prototype|
[[Vmp. Humpback]]: Curator's Association Exhibit[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Requirements[[/Heading]]
In order to effectively full clear Scraptown, there are a few general requirements:
[[Heading:2]][[Triborg]] Solve[[/Heading]]
Triborg is by far the scariest individual bot on the map with an incredibly powerful [[Siege Cannon]] that can quickly kill an unprepared Cogmind. Siege mode brings Triborg's initially high 40% core exposure down to a significantly reduced 28% which makes direct damage dealing a rather inefficient method. An EM resistance of 65% doesn't help an EM approach much either, with an average requirement of 285 EM damage to be dealt before corruption death. Very little conventional weaponry can deal enough damage to eliminate Triborg in a reasonable amount of time.
The most reliable way to beat Triborg is with meltdown. Large groups of allies with heat transfer can easily overheat Triborg before it gets much chance to deal damage. [[Storage]] frequently has a vault of 10 [[Grunt|Grunts]] that will become friendly to Cogmind upon entry. These 10 Grunts are sufficient to melt Triborg within a few volleys, if not instantly. [[Army Drone|Army Drones]] from [[Army-in-a-Box]] can also produce sufficient heat transfer for an easy kill. [[DAS Turret|DAS Turrets]] from [[Deploy-a-Sentry]] do not have heat transfer but have extremely high damage output, so if Cogmind can hold Triborg's fire, 3 or 4 turrets taken from the Exiles can deal enough conventional damage for core destruction.
Aside from allies, there are few other Exiles Prototypes that can handle the Triborg fight:
[[List]]
[[AWS/Autocannon]]: The Autocannon has an incredibly high damage output that can take Triborg out within 4 core hits.|
[[Field Lobotomy Kit]]: Triborg is not Disruption immune so the FLK will instantly turn a threat into a useful ally|
[[Firepult]]: Firepult has sufficient heat transfer to melt Triborg with ease. Make sure to pack plenty of cooling to use this early.|
[[YOLO Cannon]]: YOLO Cannon's high 50% meltdown critical easily kills Triborg. Note: the AOE effect of YOLO cannon may damage the loot on the ground.[[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]Trash Killer[[/Heading]]
Cogmind should have an efficient way of dealing with the dozens of average to weak-strength bots that will swarm Scraptown after hostilities begin. All bots will rush straight to the center of the map and Cogmind needs to either hide or take them out very efficiently. Simply average-depth loot will be unable to take out the huge rush of bots. The main strategies are to have an overwhelming force in the center of the map or to stand further away down a corridor and try to take bots out in smaller groups. If opting for the second strategy, long-ranged weaponry is the best to take advantage of some of the shorter-ranged bots.
Here are some good tools for the job:
[[List]]
Good [[Launcher|Launchers]]: Since these bots tend to roam the map in groups, having powerful decently-ranged launchers like the [[Hvy. Rocket Launcher]] is the best way to take out groups from afar.|
AWS/Autocannon: Autocannon has enough damage to core any bot on this level, builtin targeting, fires beyond Cogmind's vision, and even has no upkeep cost.|
[[AWS/Gauss]]: Notably worse than the Autocannon with significantly lower damage, but still good for similar traits. With 3 weapon slots, can be combined with another non-AWS weapon for additional damage.|
Siege Cannon: Easily lootable off of Triborg with a [[CPS Tube]]. This requires the use of [[Tri-treads]] also dropped from Triborg to enter siege mode and avoid the recoil chance. Siege Cannon is not a great weapon to stay in the center of the map with, but retreating down the corridors where it is most effective can be difficult too.|
[[Hvy. Assault Cannon]]: High range and sufficient damage to one shot any bot on core.|
DAS Turrets have high visual range (22) and will kill every bot in one core hit. Keep in mind that eventually they will run low on matter and take longer to fire.|
Bot Army: While they don't last forever, a well positioned army can act as a firing squad for bots that wander into their line of sight. Ideally this includes some combination of Storage Grunts, miscellaneous [[Recycling]] rewirable bots, and potentially even fabricated [[0b10]] bots like [[P-60 Hacker|P-60 Hackers]].|
Army-in-a-Box: Similar to a Grunt army, only there's a lot more Army Drones available. Don't use too many at once or else they will get in each others' way. For maximum effectiveness, return bots that have taken core hits and bots that have short-ranged weapons.
[[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]Essential Parts[[/Heading]]
No NPC murder setup is complete without a few highly essential build components:
[[List]]Backup Treads: Cogmind can easily salvage Triborg for Tri-treads and those should be used if possible. However, depending on Cogmind's starting position, it may be possible to be stuck fighting without having time to move over to the Triborg loot and swapping to the treads. If Cogmind happens to miss a CPS tube hit, a lot of essential loot may not drop.|
Backup Wheels (Optional): [[Wheels]] are useful to temporarily swap on to move quickly. Useful for picking up matter out of Tractor Beam range.|
Backup Armor: Self-explanatory. Triborg drops [[Mak. Medium Armor Plating]] and Elites drop [[Mak. Light Armor Plating]] to use in a pinch.|
Backup Weapons: Aside from Siege Cannon, most of the weapons dropped by NPCs on this map are not ideal for Cogmind to use in Scraptown.|
Backup Power: Self-explanatory.|
[[Cooling Devices]] (optional): Siege Cannon in particular is hot to use in prolonged combat.|
[[Ranged Targeting Utilities]]/[[Weapon Cyclers]]/[[Core Analyzers]] (optional): Useful offensive utilities|
[[Hardlight Generators]]/[[Shield Generators]]/[[Force Fields]] (optional): Useful defensive utilities|
[[Tractor Beam|Normal]] or [[Hpw. Tractor Beam]] and [[Matter Compressors]] (optional): Siege cannon requires a lot of matter to use. Matter storage and Tractor Beams allow Cogmind to continue to fight in extended encounters without having to reposition to collect more matter.|
[[Adv. Visual Processing Unit]]/[[Seismic Detector]] (optional): With long ranged weapons like Siege Cannon, it is best to hit enemies before they can see you and outside of their visual range.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]When to Kill[[/Heading]]
Generally, a build should be designed for killing Scraptown several maps ahead of time. This will typically involve going to [[Exiles (Location)]] and either taking [[FarCom]] or killing/stealing for powerful Exiles prototypes that can handle Scraptown kills. Scraptown kills are best done on -7 for the maximum amount of slots and preparation time. While it may still be possible to kill earlier, killing at -7 is difficult enough already. Cogmind should have at least 3 propulsion slots and 3 weapon slots to use Tri-treads and Siege Cannon from Triborg.

[[Heading]]Location to Fight[[/Heading]]
When engaging hostilities, there are 2 best points where Cogmind can choose to start the fight:
[[Heading:2]]Next to the UFD Gate[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Scraptown Triborg Surrounded.png|Grunts surrounding Triborg prepared to melt it down, with nearby Protector[[/Image]]
The gate is the best place to begin if Cogmind has allies or a quick way to neutralize Triborg. There is lots of room so allies won't have to run past each other or try to shoot through each other like they would in hallways. However, the open area is also a downside for the hostile UFD bots that can pour in from many different directions. Allies should initially be positioned around Triborg in a box as shown to the right. If a [[Protector]] is available, place it close to the corner of the Gate so it is more out of harms way. Note: Even with a large number of allies, expect to have to retreat to the corner of the map at some point during the fight.
[[Heading:2]]Bottom Left Corner[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Scraptown Bottom Left Triborg Path.png|Path Triborg should take if in the bottom left corner[[/Image]]
If the Triborg solution doesn't involve allies, it is much better to hide in the corner of the map to avoid the initial bot swarm. Stay in the position shown in the image to the right to begin hostilities. When Triborg peeks around the corner, move up a few tiles so Triborg is forced to move closer to Cogmind to shoot. The right side path to this location is a little short, but the top path can take good advantage of the large sightlines.

[[Heading]]Beginning Hostilities[[/Heading]]
If Cogmind starts the Scraptown assault near Triborg, the #1 priority is to use a CPS tube on Triborg to ensure full salvage drops. Take out Triborg with whatever means are available, then grab and equip the Tri-treads and Siege Cannon (if slots available). The center is a tough position to stay long-term, so use allies as temporary distractions and retreat to a safer area of the map like the bottom left corner. If fighting in the corner, start by either shooting a wall out or killing any nearby bot. Lure Triborg close and use the CPS Tube, then go for the kill or assimilate. After Triborg is dead, stay put and slowly clear out the UFD squads that wander by. Eventually, Optimus and friends will come directly to Cogmind. After taking them out, the hardest challenges of the map are done.
At this point, patience is key. Wait around for any leftover UFD patrols to wander by and take them out. Leaving too soon can force a fight against a lot of bots in a bad position. Generally, only moving around to collect more matter when needed is the best strategy here. A [[Seismic Detector]] can tell when patrols are coming by from far away.
After waiting around for a few thousand turns without any action, it is time to take the center of the map. This is where the vast majority of the remaining bots are. Sniping bots from afar one at a time works best here as heading directly into the center area can alert larger groups of bots to all attack simultaneously. There are likely still a few dozen bots hanging around the area. After the center is all cleared, be careful of any patrols leftover on the right side of the map.

[[Heading]]Loot Time[[/Heading]]
Most of the loot should be fairly self explanatory to grab. A few less obvious ones:
[[List]]
Dig through the back of the Scrapoid Pod storage to get many more pods|
Dig out the center earth tile in LU-1G1's Boring Crew room|
Check rooms closed for remodelling for the rare Exp. Plasma Cutter|
Smash open the wall hiding additional Botcubes in the Botcube Research room
[[/List]]

Other.Name: Strategy/Cetus
Other.Content:
When first entering [[Cetus]], the 4 [[Cetus Guard|Cetus Guards]] appearing around the corner may appear intimidating at first. However, they are not too tough of foes and have some extremely useful loot, especially the [[Adv. KE Penetrator]], [[Centrium Heavy Treads]], and [[Centrium Medium Armor Plating]]. They have an above average amount of core integrity but no critical destroy immunity or EM resistance, so destroy critical weapons like [[Hyp. Weapons]] and [[Electromagnetic Weapons]] work quite well against them. [[Electromagnetic Launchers]] like the [[Proton Missile Launcher|regular]] and [[Imp. Proton Missile Launcher]] are particularly effective at taking out 4 of them in a short amount of time. There will be some [[Corrupted Parts|corrupted]] parts, but this loot is definitely worth the corruption. 
Often, Cogmind will have a big group of allies brought over from [[Extension]]. These can be helpful and harmful at the same time. Too many allies, especially melee ones, will get in the way of each other. Telling some blue-controllable allies to stay back can be a good idea. [[A7]] in particular is a great ally, providing EM damage and [[Remote Force Field|remote force fielding]] effects. Another standout ally is the [[Guerrilla (5)|Guerilla]]. They have -Salvage from their [[Bore Cannon]], but perform very well against the Cetus Guards due to their very high critical destroy chance, often destroying weapons or even cores in a single hit. However, to get optimal salvage, they should be left behind.

[[Heading]]Cetus Mainframe[[/Heading]]
The [[Reinforced Walls#cetus|Cetus Mainframe Doors]] have a very low base success rate of 10% and a high armor value of 40. While [[Hackware]] can help out here, the Cetus Guards can conveniently drop a [[Adv. Variable Charge Gun]] which can be overloaded to destroy the Sealed Heavy Doors. A [[Plasma Cutters|Plasma Cutter]] will eventually cut through as well.

Other.Name: Strategy/Defeating Architect
Other.Content:
[[Image]]Access_0 Entrance.png|Hostile Entrance to Access_0[[/Image]]
[[Access_0]] is one of the hardest maps in the game that requires Cogmind to deal with numerous powerful threats on the map that gives very little breathing room for fixing a build that is starting to fall apart. Assuming [[MAIN.C]] is defeated in [[Command]], there is a large amount of preparation that can be done after all of the bots have become disabled. [[Command#command_cache_contents|MAIN.C's cache]] can provide some incredibly powerful parts, and the rest of the map can have plenty of goodies to grab. Since Access_0 is a very combat-oriented map, make sure to bring backups of essentials like power, propulsion, weapons, and armor. While there are some part caches in Access_0 itself, their contents are not particularly reliable and shouldn't be counted on to provide crucial backups. A more consistent source of parts are the drops from the [[Enhanced Bot|Enhanced Bots]] and the [[A Bots]], assuming weapons with neutral salvage can be used at least some of the time. There tend to be abundant legs and mediocre-quality power above all else from the [[Enhanced Grunt|Enhanced Grunts]] and [[Enhanced Hunter|Enhanced Hunters]]. The Grunt's [[Neutron Cannon|Neutron Cannons]] can serve in a pinch, but aren't impressive due to their middling damage and short range.

[[Heading]]Propulsion Selection[[/Heading]]
All propulsion types can be used to win in Access_0, although some are definitely better suited to the map than others. Hover and legs are nice middle ground propulsion that can have a lot of power and still retain maneuverability. Treads are the best heavy combat type with lots of coverage and integrity, but they may get stuck fighting in bad situations with no good way to reposition. Wheels are much more more niche than treads due to the rarity of good lategame wheels. Flight is the easiest to use to take down all of the pads but can struggle the most to finish off the Architect in the final fight due to lack of integrity.
[[Heading:2]][[Flight Units|Flight]][[/Heading]]
Flight builds should be extremely quick at this point in the game (sub 20 speed) and are able to outrun every bot on the map. Flight does not have the integrity for prolonged fighting. Typically flight builds should destroy the pads first and then try to lure the Architect away from all of the other bots for a quick kill. Evasion utilities in [[Phase Shifters]] and [[Reaction Control Systems]] work well to minimize the number of attacks that land. More expensive defensive utilities like [[Shield Generators]] or [[Force Fields]] also combine well with evasion utilities but may be tough to support. A bots are a major threat to this playstyle, as their remote force fields can prolong the final encounter to the point that Cogmind is unable to finish off the Architect. Destroy critical weapons like the [[Hyp. Multirail]] can be good for taking out a few enhanced bots or removing hover units off of key A bots so they don't catch up as quickly for the final fight. A strong final Architect-killer weapon is a must for this strategy.
[[Heading:2]][[Hover Units|Hover]][[/Heading]]
Hover builds tend to be the hardest to put together but can end up with a strong mix of speed, offensive, and defensive capabilities. Using a [[Zio. Metafield Generator]] or [[ST Field Compressor]] can help to outrun groups of bots or reposition more easily. However, a strategy entirely based on running away tends to fare much worse for hover builds due to the lower speed and ability to get trapped with the inability to hop in tight 1 tile corridors. Hover builds should choose their fights carefully and can reposition in combat to avoid getting outnumbered. Unlike Flight builds, Hover builds usually have the energy and mass support to use both evasion utilities and other defensive utilities like Force Fields. This combination can cut down significantly on attrition while exploring the map.
[[Heading:2]][[Legs]][[/Heading]]
Leg builds finally start to trend into the area where having a reliable way to "shoo" (deal 80 core damage to trigger the teleport) the Architect is a requirement. Legs can take advantage of the movement bonuses to dodge (5/10/15 extra evasion per tile moved in a row) and use evasion utilities to avoid most shots while running in a straight line. However, extensive repositioning is quite expensive, even for faster leg builds. [[Infowar]] like [[Terrain Scanners]] or [[Drone Bays]] can help locate the pads quicker and reduce damage taken from the Architect coming back repeatedly. One option for legs is a "siege legs" build, where an extra pair of treads are used in addition to the standard legs. This requires 2 extra propulsion slots above what Cogmind already needs to support for the full effect. However, it is not worth attaching treads if it will place Cogmind overweight. One of the bigger benefits of this strategy is that the Enhanced Hunters can't continually knock Cogmind back into collapsed tiles due to the knockback cancellation ability of treads. Additionally, siege mode can be used for tough encounters.
[[Heading:2]][[Wheels]]/[[Treads]][[/Heading]]
Wheels and treads are the slowest Access_0 propulsion types, and as such, need to be the most prepared for heavy combat. Lots of armor and strong weaponry are required for these builds. Wheel builds tend to have lower propulsion slots and higher utility slots, necessitating more utility slots being taken up by armor to compensate. Treads usually have 6-8 propulsion slots and can afford to run less armor in utility slots due to the higher propulsion coverage. Terrain scanning and drones are especially recommended for these builds to reduce the pad finding time. They will end up needing to shoo the Architect repeatedly throughout the level and fight every bot they meet.
[[Heading:2]][[Sigix Exoskeleton]][[/Heading]]
The Exoskeleton plays a little differently from the other propulsion types. Due to its incredible amount of builtin infowar, it is quite easy to find and destroy all of the Architect's pads. With the [[Sigix Shearcannon]] it is quite easy to destroy every bot on the map in a few volleys. An Exoskeleton-boosted [[Core Cannon]] can kill the Architect from full integrity, which allows skipping the pad destroying altogether. With weaker weapons like [[Sigix Sheargun|Sigix Shearguns]] or a [[Sigix Broadsword]], the Exoskeleton tends to play like a hover build without much shooing power, taking a few specific encounters and killing A bots, but mostly running from the Architect in favor of searching and destroying the pads.

[[Heading]]Key Weapon Roles[[/Heading]]
Some weapon types excel at some situations and not in others. Entropic, Kinetic, Pierce, Slashing, Thermal, Vortex damage-dealing weapons all tend to be good all-around in Access_0. Electromagnetic damage is decent in a few key places, while Impact and Explosive damage tend to be subpar. However, there are some particularly useful weapons for specific circumstances. Ratings below include (-) = not suitable for role, (~) = passable for role, (+) = good for role, (++) = great for role. Ratings are a combination of how good the weapon is at killing something, its + or - salvage potential, and resource costs of use.

[[List:Ordered]]The Core Cannon is very strong vs most bots in Access_0 but costs too much core to use consistently, it will often result in early death by core.|Critical hits can disarm or destroy propulsion/weapons of some coring immune bots but not kill directly. Mostly niche use for flight/hover.|A6 is neutral to EM and annoying to kill otherwise, but all other A bots are 75% resistant.|Vortex Lances are the strongest melee weapon here but they have limited uses and should be used sparingly. A bots and the Architect final fight are the best uses for the Vortex Lance as a primary weapon.|Multirails are reasonable Architect shooers, but they have a very high matter upkeep. A [[Desublimator]] or other matter regenerating utilities are recommended to allow Multirails to shoo over a long period of time.|The Cep. Plasma Driver is a slightly worse Architect shoo due to its 1/3 chance of dealing less than the 80 damage required.|The Sigix Shearcannon has incredible firepower but it comes with a caveat. Cogmind must typically be within 2-4 tiles of the target in order to gain maximum damage potential. Otherwise the weapon's arc will cause some projectiles to miss, with higher percentages of projectiles missing at further distances. This weapon is best suited for faster propulsion types, although even treads can make good use if it in some situations.|Vortex weaponry is quite powerful and good at killing all in Access_0. However, it is not good to use for fighting everything as they have limited usages. A bots and the final Architect kill tend to be the most important uses.|These launchers have very strong killing power and Architect shooing potential. However, the incredibly high matter cost makes them not a good choice for regular usage. One or two [[Prc. Matter Filter|Prc. Matter Filters]] along with a Desublimator may make this a more reliable option, but it may be a bad idea to rely too heavily on launchers without other good options due to the risk of running out of matter entirely.|The Alpha Cannon Mk. II does not need any particle charging in some situations but does in others. It naturally kills 120 integrity Enhanced Grunts/Hunters in 2 hits with its base 65 damage. A bots and Enhanced Sentries have 150 core integrity which takes 3 hits. However, an Adv. Particle Charger ups the damage to 81. This turns those 3 hits into a 2 hit kill. This also matters for the Architect, where 81 damage will guarantee the shoo on a single core hit instead of requiring 2 hits.[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Other useful parts[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:2]]Targeting[[/Heading]]
Specifically, [[Ranged Targeting Utilities]], for ranged combat, or [[Melee Analysis Suites]] for melee. Targeting is the most important combat utility to use in Access_0. The Architect and Enhanced Hunters all run [[Exp. Phase Shifter|Exp. Phase Shifters]] which dramatically reduce chance to hit ranged attacks. Running 2-3 targeting utilities is extremely recommended to maintain a high chance to hit, although melee builds are able to get away with fewer.
[[Heading:2]]Core chance to hit boosters[[/Heading]]
Specifically, [[Core Analyzers]] and [[Armor Integrity Analyzers]]. Next to targeting, these are the best offensive utilities to use. Core Analyzers are superior, but they both work together. An Armor Integrity Analyzer should be used over the second Core Analyzer if there is space.
[[Heading:2]][[Weapon Cyclers]]/[[Actuators]][[/Heading]]
Weapon cycling is another great way to increase the damage done. Keep in mind they do require extra weapon energy/heat upkeep as the full volley will be fired more quickly than without. A [[Mni. Quantum Capacitor|Mni.]] or [[Quantum Capacitor|Regular Quantum Capacitor]] is good for any single powerful energy cannon, especially ones that can shoo the Architect in a single core hit.
[[Heading:2]][[Kinecellerators]]/[[Particle Chargers]][[/Heading]]
Nearly mandatory for some weapon types and less important for others. In some cases, like with the Omega Cannon and an Adv. Kinecellerator, it can be the difference between a single core hit Architect shoo and a double core hit Architect shoo.
[[Heading:2]][[Shield Generators]] and [[Force Fields]][[/Heading]]
Force fields are one of the best ways to reduce damage in the game as long as their heavy energy demands can be met. Airborne propulsion may want to use Shield Generators for their lesser energy requirements and lighter mass.
[[Heading:2]][[Phase Shifters]]/[[Reaction Control Systems]][[/Heading]]
All around good ways to reduce damage taken. Reaction Control Systems can only effectively be used by airborne propulsion types and legs.
[[Heading:2]][[Microwarp Drive]][[/Heading]]
This is especially useful for grounded propulsion types. The Microwarp Drive can be used to travel large distances very quickly in order to get to a specific pad location, reposition for a fight, or even just move around much quicker than normal. The core cost is prohibitive for constant warping, but this item can save a lot on overall build attrition with good use.
[[Heading:2]]Scouting Infowar[[/Heading]]
Specifically, [[Terrain Scanners]] with [[Terrain Scan Processors]], [[Drone Bays]], [[Visual Processing Units]], [[Structural Scanner]] or [[Deep Structural Scanner|DSS]] variant, [[Triangulator]], or [[IFF Parsers]]. All of these provide extra bot or map intel which can be used for locating pads more easily, finding shortcut digs that can be taken, or avoiding some bots. The Structural Scanner is more useful for airborne propulsion than grounded propulsion since it works instantly and can be used to dodge groups of hostiles if running away. It doesn't typically help find the pads sooner like the others.
[[Heading:2]][[ECM Suites]][[/Heading]]
For airborne propulsion only. This can help take some pressure off by causing groups of followers to much more quickly lose tracking of Cogmind.
[[Heading:2]][[Triangulator]][[/Heading]]
This typically niche item has a unique ability in that it allows for tracking hostiles at 24 range even if they can't be seen via other sensor methods. The Architect has scan cloak 5 which prevents all other detection methods. Using the Triangulator can pinpoint the way the Architect is coming from at long range which can greatly help in determining pad locations.
[[Heading:2]]Matter generating utilities[[/Heading]]
Specifically, [[Desublimator]], [[Field Recycling Units]], [[Matter Filters]], [[Tractor Beams]], and [[Matter Compressors]]. For any kinetic based weapons or weapons that cause a lot of negative salvage like the Potential Cannons, having ways of stockpiling matter or restocking up on matter mid-map can be entirely essential to avoid losing the run due to running out of matter. The Desublimator can be found off of Enhanced Hunters only on this map, but the others can be brought over from earlier maps.
[[Heading:2]]Energy support[[/Heading]]
Specifically, [[Energy Wells]], [[Power Amplifiers]], and [[Energy Filters]]. All of these utilities can be used to maintain expensive energy cannons and force fields through prolonged combat. Energy wells can be dropped on the ground to instantly absorb the energy needed to keep firing, while the others must be attached to help.
[[Heading:2]][[Remote Datajacks]][[/Heading]]
If the Data Conduit is used, Cogmind will be given intel for instant kill codes for all A bots that must be used with a Remote Datajack.
[[Heading:2]][[Terrabomb]][[/Heading]]
Although a little niche, Terrabombs do great at opening up a large part of the map to check for nearby pads. This is a double-edged sword since any nearby groups of enemies will spot you instantly, and the Architect can potentially start shooting from out of weapon range.
[[Heading:2]][[Sigix Terminator|Regular]] or [[Supercharged Sigix Terminator]][[/Heading]]
This single-use weapon is best used after taking down all of the pads in order to kill or at least severely cripple the Architect for the final fight. If airborne, this can also be used to kill off a lot of the bots following behind in a big mass.
[[Heading:2]][[Transdimensional Reconstructor|Regular]] or [[Hpw. Transdimensional Reconstructor]][[/Heading]]
There is almost always one of these on the map somewhere, and the Architect drops one when defeated. However, using one of these to escape can be an issue if defeating the Architect with a weapon with knockback like a kinetic cannon because it may be dropped too far away to pick up to exit the map in time. Potential Cannons also have a habit of destroying them when dropped on the ground. Keeping a spare is a way to escape with a non-Architect killing win if all hope is lost instead of dying in Access_0.
[[Heading:2]][[Core Reset Matrix]][[/Heading]]
There are several Alien Artifacts on the map and using the Core Reset Matrix ahead of time allows for locating them right away on entering the map. Sometimes being able to head for a Core Regenerator or Integrity Redistributor right away after entering the map is the difference between a loss and a win.
[[Heading:2]][[Integrity Redistributor]][[/Heading]]
Useful to prevent essential parts of the build from breaking or just generally to repair everything at once. Limited parts with very high value such as [[Shieldings]] or non-regenerative armor like [[Zio. Shade Armor]] or [[Exp. Powered Armor]], as well as unique parts that are essential to the build, should be taken off preemptively at low integrity in order to use a Redistributor on them at a later time.
[[Heading:2]][[Core Regenerator]][[/Heading]]
Most helpful if using core-hungry Alien Artifacts like the Core Cannon, Microwarp Drive, or an Integrity Redistributor. It provides 400 (or more core with [[LRC Armor]] that can be used as more fuel for these parts, or even just extra integrity to stay alive. Sometimes it is better to use before entering the map if core is low enough.
[[Heading:2]][[Navigation Efficiency Matrix]][[/Heading]]
While this artifact can be very painful to use from the random teleportation, it does have some good usages in Access_0. When teleporting, all of the Enhanced bots lose tracking on Cogmind. This can be used on airborne propulsion to avoid getting large groups of Enhanced bots following behind, or on grounded propulsion to attempt to reposition or even avoid fighting groups of enemies. It is a mixed bag since it can just as easily teleport Cogmind into an even worse position than before.

[[Heading]]Stages of the map[[/Heading]]
There are several distinct stages of the map where different strategies can be used. Some playstyles may skip certain stages entirely, like how a flight build will typically not stick around for the initial map fight, while grounded propulsion builds will have to fight.
[[Heading:2]]Initial fight[[/Heading]]
Cogmind is confronted by the Architect, A8, and 2 dormant Enhanced Grunts. Rarely, a patrol of more Enhanced Grunts or Enhanced Hunters spawns close enough to also join in here. Flight will typically ignore this part and skip straight to hunting for the pads to destroy. Hover can kill all the bots and shoo the Architect right away or move deeper into the level and try to fight the bots one-on-one instead. Grounded propulsion usually need to fight right at the starting position, so be prepared with strong weaponry to begin with. Siege up right at the entrance of the map if using treads. Targeting the Architect for a shoo is usually the best approach, followed by A8, and finally the Enhanced Grunts. If lacking any good Architect shooing weapons, focusing A8 first may be preferable so A8's Remote Force Field won't be able to protect the Architect.
[[Heading:2]]Searching for the pads[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Access_0 Subspace Access Node.png|Subspace Access Node layout[[/Image]]
This stage is where the vast majority of the time spent in Access_0. This part involves running or actively fighting the Architect, Enhanced bot guards and patrols, and the A bots as they appear. Infowar utilities are most useful at this time. The general strategy for combat here is to shoo the Architect and then start heading in the direction that it came from. Since it typically comes from the closest pad, that is the best way to get in the right general area. However, if multiple pads are close by, the Architect can start spawning at different pads and coming at different directions. This can make it tough to decide which direction to head in. Infowar is best to help find the pads in this situation, but if none is available then making a guess at the pad location and heading there is better than getting stuck moving back and forth in a loop, failing to get anywhere.
When using terrain scanning, there are often telltale signs of a pad even before getting the whole area scanned. Any of the 4 inner tiles or the 4 surrounding cyan tiles are very recognizable. The white tiles surrounding the machine are also not guaranteed to lead to a pad, but they are good to investigate. Finally, pads are always found at the end of 2 tile corridors. Following 2 tile paths can be a good way to get to the final pad location.
Drone Bays and especially Terrain Scanners tend to have high coverage and not the most impressive integrity. They should usually be swapped out during any prolonged combat encounters for offensive utilities or better armor. With a good shooing weapon, it may not be necessary to swap out every time the Architect comes. Make sure these important utilities don't get destroyed early on. If using drones, the best time to release them is just before or right after the Architect teleports away. That gives them the maximum amount of time to explore before the Architect gets a chance to attack them.
If the [[Data Conduit]] was used, finding the pads is easy since all the machines are revealed on entering the map. However, the additional [[Enhanced Programmer]] patrols can be a huge pain even when knowing exactly where to go. Make sure to have a good answer to these Programmers.
Most of the A bots are fairly similar in overall strategy to fight. Most have remote force fields that shield allies, so the A bots are a high priority to take out first. EM is ineffective against all of them except for A6, for which EM is the best solution. Generally, any other damage type is fine for taking out the rest of them. Core Stripper and Disintegrator are uniquely good for killing some of the A bots because they guarantee (or nearly guarantee) full salvage of all parts.
[[Heading:2]]Destroying the Singularity Gate (optional)[[/Heading]]
Destroying the gate is an optional action that needs to be done in order to obtain any Architect Logs lore without a way to dig into the 120 armored shell. Otherwise, the singularity will crush Cogmind before there is enough time to get the lore. The gate is on the left side of the map and [[A2]] is on the way. The gate itself is very fragile and just about any weapon will destroy it easily. It is best to get rid of nearby pads on the right side of the map before crossing the bridge so the Architect takes longer to get to Cogmind's location. After that, take the trek back to finish off the final pad and the Architect.
[[Heading:2]]The final pad[[/Heading]]
After all the other pads are destroyed, the Architect will continually teleport back to the last pad. This can be frustrating for grounded propulsion, where after being shooed the Architect will return after only a few moves as you get closer and closer. At a certain point, it is best to ignore the Architect and just walk by until the last pad is destroyed. Faster propulsion types have an easier time of doing this, and the Microwarp Drive can help a lot here. Putting on evasion utilities helps to reduce the damage taken during this last walk.
[[Heading:2]]The final fight[[/Heading]]
After all this, the Architect can finally be fought normally. For grounded builds, siege up with any treads if you have them, then start fighting to the death. Frailer airborne builds might need to lure the bulk of the pursuers to one corner of the map and then take the Architect to the other side of the map to avoid getting overwhelmed.
[[Heading:2]]Escape/cleaning up[[/Heading]]
After the Architect is destroyed, the Singularity Gate will be trigger a 10 turn countdown if still intact. Grounded builds may need to be close to the Architect if relying on the Transdimensional Reconstructor that it drops. The singularity countdown will kill Cogmind instantly if still on the map in that time. Slower builds will usually need to detach all parts and core hover to equip the Reconstructor and to make it to the exit. Airborne propulsion usually have enough time to get to the exit without needing to do this.
If the gate is destroyed, however, there is an unlimited amount of time to clean up any stragglers on the map. Get the [[Architect Data Core]] and head to the bottom-left corner of the map to open up the Architect Logs Terminal and obtain any new lore. Exploring the rest of the map will cause all remaining A bots to spawn as normal. The A bots and any other remaining Enhanced bots can be fought for extra points.

Other.Name: Strategy/Defeating MAIN.C
Other.Content:
[[Command]] is one of the toughest maps in the game and has a lot to prepare for. Since the most challenging encounters on the map are fixed, it is possible to prepare for many things ahead of time. Unlike the basic [[Wintype]], combat is mandatory in order to kill [[MAIN.C]], although Cogmind does not necessarily need to do any fighting. However, it is always a good idea to be able to meaningfully contribute to the fight. [[Command#cave_seal_contents|Cave Seal allies]] can be incredibly strong, and can even kill MAIN.C unaided in some cases.

[[Heading]]Seal Strategy[[/Heading]]
Both [[Warlord (Alignment)]] and [[Imprint]] seals are quite powerful and have the potential to carry a run through the [[Command#doom_corridor|Doom Corridor]], and sometimes even through MAIN.C. Since seals have a 0% base success rate, opening them requires some forward planning. A decent stack of [[Hackware]] is all but required to open seals successfully. Killing 0b10 [[Operator|Operators]] can be a good way to stockpile Hackware ahead of time. Destroying one or more Network Hubs in [[Hub_04(d)]] can provide free defensive hacking bonuses. Prototype Hackware is very useful here for minimizing the number of utilities that need to be carried around. Other ways to increase hacking capabilities are the [[Terminal]] Trojan(Botnet) hack and the allied Operator bonus.
One advantage of Warlord alignment is the ability to skip the Hackware requirement entirely. After staying approximately 1000 turns in the [[Warlord (Alignment)#-2_research_assault|-2 Research Assault]], a special manual hack will be given to Cogmind that will open both Command seals.
Locating the Seals can be difficult on some maps. Unless the Phase Generator is destroyed, terrain scanning does not work in Command. It may be worth keeping a [[Terrain Scanners|Terrain Scanner]] around in case of an early Phase Generator. While it does generate 150+ Alert, the ability to search for Seals and potentially use [[Sensor Arrays|Sensors]] to avoid enemy encounters may be a worthy tradeoff. Unfortunately, the [[Machine Analyzer]] does not work on seal Terminals, and neither does the [[GameText]]Index(Terminals)[[/GameText]] hack. Using the [[Data Conduit]] trivializes the search, as all machine intel is given instantly upon entering the map.
Once a seal has been located, there is one choice to make. Use the seal now or fight the Doom Corridor first and come back for the seal for the MAIN.C fight? The answer can depend on the seal type, Alert situation, machine location relative to the Doom Corridor, Cogmind's build, and more. Opening a seal will spawn a large group of allies immediately and allows a few backup waves to spawn over time. This is great to protect Cogmind immediately, although it may not help the Alert situation in the case of Imprint or Core Reset Matrix (CRM) seals if there are a lot of hostiles nearby or if the seal is far away from the Doom Corridor. Large groups of blue or purple allies can skyrocket Alert and trigger [[High Security]] quickly. Warlord allies do not generate Alert themselves, so this is less of an issue for that faction. If the seal is far from the Doom Corridor, it may be impractical for Cogmind to defeat the Doom Corridor solo and then make the trek back to the seal and then all the way back to MAIN.C without getting caught up by additional patrols, [[Extermination Squad|Exterminations]], and [[Assault Squad|Assaults]]. Prolonged time in Command will cause part attrition to Cogmind and/or a loss of seal allies very quickly. High Security disables the seal machines and the Assault forces will make quick work of any amassed allies with additional [[Demolisher|Demolishers]] being sent along, although already opened seals will not stop spawning allies when the machine network is disabled. If Cogmind is already in good shape to take on the Doom Corridor without assistance, the allies may be better saved for the MAIN.C fight instead.

[[Heading]]Doom Corridor Strategy[[/Heading]]
The Doom Corridor is the first major fight of the extended endgame. 2 [[M Guard|M Guards]] and 2 [[Combat Programmer|Combat Programmers]] down a hallway. They can tank very well and deal quite a bit of damage back to Cogmind. It is possible to skip fighting Doom Corridor to avoid any combat at this part, but it is not generally recommended because all 4 of the guards will be summoned to aid MAIN.C later on. The vast majority of runs hoping to complete Command will have to fight head-on.
[[Heading:2]]Doom Corridor Skip[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Command Doco Skip.png|One Doom Corridor skip[[/Image]]
Digging past the Doom Corridor requires a strong digging tool that can break through 100 armor tiles, ideally at range. Dig the path shown on the right to safely get past without being spotted. The end of this path results in a 4 tile dig which does have a slight cave-in risk. There is an alternative route that digs directly into the terminal tile and through the Sealed Barrier instead, but this can be even riskier as a poorly timed misfire or misdirect can place Cogmind in a very bad spot. Another alternative skipping solution for airborne builds is to use one or mores [[ECM Suites]] after luring the guards out of the corridor. The idea is to loop the Combat Programmers across the map for a while until the M Guards get sufficiently far out of the way. Then use the ECM Suites on the return trip so they forget about Cogmind. Then simply pass through the corridor up to MAIN.C, forgotten by its guards.
[[Heading:3]]Why skip?[[/Heading]]
There are a few reasons why skipping the guards might be desirable. If going for a [[Command#w8_fortifying_0b10surrender|W8 Wintype]], keeping the Doom Corridor guards alive is very useful for defeating the summoned [[Enhanced Q-Series]]. The more bots destroyed on the way, the fewer guards there are to protect Cogmind and MAIN.C for the hard part of the ending. Another reason could be if [[Zhirov]]'s SGEMP quest has been completed. Zhirov will set off the Modified SGEMP after phase one of MAIN.C is defeated any unpower all bots anyway, so there is not a big benefit in fighting the Doom Corridor first, except for the possibility of looting the valuable M Guard loot. One last reason might be if Cogmind has a very powerful MAIN.C killer, where the guards won't be able to reach Cogmind by the time MAIN.C is dead. This is mostly applicable to the extreme superweapon the [[BFG-9k Vortex Edition]] that can kill MAIN.C in only a few hits.
[[Heading:2]]Doom Corridor Guards[[/Heading]]
The Doom Corridor guards are quite intimidating at first glance. The Combat Programmers don't deal too much damage compared to the M Guards, but they still rack up [[Corruption]] quite quickly, and their strong hacking ability can assimilate allies. M Guards can deal massive direct damage to Cogmind and any allies around with their powerful launchers.
The guards complement each other well and protect the other bot type effectively. M Guards are reasonably susceptible to EM attacks with only 50% damage resistance, but Combat Programmers can cleanse their corruption before getting enough for a kill. The M Guards provide high damage reduction to the Combat Programmers with their [[AEGIS Remote Shield]] that makes them more difficult to kill first.
[[Heading:2]]Useful parts vs Doom Corridor[[/Heading]]
Some specific parts can be especially helpful for conquering the Doom Corridor:
[[Heading:3]][[Point Defense Systems]][[/Heading]]
Most of the damage coming from the M Guards is from their Launchers. A single [[Adv. Point Defense System]] has a roughly 2/3 chance of shooting down a Launcher shot coming in from >3 range. A second one brings that chance up to about a 90% chance to shoot down Launcher shots. This is a significant damage decrease to Cogmind if fighting solo and is absolutely crucial to keeping large groups of allies alive.
[[Heading:3]][[Exp. EM Shield]][[/Heading]]
Fairly self-explanatory, this part will reduce the offensive threat of Combat Programmers substantially.
[[Heading:3]][[Imp. Shock Absorption System|Imp]]/[[Exp. Shock Absorption System]][[/Heading]]
This is a good alternative to the Adv. Point Defense to cut down Launcher damage taken.
[[Heading:3]][[Graphene Brace]][[/Heading]]
This part is most helpful against [[Graviton Cannon]] M Guards. Blast is a scary mechanic to face, and getting an Adv. Point Defense blasted off immediately into a Launcher hit is the stuff of nightmares. It also helps a little against the Combat Programmer corruption criticals.
[[Heading:3]]Strong Thermal Cannons like [[Enh. Nova Cannon]][[/Heading]]Combat Programmers have a -25% resistance to Thermal damage and strong Cannons are the best way to exploit this. Alternatively, a thermal gun stack with good burn criticals can be used to overheat the bots to death and earn an early kill.
[[Heading:3]]Strong EM Cannons like [[Com. HERF Cannon]][[/Heading]]
After the Combat Programmers are taken down, the M Guards are vulnerable to EM damage. With high resistances all around and an additional 50% damage reduction from AEGIS, EM is the ideal way to kill here. M Guards only have 50% EM resistance, and EM corruption ignores the AEGIS damage reduction entirely. HERF can take down an M Guard in relatively few volleys.
[[Heading:3]][[Core Stripper]]/[[Disintegrator]]/[[Warp Cannon]][[/Heading]]
These weapons can instantly kill any of the Doom Corridor guards. Core Stripper and Disintegrator in particular are great at generating loot, although they have prohibitive resources costs. These are best used by airborne builds that can easily separate the guards from each other for easier looting. Alternatively, allies can be used to draw fire away from Cogmind so that the dropped loot doesn't get beat up by M Guard Launchers.
[[Heading:3]][[Firepult]][[/Heading]]
This part can single handedly melt all of the Doom Corridor bots in only a few volleys, with some lucky hits. If heat dissipation allows, using a Quantum Capacitor can help a lot to overwhelm the [[Exp. Coolant Injector|Exp. Coolant Injectors]] of the M Guards even quicker.
[[Heading:3]][[Vortex Catalyst Activator]][[/Heading]]
