This launcher is uniquely good at softening up the Doom Corridor due to dealing Vortex damage, something that none of the bots resist. It may not be able to single handedly kill all the guards due to the limited number of shots it can fire, but it should get most of the way there, albeit with the cost of dropping loot to 0.
[[Heading:3]][[Microwarp Drive]][[/Heading]]
This part is very strong for slow treaded bots. Either get into line of sight or shoot with a long-ranged weapon to attract attention, then warp out of the corridor to safety. This allows for easily separating the Combat Programmers to destroy them first without any AEGIS protection. The M Guards will take a long time to make their way over.
[[Heading:3]]Defensive [[Hackware]][[/Heading]]
Defensive Hackware will reduce the chances of Combat Programmers being able to hack allies. Very useful if Cogmind has seal allies.
[[Heading:3]][[Energy Wells]][[/Heading]]
Using stored energy to continue firing EM weaponry or to power expensive [[Defensive Utilities]] is always useful in combat.
[[Heading:3]]Traps[[/Heading]]
[[Fire Trap|Fire Traps]] and EM traps like [[EM Surge Trap|EM Surge Traps]] can be used to take out the Combat Programmers and M Guards respectively.
[[Heading:3]][[Relay Coupler [Proto]|Prototype Relay Couplers]][[/Heading]]
A [[RIF]] build can assimilate the M Guards with these, although the Combat Programmers are immune.
[[Heading:3]][[Field Lobotomy Kit]][[/Heading]]
The Field Lobotomy Kit can assimilate both Combat Programmers with the cost of 2 charges. They typically make short work of the M Guards afterwards.
[[Heading:2]]Doom Corridor Combat Strategies[[/Heading]]
There are several common Doom Corridor fighting strategies that depend on obtained parts and allies:
[[Image]]Command Doom Corridor MWD.png|Using a Microwarp Drive to lure the Combat Programmers away[[/Image]]
[[Heading:3]]Solo Cogmind[[/Heading]]
If Cogmind is fighting alone, it can be very effective to lure the Combat Programmers out first to kill them before the M Guards arrive. A Microwarp Drive makes this very easy to do. Without a Microwarp Drive, one strategy is to use a long ranged [[Ballistic Cannons|Ballistic Cannon]] to shoot one of the M Guards and then duck into one of the Warlord cubbyholes. The Combat Programmers will run out of AEGIS protection range to fight. With good offensive firepower, the Programmers will be destroyed by the time the M Guards catch up. If not, it is still good to finish them off before moving to the M Guards. Switch over to EM to quickly finish the M Guards. Even a weaker EM weapon like a [[Gamma Rifle]] from a [[P-80 Master]] is more effective at killing M Guards than most other damage types.
[[Image]]Command Doco Warlord Aggro.png|Path to allow Warlord to draw aggro, good with Core Stripper and Disintegrator[[/Image]]
[[Heading:3]]Seal Charge[[/Heading]]
If one or more seals have been activated, there can be a large mass of allies following Cogmind around. If grounded and slow, sometimes there are so many allies that no kind of special maneuvering is possible. In this case, charging down the Corridor is the only real choice. If possible, try to use an Adv. Point Defense or two to keep allies alive as long as possible. This strategy usually results in most or all allies getting destroyed in the fight. If Warlord is present, he will typically be the last ally standing for this type of strategy. In fact, Warlord alone can end up carrying the entire Doom Corridor fight. He has 100% EM resistance so the Combat Programmers can't hurt at all, and he has a massive amount of integrity to tank the M Guards.
One variant of this strategy is to try to sneak around the top of the Corridor with the intention of Warlord or other allies getting spotted first. This will result in the majority of allies getting Launchered out of existence very quickly, but will keep fire off of Cogmind. The tradeoff here is that it is much easier to sneak in with a Core Stripper or Disintegrator and preserve dropped M Guard loot while Cogmind is not the primary focus of the guards. Otherwise, Cogmind rushing in can result in -salvaged M Guards or existing floor loot being destroyed.
[[Image]]Command Doom Corridor Lure Setup.png|CRM Imprint seal Doom Corridor lure setup[[/Image]]
[[Heading:3]]Lure strategy[[/Heading]]
This strategy works best with fast airborne builds and/or with blue CRM-controlled Imprint seals. The general idea is to set up a killzone just outside of the Doom Corridor front doors and lure the guards to that spot. For Imprint, try to separate Experimentals in a way such that multiple Experimentals won't get hit by a single M Guard Launcher hit. If Warlord seals, try to lure the Derelicts back a little ways to give yourself some breathing room before you return. Run or Microwarp in, get the guards to follow you out, then let your allies do their thing. Ideally the M Guards don't make it out until Combat Programmers are dead, and they should suffer the same fate as the Programmers. This works better with a large number of allies, particularly Experimentals or Z-Heavies, and a wide-open area outside of the Doom Corridor. This usually results in much fewer ally casualties due to bots rushing in front of each other and getting in each others' way, blocking LOS and causing missed shots to result in friendly fire. It can be a good idea to hide behind a wall for a bit after luring the guards since they will prioritize Cogmind first and take a while to switch into attacking other hostiles.
[[Heading:3]]Trap strategy[[/Heading]]
This strategy works best with fast airborne builds or tread builds with the Microwarp Drive. Use Fire Traps first to take out the Combat Programmers. 1-2 should result in a heavily disabled or entirely melted down Programmer. A thermal weapon can be used to trigger the full meltdown of a bot in critical range to begin with. After the Programmers are dead, place down any type of EM-damaging or corruption trap. EM Surge Traps work best. 2-3 of these will take down an M Guard alone. Use of a [[Trap Extractors|Trap Extractor]] is helpful to preserve inventory space.
[[Heading:3]]Assimilation strategy[[/Heading]]
Using RIF with Prototype Relay Couplers is an easy way to handle some bots in the Doom Corridor. However, Combat Programmers are immune to all RIF effects, which makes this strategy a little awkward. After taking out the Combat Programmers by whatever means are available, 26 charges of these couplers will assimilate the 2 M Guards.
[[Heading:2]]Accessing MAIN.C[[/Heading]]
MAIN.C is locked behind a very powerful [[Reinforced Walls#command|sealed barrier with 80 armor]]. The Terminal has a high base success rate of 60% but may not always be available. If Cogmind has hit High Security or if the Terminal is blown up while fighting the Doom Corridor, alternative methods must be used to gain entry.
Powerful Thermal weaponry including [[Cld. Nova Cannon]], [[Null Cannon]], [[Potential Cannon]], [[Imp. Potential Cannon]], and [[Core Cannon]] can be used to dig through the center. An high rating reactor explosion from an [[Electromagnetic Launcher]], such as the [[Shock Bomb Launcher]] sometimes available on [[Warlord D3-CKR]], can destroy a few wall tiles at a time. [[Plasma Cutters]] can be used to disassemble the Sealed Barrier as well. Another alternative is to skip through the barrier with a [[Spacefold Activator]], or to dig around it using a [[Matter Drive]], [[LU-1G1's Laser Shovel]], or [[Terrabomb]].

[[Heading]]MAIN.C Strategy[[/Heading]]
After bypassing the Doom Corridor in one way or another, the big boss MAIN.C lies ahead. The [[MAIN.C (Shell)|first form]] is the easier of the two. It is easier to hit, has weaker weapons, lacks some resistances that the second phase has, and has no strict timer. However, the disruption effects on the [[Hpw. Disruptor Cannon|Hpw. Disruptor Cannons]] can be quite annoying, especially for builds that are very close to the support limit or builds with few weapons. Consider [[Dynamic Insulation Systems]] or [[Shieldings]] to protect crucial parts from Disruption.
However, the [[MAIN.C|second phase]] is much scarier. This form deals much more damage, has a 20% blast from the [[Omega Cannon]], gains Thermal and Explosive resistance, becomes much quicker at 34 speed. Most importantly, this form puts Cogmind on a time limit since the Command Garrisons become active. Linger too long and hoards of 0b10 bots will come into the room.
[[Heading:2]]Useful parts vs MAIN.C[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:3]]Strong Kinetic, Entropic, or Vortex weapons[[/Heading]]
Phase two is 75% resistant to Thermal damage and Explosive damage, and 100% EM resistant. That only leaves melee weapons and the aforementioned ranged damage types capable of realistically taking him down. While superweapons or allies can help take him down easily, 4 [[Linear Accelerator|Linear Accelerators]] backed with offensive utilities is enough to win. Some other good weapon choices are: [[Hcl. Linear Accelerator]], [[Multirail]], [[Graviton Cannon]], [[Omega Cannon]], [[Zio. Phaser-H]], [[Zio. Alpha Cannon]], [[Zio. Alpha Cannon Mk. II]], [[Vortex Cannon]], [[Vortex Driver]], [[Vortex Rifle]], [[Vortex Shotgun]], [[Sigix Sheargun]], and [[Sigix Shearcannon]].
[[Heading:3]][[BFG-9k Vortex Edition]][[/Heading]]
This unique weapon deserves a special mention of its own. This will always kill with 2 core hits and even guarantees the kill in one with a single [[Adv. Particle Charger]].
[[Heading:3]][[L-Cannon]][[/Heading]]This weapon is also very unique. The completed L-Cannon is capable of killing MAIN.C in a single hit, and with good aim, can even destroy both phases in a single volley. Due to MAIN.C's fixed location and the L-Cannon's unique infinite range, it is possible to camp out in the corner of the map and destroy phase one safely out of sight. If MAIN.C survives into phase two, Cogmind can just wait around until he comes into range to finish the job.
[[Heading:3]][[Graphene Brace]] (MAIN.C)[[/Heading]]
Phase 2's 20% blast from the Omega Cannon can blast parts off of Cogmind, causing wasted time re-equipping parts or destruction of critical utilities. Graphene brace completely negates this risk.
[[Heading:3]][[Imp. Utility Shielding|Imp.]] or [[Exp. Utility Shielding]][[/Heading]]
These will protect vital utilities and also protect utility parts from getting blasted by phase two.
[[Heading:3]]A strong Launcher[[/Heading]]
while MAIN.C himself is highly resistant to Launchers, the Garrison ARCs can wander into the room and drop a bunch of bots on top of Cogmind. It can be worth swapping to a Launcher to finish off that group before switching back to MAIN.C.
[[Heading:3]]Chance to hit core utilities[[/Heading]]
Specifically, [[Core Analyzers]] and [[Armor Integrity Analyzers]]. Since killing MAIN.C quickly is the highest priority, these utilities are greatly appreciated to cut down time to kill. Killing quicker also has a stacking effect. The less time MAIN.C is alive, the less time he has to regenerate core, and the fewer overall core damage is required.
[[Heading:3]]Kinetic resistance[[/Heading]]
For example, [[Focal Shields]] or kinetic [[Resistance Armor]] like the [[Hvy. Reactive Plating]]. Being able to cut down on the kinetic damage dealt by phase two can help a lot. Hvy. Reactive Plating in particular can be acquired on the map from [[Warlord 4Z-XS3]]
[[Heading:3]]Any Remote [[Datajacks|Datajack]][[/Heading]]
The A7 MAIN.C hack can only be delivered with a manual hack performed with a Datajack.
[[Heading:3]][[Energy Wells]][[/Heading]]
Powering Force Fields or expensive Energy Cannons can require a lot of energy, and storing some in advance is always helpful. Consider pre-dropping energy wells so that energy is available when needed.
[[Heading:3]][[Matter Compressors]] or [[Tractor Beams]][[/Heading]]
Kinetic weapons, especially [[Ballistic Cannons]], can eat through stored matter very quickly. Without a good way to replenish it mid-combat, Cogmind can run out of matter entirely. Phase one will typically drop a large amount of matter that can be gathered mid-combat with a Tractor Beam. Matter Compressors do a good job of storing matter ahead of time. [[Exp. Matter Compressor|Exp. Matter Compressors]] can be looted from M Guards earlier. In a pinch, [[K-01 Serf|K-01 Serfs]] can carry [[Med. Matter Pod|Med. Matter Pods]]
[[Heading:2]]MAIN.C Combat Strategies[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Command Warlord Seal MC Attack.png|Charging MAIN.C with Warlord Cave seal allies[[/Image]]
There are not too many strategies for killing MAIN.C. The majority of the work is going to be in the initial setup and not necessarily in the actual fight. The typical course of action is to step into the room, use the MAIN.C hack (if obtained this run), take a few steps into the room, and [[Siege Mode|siege]] up if wearing Treads. After that just start shooting. Phase one can be destroyed with thermal weapons to preserve matter for Kinetics or integrity for Vortex weaponry. When phase one is almost destroyed, it can be worth pre-switching to the phase two build to ensure minimum delay between phase two summoning the Garrisons and MAIN.C dying.
[[Heading:2]]Post-kill[[/Heading]]
After the kill, a large portion of the 0b10 forces will begin to turn on each other. However, it is not safe yet as both 0b10 factions will still try to fight Cogmind. Grab whatever loot there is from MAIN.C (make sure to grab the [[MAIN.C Data Core]]) and decide what to do next. If Warlord is still alive, getting within line of sight of him will result in a W7 "Establishing Free Derelict Territories" win. Otherwise, there are two main options here:
[[Heading:3]]Hide in the MAIN.C room[[/Heading]]
Digging through the machinery to hide in the corners of the room can avoid getting spotted by the remaining 0b10 forces. This is most effective with a weapon that can dig into the 100 armor Reinforced Barriers around the room. Otherwise, the machinery tends to get destroyed over time and Cogmind will eventually become exposed. Digging and hiding in the walls is a little safer, just be sure not to get caved in on. Either way, just wait out the 600 turns until all of the remaining bots are disabled.
[[Heading:3]]Heading to the left side of Command[[/Heading]]
There are some 0b10 bots wandering around the left side, but much fewer than the ones on the right side. Usually, a little fighting is required to head this way. Hiding out in one of the corners on the left side here is much safer than trying to hide in the corners of the MAIN.C room without being able to properly dig. There is a much smaller chance of wandering bots discovering your hiding spot. The Command cache is a great safe spot to hide in.
If surrounded by a lot of hostiles, one potential strategy is to drop all parts except for the propulsion and try to return later. Core hovering with propulsion armor can be an effective way to escape to left side of Command.
After the bots are disabled, there are two more options to take. Either take one of the surface exits now, or break the Wave Inhibitor machine, loot the map, and teleport to Access_0. If going to Access_0, there is plenty of good loot on the ground or still on unpowered bots. Some of the nicer targets for looting are [[Executioner|Executioners]], [[Alpha 7|Alpha 7s]], [[B-99 Colossus|Colossi]], and both forms of MAIN.C. The Command cache also has plenty of strong prototype parts that will help out.

Other.Name: Strategy/Defeating Superfortress
Other.Content:
[[Image]]Protoforge Superfortress.png|Dormant Superfortress in Protoforge[[/Image]]
[[Superfortress]] in [[Protoforge]] is arguably the strongest robot in the game with powerful offenses that easily out-damage other endgame bosses and a defensive profile including resistances to most common damage types, an efficient [[Exp. Force Field]], near immunity to launchers with the [[Cep. Antimissile System]], and regenerating core integrity and parts. Killing Superfortress is a feat that can only be accomplished by incredible offensive firepower, either through Cogmind's own power or by overwhelming numbers. Even after getting the kill, the punishment includes much more dangerous future floors and an immediate triggering of [[High Security]] unless the UFD assault has begun. Builds should be in peak condition to even consider attempting the kill.

[[Heading]]Overwhelming Firepower[[/Heading]]
There are a few main ways that Cogmind can single-handedly output enough damage to take out Superfortress in a reasonable amount of time. These approaches typically require rare weapons, a difficult to sustain amount of heat dissipation and matter stockpile, and a generally fantastic build.
[[Heading:2]]Triple [[Linked Autogun|Linked Autoguns]][[/Heading]]
Linked Autoguns can be obtained in bulk by killing [[Tracker|Trackers]] after using the [[Data Conduit]]. The [[Cep. Thermoelectric Network]] is ideal to reduce the amount of cooling utilities required to sustain fire, but stacking multiple [[Adv. Coolant Injector|Adv]] or [[Exp. Coolant Injector|Exp. Coolant Injectors]] can work too. 3 of these puts the firing delay at 25 which is the lowest possible value.
[[Heading:2]]Ovr. Weapon Stack[[/Heading]]
Ovr. weapons, especially the top tier [[Ovr. Railgun]], [[Ovr. Quantum Rifle]], [[Ovr. Linear Accelerator]], and [[Ovr. Nova Cannon]], can be easily obtained in bulk from the [[UFD]] bots during the [[Protoforge#w9_defending_0bprimeufd_assault|UFD assault]]. 8 of these will hit the delay cap of 25 delay per volley. Cep. Thermoelectric Network is a required item for this strategy because of the completely unreasonable amount of heat per turn that gets generated (easily over 1000 per turn).
[[Heading:2]][[Scrap Engine]][[/Heading]]The Scrap Engine can be quite unpredictable but very powerful. Larger weapon constructs, especially 4 slot ones, can deal absurd amounts of damage in the mid hundreds range. It is possible to build up a powerful construct before entering the map, although there are a lot of strong parts in Protoforge to help become even more overpowered. Finishing the construct with entropic or vortex damage is the best option due to the lack of resistances, but kinetic damage works reasonably well against Superfortress.
[[Heading:2]]Melee Sneak Attacks[[/Heading]]
While Fortress is [[Protoforge#dormancy|dormant]], it is possible to get free sneak attacks until the 10 turn wake up process is completed. For a powerful weapon with low delay combined with Femtoactuators, this can be a free 10 sneak attacks with no damage returned and no bots summoned. This is best for fast flight builds with a fully fabricated melee kit. Even though 10 turns is often not enough to kill, if Superfortress is brought down to only a few hundred core integrity, it is reasonable to finish the rest of the kill even under fire. While some nice melee parts are available in the lab, the more time spent back there is a higher risk that Cogmind will eventually be reported and lose the sneak attack opportunities. The best weapons for this approach are [[Vortex Lance|Vortex Lances]], [[Exp. Jetlance|Exp. Jetlances]], and the [[Superquantum Companion]].
It is still possible for a peak flight melee build to take out Superfortress while awake. However, doing so is much riskier and will cost a ton of integrity even if successful. Worst case, the build may not be intact enough to escape the map with the imminent High Security.
[[Heading:2]][[BFG-9k Vortex Edition]][[/Heading]]
The BFG deals a huge amount of entropic damage which is one of the few damage types that isn't resisted by Superfortress. The weapon damages itself with use and it has a tendency to tank lots of damage from high coverage, so protecting it with defensive utilities is a must. [[Exp. Weapon Shielding]] can be looted from [[Hotshot|Hotshots]] and is a great choice to keep it alive long enough to secure the kill.
[[Heading:2]][[Vortex Shotgun|Vortex Shotguns]][[/Heading]]
The Vortex Shotgun is another powerful source of Entropic damage. It is much less flashy than the BFG, but easier to support with lower vulnerability and resource costs. Two of these (keeping only one attached at a time) coupled with a [[Quantum Capacitor]] and [[Exp. Target Analyzer]] can deal good damage to Superfortress. With the Target Analyzer, each of the 3 projectiles has a 15% chance to explode an engine, hurting Superfortress as well as any nearby bots that were summoned. While Superfortress has no engines, it can't fire back on Cogmind due to the high energy upkeep of its utilities which can massively cut down on the amount of damage taken during the fight.
[[Heading:2]]Protoforge Kinetics Build[[/Heading]]
It is possible for a more "standard" build to defeat Superfortress without any unique parts or gimmicks, although it will be extremely difficult compared to all other methods. Trying to fight Superfortress "fairly" tends to be a recipe for disaster, but with enough Protoforge parts, it is possible to win single-handedly. The best possible build includes multiple [[Cep. Helical Railcannon|Cep. Helical]] or [[Cep. Heavy Railcannon|Cep. Heavy Railcannons]], at least 4 or more slots worth, with an Exp. Kinecellerator, combined with other standard offensive and defensive combat utilities like [[Core Analyzers]], [[Weapon Cyclers]], and [[Armor Integrity Analyzers]]. Be aware that this will be an uphill battle throughout.

[[Heading]]Overwhelming Numbers[[/Heading]]
There are also strategies that involve use of allies to overwhelm Superfortress instead of only relying on Cogmind's own damage output. Most standard allies are not suitable for this purpose for a few reasons. First and foremost, Superfortress can assemble a variety of launcher if Cogmind has many allies. Most army strategies quickly fall to the top tier launchers that he can assemble, especially the unique [[Gamma Driveblaster]]. A Cep. Antimissile System can mostly negate this downside. The other major downside is the increased assembling rate of Superfortress bots when allies are around. Without adequate firepower, it may quickly turn out that Superfortress's army outnumbers Cogmind's own. Ideal allies are independently strong/tanky, extremely numerous, or bots with Impale criticals to help to lock Superfortress down so that it can't take actions.
[[Heading:2]][[Immortal|Immortals]][[/Heading]]
Immortals have a fast attack rate, high Impale crit rate, and can be assimilated in the map with [[RIF]] by using [[Relay Coupler [Proto]|Proto Relay Couplers]], so they make great choices for allies. 4 Immortals can keep Superfortress from attacking most of the time, and the 5th will typically allow Superfortress to be permanently stunned via impale criticals. Be aware that Superfortress can still assemble bots in this state, so it is not a totally safe kill, especially if the assembled bots start to kill off Immortal allies. Focus on keeping the assembled allies off of the Immortals and they will finish Superfortress off.
[[Heading:2]]Liberated [[K-01 Serf|K-01 Serfs]] (Yes Really)[[/Heading]]
Serfs that are assimilated by [[IN-MT5's Pitchfork "Insurrection"]] will become armed with a [[Shield Trident]], a ranged 100% Impale weapon. While the damage on these weapons are not particularly high, they can permanently lock Superfortress down just like Immortals. 4 or more is recommended to maintain the lockdown. Try to keep as much fire off of the Serfs as possible, as even with the Shield Trident they are still fairly fragile.
[[Heading:2]]UFD Army[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Protoforge Teleported Superfortress.png|Superfortress teleported into the UFD army[[/Image]]
The UFD assault from the event contains numerous strong bots, especially [[Triborg (Optimus)]] and [[Scraphulk|Scraphulks]], and are perfect for eliminating Superfortress. The hardest part is getting them to meet in a favorable position. There are 2 main strategies to use the army against Superfortress:
[[Heading:3]]Superfortress Lure[[/Heading]]
This strategy involves luring Superfortress out of its initial spawn position down to the place where the army pops out in the forge area. Either pop in and out of sight or hit with a long-ranged weapon to continue to retain aggro on Superfortress. This strategy is best performed on a fast airborne build to stay out of weapons range most of the time. After Superfortress is near position, initiate the event at a Recycling Unit.
[[Heading:3]][[Supercharged TR]][[/Heading]]
By using a [[Dimensional Node Initializer]] with a Supercharged TR, Superfortress can be brought to the center of the forge where the assault is happening. Plant the Node close to the incursion point at the bottom right of the map, engage the event, and then rush over to Superfortress. If Cogmind is fast enough, the teleport will leave Superfortress surrounded by the initial assault of UFD bots. This strategy is most effective with high UFD readiness.
[[Heading:2]]Fabricated Army[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Protoforge Fabricated Army.png|Reasonably sized fabricated army of Hunters and Duelists (10 Authchips)[[/Image]]
Fabricating a bot army is a relatively difficult strategy to pull off. For optimal results, Superfortress must stay dormant for the entire process so that all fabricated bots can be adjusted into position before starting the fight. If the bot army has to approach an awake Superfortress, there is little chance of success since bots will only slowly trickle into range. For this reason, a Jamming Amplifier is highly recommended to avoid any jamming failures.
There are 4 level 3 [[Fabricator|Fabricators]] in the forge section of the map that can allow for very rapid fabrication with a lot of [[Authchip [R/Combat]]]. The [[H-88 Terminator]] is arguably the best bot to fabricate for the Superfortress kill due to its high core integrity, damage output, and evasion. A few [[L-61 Swordsman|L-61 Swordsmen]] are also a good addition thanks to their high damage output that isn't resisted, although only a limited amount of melee bots can fit around Superfortress, so there is a practical limit to them.

[[Heading]]Other Useful Items[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:2]][[Cep. Rapid Grenade Launcher]][[/Heading]]
While not capable of taking down Superfortress single-handedly, this part deserves a special mention. Most kill strategies will take long enough for Superfortress to assemble an army of bots that will wear Cogmind down. The Cep. Antimissile System prevents easy launchering of the growing army. However, the Cep. Rapid Grenade Launcher's unique effect bypasses this part, making it one of the few ways to quickly take out a group of Superfortress-assembled bots at once.

[[Heading:2]][[PL-3XN's Obliterator]][[/Heading]]
The Obliterator is another weapon that is worth mentioning independently. While it has high damage, its limited number of shots and very high matter cost makes it unsuitable for a full kill. Still, its ability to rip components off of any target makes it very valuable for nearly all kill strategies. The only parts that the Obliterator will fail to rip off are the [[Exp. Heavy Siege Treads]], [[Centrium Heavy Armor Plating]], and any 2-slot weapons that happen to be assembled. It rips off all power and all defensive utilities each time it is fired, dramatically reducing Superfortress's offensive and defensive capabilities. Its secondary instant-kill effect can also clear up any assembled hostile bots nearby.

[[Heading]]Escaping the Map[[/Heading]]
After Superfortress is dead, there is still the remaining issue of leaving the map in one piece. Unless the UFD assault has begun, High Security will begin to activate as Superfortress dies. The ideal strategy in this case is a Dimensional Node Initializer placed near the exit. Airborne builds can usually make it to the exit before the first wave of assaults spawn due to their high speed. For grounded builds without these options, be prepared to fight through multiple waves of High Security while heading to the exit. [[Sterilization]] not being an option on this map means that there is no possibility to siege up and fight until the end.

Other.Name: Strategy/Extension
Other.Content:
[[Image]]Extension Guide Route.png|Recommended path through Extension[[/Image]]
[[Extension]] is a straightforward map with little variation between runs. The typical strategy is a fairly simple one:
[[List:Ordered]]
From the spawn location, take the path to the top-left of the map. Travel along the right and destroy any hostiles. Rewiring and freeing bots in cells is an option at this point, but it is usually better to wait to do this to keep [[Alert]] lower and to preserve ally integrity for the center fight.|
Once reaching the middle of the map vertically, head back to the beginning area rather than continuing down. The 1 tile corridor tends to get too congested and favors the [[0b10]] defenders there. Free or rewire any remaining allies along the way, then take the army and charge into the center of the map from below. Here, the open corridor allows for better lines of fire for the army.|
Assuming the fight went reasonably well at this point, the remainder of the map should be a breeze to run through. Free and rewire any allies on the top right of the map and then head down to the exit.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Extension Dig[[/Heading]]
One alternative to fighting through the center of the map is to dig across through the top. This is typically a 10 tile dig, which has a reasonable risk of cave-ins occurring. If there were few allies gained or they were destroyed, or if Cogmind's offensive ability is very low, this alternative route may be preferable. Beware [[cave-ins]] this way.

Other.Name: Strategy/Hub_04(d)
Other.Content:
Blowing up Network Hubs in [[Hub_04(d)]] can be very valuable to the run thanks to the huge defensive hacking bonuses provided. However, destroying one as soon as you see one by shooting immediately is usually a bad idea. Shooting them directly causes a ton of [[Alert]] around the order of several hundred due to their large destructive radius. The [[Lightning]] squads that follow can also be very scary for an unprepared Cogmind. It is often a better idea to blow up the Hubs from a distance, especially when right next to exit.

[[Heading]]Explosion Methods[[/Heading]]
There are a lot of methods to blow up Network Hubs that do not trigger the alert gain:
[[Heading:2]]Hostile attack[[/Heading]]
If a bot stands in front of a Network Hub and an [[0b10]]-aligned bot misses into it, the destruction will be associated with that bot and not Cogmind. This works especially well with allies and drones. Position the ally in front of a Hub and attacking enemies can shoot around or through them to trigger the explosion. The Lightning [[EMDS]] has a 100% penetration, so any allies standing in front of a Hub is sure to get it to explode.
[[Heading:2]][[Traps|Trap]] explosion[[/Heading]]
Traps never assign Alert to Cogmind unless manually triggering the trap. Any explosive or area EM traps will work, [[I]]but[[/I]] if the trap triggers due to Cogmind's [[Corruption]] then the alert isn't assigned, which can be used to avoid the alert. For example, plant a [[Dirty Bomb]] trap and then walk back and forth over it. Eventually, this will trigger the trap to explode.
[[Heading:2]][[Plasma Cutter|Regular]] or [[Imp. Plasma Cutter]][[/Heading]]
Plasma Cutters can destroy explosive machines like Hubs without triggering the explosion. This can be nice for for Cogmind to avoid being caught out in the open in a bad defensive position. Because the majority of the Alert gained from destroying a Hub is from the explosion, this will reduce the typical several hundred Alert gain down to just 15.
[[Heading:2]]Force(Sabotage)[[/Heading]]
If successful, this hack will blow up a random explosive machine on the map. Network Hubs are the only available targets in this map, so this will always hit a Hub if successful. However, this hack is inconsistent and may fail multiple times in a row. It does cause an Alert gain of 50 if successful, but it is substantially less than the several hundred of a manually-blown Network Hub. Note: unlike this hack, Trojan(Detonate) does cause Alert to go up from the Explosion and is not a great hack to use.

[[Heading]]Lightning[[/Heading]]
4 squads of these will appear after blowing up any Hubs. They can be defeated with combat or evaded.
[[Heading:2]]Combat[[/Heading]]
The best way to deal with the Lightning squads is to use critical destroy weapons as they lack any critical immunity. [[8R-AWN's Boregun]], [[Adv. KE Penetrator]], or [[Hyp. Weapons]] work well. [[Damper Plating]] works great at reducing damage taken by Lightnings to negligible amounts. The [[Exp. EM Shield]] that they carry is a lot less effective than Damper Plating, but is still a substantial reduction and only costs 1 slot.
[[Heading:2]]Evasion[[/Heading]]
Lightning have Scan Cloak 5 which makes them entirely undetectable by [[Sensor Arrays]]. However, there are still some methods that can be used to track them:
[[List]]
Sensor Arrays can still track the [[I-47|Archangel]] that follows the squads around|
[[Seismic Detector]]|
[[FarCom]]|
[[IFF Parser]]
[[GameText]]Trojan(Track)[[/GameText]] at [[Terminal|Terminals]]
[[/List]]

Other.Name: Strategy/Looting Protoforge
Other.Content:
While [[Protoforge]] contains a staggering array of high powered parts, collecting all of them is one of the most difficult challenges in the game. There are many ways for things to go wrong on the map. If they do, the layout of the map is highly unforgiving, and an emergency escape may not always be possible. Combat builds may run into issues like taking lots of damage getting past [[Superfortress]], being forced to fight every bot in the back area leading to [[Alert]] or attrition issues, and getting scanned by [[Researcher|Researchers]]. Stealthier builds, especially [[Flight Units|Flight]] builds, can find it difficult to take the many powerful [[Prototype Robot|Prototype Robots]] in combat, to lose bots due to the lack of escape options in the map layout, and can often get stuck in stasis traps in a bad position.
[[Heading]]Getting In and Out[[/Heading]]
The first two questions to consider when entering Protoforge are the following: How will I get into the back where all the good loot is? How will I get back out? While stealthing past a dormant Superfortress is ideal, this is not always a viable approach for every build. Fully safe stealthing requires a specific and energy-intensive set of [[Infowar]], and bad [[Operator]] placement can always wake up Superfortress even for the most well prepared build. Additionally, once inside, there are jamming-immune [[V-Series]] that will always wake Superfortress. There are a few main strategies available here:
[[Heading:2]]Stealthing Past Superfortress[[/Heading]]
Stealthing past dormant Superfortress can be somewhat consistently achieved with either of 2 sets of specific utilities. An [[Adv. Transmission Jammer]] or better combined with an [[Adv. Cloaking Device]] or better will reduce the visual range of most bots in the starting area down to the jamming range, with the exception of the [[Overlord]] which can be usually be seen ahead of time due to its [[Exp. Active Sensor Suite]]. However, due to a quirk in line of sight calculation, a [[Visual Processing Units|Visual Processing Unit]] must be used in order to jam [[Watcher|Watchers]] at 16 tiles. Otherwise, Watchers can see Cogmind at 16 tiles but Cogmind cannot see them back, so the jammer does not apply. The other approach is an [[Adv. Visual Processing Unit]] or better combined with an [[Exp. Transmission Jammer]], although this approach is a little more likely to run into the Overlord. [[Transmission Jammers]] do have a chance to fail which will result in Superfortress powering up anyway, although this chance can be eliminated with a Jamming Amplifier. As previously mentioned, an Operator can also still make it to a [[Terminal]] and report Cogmind when turning a corner. Some form of bot detection like [[Sensor Arrays]] is always helpful to avoid unnecessary combat and risk of jammer failure.
Due to jamming-immune bots inside the back lab area, a full stealth entry and exit is unlikely to happen. Another method will typically be required to exit the map.
[[Heading:2]]Digging Around Superfortress[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Protoforge Dig 1.png|Digging from the top left room[[/Image]]
[[Image]]Protoforge Dig 2.png|Digging from the Superfortress hallway[[/Image]]
Digging around Superfortress is a consistent strategy that is generally preferable for grounded combat builds and less so for airborne builds because [[Cave-ins]] tend to be much more dangerous for more fragile airborne builds. This strategy involves getting a strong enough digging weapon or other digging utility to bypass the standard Superfortress-guarded opening. The downsides of this approach are the potential for multiple cave-ins and the summoning of 2 additional patrols to the map once the reinforced barrier is breached. However, for most combat builds, this solution can be safer than running all of the way past Superfortress.
When performing the dig, ideally the path should be at least 2 tiles wide to avoid having to continue shooting while already in the dug out tiles in case one of the tiles collapses while walking past it. There are two best digging spots, although one is seed-dependent. The ideal digging spot is from the top left of the map. Occasionally, the map will create a room that is very close to the bottom left prototype vault. Digging from that location can be quite short, although it is not guaranteed to be there. The next best spot is to dig from the Superfortress hallway up into the Garrison room above.
[[Heading:4]]List of Parts That Can Dig[[/Heading]]
Note: Some parts like [[Scrap Engine]] weapon constructs can sometimes dig these walls, and other parts may be able to dig when paired with damage boosting utilities like [[Force Boosters]] and [[Particle Chargers]].
[[List]]
[[Cld. Nova Cannon]]|
[[Core Cannon]]|
[[Electromagnetic Launchers]] or [[PSU Rigger]] exploding an engine on the ground|
[[Mak. Laser Shovel|Mak]] or [[LU-1G1's Laser Shovel]]|
[[Matter Drive]]|
[[Molecular Deconstructor]]|
[[Null Cannon]]|
[[Potential Cannon|Regular]] or [[Imp. Potential Cannon]]|
[[Terrabomb]]|
[[Vortex Driver]]
[[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]Teleporting past Superfortress[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Protoforge Navigation Harness.png|Possible Cep. Navigation Harness teleport paths[[/Image]]
A few special items can allow for teleporting past Superfortress. Typical [[Transdimensional Reconstructor|Regular]] and [[Hpw. Transdimensional Reconstructor|Hpw. Transdimensional Reconstructors]] can be unreliable for getting inside the lab, but there are alternate approaches to teleporting. The [[Personal Teleporter v0.10]] and [[Telecube]] both allow directional teleportation past Superfortress, albeit with a cost of random part loss.
For exiting the map, Transdimensional Reconstructors can really shine. A [[Dimensional Node Initializer]] placed near the exit will make for an easy escape route while deep in the lab. In fact, this is the best strategy for exiting the map due to the low cost and risk of the approach. There is even a spare Transdimensional Reconstructor available inside the [[Tinkerer]] lab for this use, although the Dimensional Node Initializer must be carried in from [[Quarantine]] or [[Caves]].
Another solution for teleporting out of the map is also contained within the Tinkerer lab. The [[Cep. Navigation Harness]] is difficult to use correctly, but can be used to jump outside of the lab, bypassing Superfortress. Cogmind can influence the teleport direction by making continuous moves in the same direction. Since this part's teleport works through walls, it can be used to bypass large portions of the level that would otherwise require a longer unfavorable route or digging.
[[Heading:2]]Walking Past Superfortress[[/Heading]]
Walking past an awake Superfortress can be a dangerous proposition, but sometimes is a necessity. Airborne builds, especially with overloadable propulsion, can get by with only a few volleys sent their way. However, grounded builds will take substantially more damage trying to do this. Evasion parts like [[Phase Shifters]], [[Reaction Control Systems]], and [[Thunder Leg|Regular]] or [[Imp. Thunder Leg|Imp. Thunder Legs]] can help reduce damage taken greatly.
After Superfortress has been bypassed, keep running and don't stop to fight any bots following or else there is a risk that Superfortress will catch up and reset its 20 action memory. The best place to go after running past Superfortress to enter the back lab is into the Garrison room, out of sight. When leaving, keep going to the corner where the corridor turns back downward again.
[[Heading:2]]Exiting Through the Garrison[[/Heading]]
While it is often desirable to close the [[Garrison Access]] to avoid prototype reinforcements, there is always the option to leave through it instead. Research [[Garrison|Garrisons]] are quite tough and can add lots of Alert, although this option may be more preferable for [[RIF]] builds.
[[Heading]]Propulsion Choice[[/Heading]]
While all propulsion types can be used to loot Protoforge, [[Hover Units|Hover]] and [[Legs]] are generally the best suited for the job. [[Treads]] have a major integrity issue in the map, with only one rarely spawning type of propulsion available in the propulsion vault ([[Exp. Heavy Siege Treads]]). Treads players should expect to bring multiple backup treads into the map or switch to a different propulsion type later. Flight has more types of propulsion available, but it struggles heavily to be both combat capable to take out the prototype guards and have enough storage to take out as many parts as it wants to. [[Wheels]] are generally niche already, and the lack of good wheels on the map doesn't help the issue.
Legs and Hover serve as ideal mid-ground propulsion types. They have plentiful high integrity multi-slot parts available in the propulsion vault and have good support and carrying capacity. They both also make great use of the [[Cep. Antigrav Storage Unit]], something that treads doesn't need and flight struggles to support at times. Additionally, both legs and hover have high-rating drop from some of the common guards. Legs are dropped by [[AP7-3|AP7-3s]], [[Hotshot|Hotshots]], and [[Immortal|Immortals]], while Hover is dropped by V-Series.
[[Heading]]Looting the Lab Area[[/Heading]]
After successfully infiltrating the lab, it's time to begin collecting loot.
[[Heading:2]]Helpful Looting Items[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
[[Crosscalibrator]]: Many of the prototype parts in the lab are faulty but appear in multiples. Any part that has multiple copies can be fixed by the Crosscalibrator. A [[Subatomic Replicator]] can duplicate a rare faulty part to create two good parts.|
[[Plexus Tether]]: The Plexus Tether will identify all prototype parts on the map with the downside of summoning a Decapitator squad if the Garrison is open. If the Garrison is shut, however, this intel is completely free.|
[[Graphene Brace]]: Decapitators and Immortals have scary high critical effect percentage weapons, inflicting sever and impale respectively.|
Transmission Jammers: Jamming the dormant guards in each area can allow for picking them off one at a time instead of all at once.|
Powerful Digging Items: Digging through the walls of the map can allow for getting into vaults without being spotted by Researchers. The Cep. Plasma Driver located on the map is a good choice. A [[Warp Cannon]], while unable to dig, can serve a similar purpose by shooting around walls.|
[[Cloaking Devices]]: Cloaking serves dual purposes. One benefit is to allow firing in rooms where Researchers are present without getting spotted. Another is to see patrols roaming the lab area before they see Cogmind. [[Visual Processing Units]] can help provide the same benefit, but don't help in opening vaults like Cloaking does.|
[[Relay Coupler [NC]]]: Relay Couplers have multiple useful Researcher hacks. They can disable scanning functionality, assimilate Researchers to identify picked up prototypes, and identify all prototypes nearby instantly. A similar Researcher-disabling effect can be obtained at the Research Penetration Think tank in Scraptown.|
[[Phasing AFG]]: This part can grab loot stuck in bad positions, sometimes being able to bypass dormant guards or unfortunately-positioned Researchers.|
Plenty of backups: Due to the inconsistent placement of different vault types in the lab and the lack of normal parts on the ground, backups of essential parts are very valuable since they may show up as the last vault checked.[[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]Exploration Order[[/Heading]]
The typical route to explore the Protoforge is to head to the left side first. This allows for shutting down or destroying the Garrison Access, grabbing the Crosscalibrator, and getting the prototype IDs from the Forge Research Registry Terminal early into the map. If the Garrison is shut down or destroyed, the Plexus Tether should be used right away to minimize time spent searching for useful parts. After that, plan out which rooms are worth going into and which aren't. While it's possible to loot every vault, doing this tends to be rougher on alert and build attrition.
After leaving the left side, stick to the top of the corridor that leads back to Superfortress. The path is just wide enough to allow traversal without getting spotted. After hitting up the standard vaults on the right side, there are two more decisions to make. Are the guarded vault and Tinkerer lab worth hitting up? The guarded vault has some of the most powerful loot on the map but is also the most heavily guarded with 2 AP7-3s. The Tinkerer lab parts are not so powerful, but the Cep. Navigation Harness and Transdimensional Reconstructor can be used as ways out of the map. These parts can help avoid the extra patrols that will be summoned after entering the Tinkerer lab.
[[Heading:2]]Triggering the [[Protoforge#w9_defending_0bprimeufd_assault|UFD Assault]] Before the Lab[[/Heading]]
It is possible and sometimes even desirable to trigger the [[UFD]] assault on Protoforge before looting the Lab, even if not planning to complete the event itself. Doing this has several advantages and disadvantages. This will stop the dispatch of all [[Extermination Squad|Exterminations]], [[Assault Squad|Assaults]], and even prevent [[High Security]] from occurring. Even if the UFD readiness is low, the allies can be used as distractions and sources of looting parts like [[CPS Tube|CPS Tubes]] and [[Mak. Salvage Targeting Computer|Mak. Salvage Targeting Computers]]. The tradeoff of this decision is a much more difficult Access and [[Command]] with advanced fortification protocols activated. Additionally, it may be difficult to sneak to the exit with all of the event assaults roaming around the map.

Other.Name: Strategy/W8 Fortifying 0b10
Other.Content:
After defeating [[MAIN.C (Shell)]] in [[Command]], the [[Command#w8_fortifying_0b10surrender|surrender option]] may be selected instead of continuing to fight MAIN.C. A [[Core Reset Matrix]] or being [[Warlord (Alignment)|Warlord aligned]] while [[Warlord]] is alive will prevent this option from being selected.
Cogmind, MAIN.C, and the newly allied [[0b10]] bots must face off against waves of [[Enhanced Q-Series]]. These bots are mostly randomized, but there are some common qualities to them. They all have [[Adv. Dynamic Insulation System|Adv. Dynamic Insulation Systems]] which makes EM damage not a very reliable way to kill. They typically have another damage resistance utility or armor, although Kinetic and Thermal damage is usually effective. A 4+ [[Ballistic Cannons]] or [[Multirail]] stack is a good set to deal a lot of damage to these bots. The overall build requirements tend not to be too strict here. Cogmind does need to be able to put out a decent amount of damage and manage to keep a build well intact from backup parts and from Q-Series or 0b10 bot loot. MAIN.C does have a tendency to wander off and get overwhelmed at times, so try to keep up with him.
One consideration when doing this event is whether or not to go to the cache. Since Cogmind only gets 100 moves and about 40 more turns after that, it may be worth calculating the path ahead of time. If MAIN.C gets overwhelmed in the first fight, single-handedly fighting a large group of Q-Series, the event can end in failure right at the very beginning. A [[Microwarp Drive]] can help greatly here since one warp only counts as one move for the purposes of the counter.

[[Heading]]Useful parts vs. Enhanced Q-Series[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:2]][[Point Defense Systems]][[/Heading]]
Some of the Enhanced Q-Series carry powerful [[Launchers]] that are blocked by this utility.
[[Heading:2]][[Tractor Beams]][[/Heading]]
There aren't typically a lot of turns to spend running around collecting matter in this event. Being able to restock remotely can help save a lot of time and damage dealt to Cogmind.
[[Heading:2]][[Matter Compressors]]/[[Energy Wells]][[/Heading]]
Resource storage is always useful in extended combat encounters like this.
[[Heading:2]][[Launchers]][[/Heading]]
While these should be used sparingly to avoid friendly 0b10 fire that can trigger an accidental betrayal, sometimes large groups of Enhanced Q-Series will wander into the MAIN.C room at about the same time. It is very nice to be able to attack these groups simultaneously.
[[Heading:2]][[Phasing AFG]]/[[Portable AFG]][[/Heading]]
Drawing loot piles closer to Cogmind can also save a lot of otherwise wasted time trying to travel a long distance to get some good loot.

Other.Name: Strategy/W9 Defending 0bPrime
Other.Content:
Assisting the [[UFD]] forces in their [[Protoforge]] assault is a task that is initially extremely challenging but can be made much easier with lots of preparation. The minimal readiness UFD will be utterly annihilated by [[0b10]] forces, leaving Cogmind up against a huge amount of bots with little assistance. On the other hand, the maximal readiness UFD can put up a solid fight against 0b10 and can even win fights well enough to plant multiple [[UFD Drillbomb|UFD Drillbombs]]. The ideal scenario is to have at least 120 Fedlink [[UFD#resource_mechanics|resources]] when beginning the event and to avoid the civil war in [[Scraptown]] which would otherwise weaken the UFD forces.

[[Heading]]Primary Strategies[[/Heading]]
There are two main strategies for this event: Stealth based and combat based.
[[Heading:2]]Stealth Bombing[[/Heading]]
Stealth is the easier option of the two to beat the event. With maximal UFD forces, Cogmind has to do little to no fighting in order to help complete the event. Instead, focus on remaining out of sight and planting Drillbombs. However, helping out the UFD forces here and there with launchers, especially guided ones like a [[Mni. Smartbomb Launcher]], can be an easy way to help out the UFD without risking too much damage. [[Flight Units|Flight]] is the ideal propulsion type for stealth thanks to its high speed, allowing for easily sneaking to Drillbomb planting locations and retreating back to friendly bots when caught in a bad position. [[Hover Units|Hover]] is still a good option since it tends to be more capable of taking on fights when needed. The lack of inventory is one of the biggest issues for flight, with a [[Med. Storage Unit]] being required to carry a single Drillbomb without any backups available. However, thanks to the massive number of Strikers that appear during this event, there will always be spare flight units.
Although rather slow, [[Impulse Thruster Array|Impulse Thruster Arrays]] have good support and integrity. Hover is much worse off here, as the only dropped hover propulsion, [[Imp. Antigrav System|Imp. Antigrav Systems]], from [[P-80 Master|P-80 Masters]] is not very impressive. The lab area has plenty of great hover units to stock up on before or during the event as needed.
[[Heading:2]]Combat[[/Heading]]
Heavy combat builds are also more than capable of completing the event, even at lower UFD resource levels. One major boon to combat builds is the amount of loot and matter generated from the attack. It's very difficult to run out of crucial build elements like power, propulsion, and weapons, although the choice of parts may not always be the most desirable. Combat builds can choose between helping out with some Drillbomb planting or fully committing fighting the 0b10 waves. If Cogmind can fight up to the exit, camping nearby and using launchers at each new 0b10 wave can be a very effective strategy.
Mass Executioner spawns guarantee a limitless supply of good offensive processors. Their [[Adv. Kinecellerator|Adv. Kinecellerators]] are also a good option for any kinetic builds. They pair well with the [[Helical Railgun|Helical Railguns]] dropped by Executioners and Ovr. weaponry dropped by the [[Scrapoid|Scrapoids]] and [[Scraphulk|Scraphulks]]. While some [[Ovr. Medium Treads]] are available from Elites, they are not all that good for the depth, so it can be problematic to restock on [[Treads]]. [[Wheel|Wheels]] builds can get the [[Ovr. Huge Scrapsphere]] from Scrapoids. [[Legs]] builds have the best options available between [[Enh. Biometal Leg|Enh. Biometal Legs]] from Executioners and [[Ovr. Armored Exoskeleton|Ovr. Armored Exoskeletons]] from Scraphulks.

[[Heading]]General Strategies[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Protoforge Alternate Dig Path.png|A good alternate path to dig out of the Protoforge area[[/Image]]
[[Heading:2]]Eliminate the [[Garrison Access]][[/Heading]]
The [[Prototype Robot|Prototype Robots]] spit out from the Garrison can be a nuisance to the UFD forces. While they are not as numerous as the main [[Assault Squad|Assault]] forces, they are additional dispatches that tend to be tougher than usual bots. Shutting down or destroying the Garrison before starting the event begins is a good idea. While technically possible to do after starting the assault, running down the [[Superfortress]] hallway to shut the Garrison is pretty risky.
[[Heading:2]]Dig to Improve UFD Routing[[/Heading]]
The layout of the left part of the forge area can be quite variable from run to run. Sometimes there are multiple great routes for planting Drillbombs without having to fight off many 0b10 forces. Sometimes the map ends in a giant single hallway chokepoint where it is nearly impossible for the UFD to make any progress. Don't be afraid of digging tunnels to create alternate routes to sneak past enemy forces. Being able to dig through the Forge [[Reinforced Walls#protoforge|Reinforced Barriers (80 armor)]] is often useful since the rooms on the left side tend to back up against the Forge in multiple locations other than just the entrance.
[[Heading:2]][[Launchers|Launcher]] It Up[[/Heading]]
Don't shy away from using Launchers during the event. Launchers are always a good tool against large groups of enemies, but some of their downsides costs are high [[Matter]] use and [[Alert]] generation. During the event, there is so much matter generated that it's impossible to ever run out. Alert during the event is irrelevant and will not cause any additional responses. Keep in mind that alert will still travel to the next map if planning to exit through the main exit instead of taking the win.
[[Heading:2]]Useful Event Items[[/Heading]]
[[List]][[Cloaking Devices]]: Help traverse the map and plant Drillbombs without being spotted. [[Cep. Cloak Mesh]] is available on the map in the lab area.|
Digging parts: Digging parts strong enough to dig through the Forge Plexus area Reinforced Barriers are highly useful for getting around a chokepoint.|
Good Launchers: Protoforge Launchers in particular are some of the most powerful options in the game and can easily wipe out squads to turn the tide in favor of the UFD forces.|[[Active Sensor Suite|Regular]] or [[Exp. Active Sensor Suite]]: The [[Investigation Squad|investigation]]-summoning effect of this part is not active during the event, leaving only the upside of powerful, long ranged and unjammable sensors.[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Loot the Lab?[[/Heading]]
The back lab area of the map can provide lots of good items but may not always be worth going for. With a good build going into the map, there is a chance that going to the lab leads to losing the build instead of improving it. If alert is an issue, consider how likely it is that High Security will trigger before leaving, which will lock the event out altogether and possibly even kill the run.
If going into the lab, the other question is when? Going in before the event is a little safer since there aren't going to be any assaults wandering through the Superfortress hallway or prototypes dispatched from the Garrison, and there is the possibility that Superfortress is still dormant. After the event is begun, getting back there is more challenging, but at least there won't be any [[Extermination Squad|Extermination]] or [[Assault Squad|Assault Squads]] dispatched to the back of the lab. Depending on the UFD readiness, spending an extended amount of time in the lab can result in the UFD forces becoming overrun.

Other.Name: Strategy/Wastes
Other.Content:
[[Wastes]] is a very dangerous [[0b10]] map that can easily demolish slower builds with [[C-40 Crusher|Crushers]]. Airborne builds have a fairly easy time escaping this map, but grounded builds will need a plan to escape intact.

[[Heading]]Airborne builds[[/Heading]]
If Cogmind is airborne there are lots of options available. Beelining for the exit is a good strategy when allies aren't wanted or if the EMP is on. If the EMP is off, there are most likely allies on the map. Search for [[Derelict]] allies in the larger square openings on the top and bottom of the map where they can appear. They can usually take out all of the Crushers unaided. Fast speed can also allow easy kiting of Crushers around the map. Crushers do not have the most intelligent movement and can often be baited to moving to one side of the corridor. After this, quickly cross to the other side and pass out of reach. Circling back may be needed to avoid groups of Crushers.

[[Heading]]Grounded Builds[[/Heading]]
Dealing with Crushers on slower builds is a much more daunting task. Crushers are slow moving but incredibly tanky and difficult to kill through conventional means. The high integrity of [[Damper Plating]] and low core exposure of only 15% makes kills inconsistent. One good strategy to kill them are critical destroy weapons such as a [[8R-AWN's Boregun]] and [[Hyp. Weapons]]. While the armor can't be destroyed with a crit, the core and compactor exposure are about 23% combined, and getting a single critical hit will either kill or disarm the Crusher immediately. To avoid corruption when the EMP is on, put on a [[Damper Plating]] and/or a [[Dynamic Insulation System]] as soon as possible after killing a Crusher. Another strategy is a meltdown build. 3 or more thermal guns can overheat the Crushers and cause them to melt.
[[Image]]Wastes Crusher Lure.png|Crusher loop strategy[[/Image]]Fighting Crushers head on without enough firepower can usually result in essential parts of the build getting crushed onto the floor. One way to reduce the risk is to fight the Crushers in a circle around the starting corner of the map. Dig a tunnel around the starting area and shoot Crushers through it like the image on the right. Crushers are forced to take the long path around, giving plenty of time to get free shots off. However, this technique is a little risky as it is possible to get totally surrounded by multiple Crushers.
Sometimes the best option is simply to detach all parts and make a run for it. If the EMP is off, dropping parts in the corner of the map preemptively is a good idea. If the Derelict allies are on the map, they can clear out most of the Crushers for you so you can go back and pick up your parts later. Even if there are no allies around, being able to pick the parts that you want to take is a lot better than having all your parts crushed and being stuck with potentially only junk.

[[Heading]][[RIF]][[/Heading]]
Using RIF along with a [[Datajacks|Datajack]] and [[Relay Coupler [NC]|NC Couplers]] makes each Crusher non-hostile for 3 charges a pieces. This makes the Crushers trivial to loot for maximum salvage, although the EMP can still make the process be quite annoying. Since there are 6 Crushers, the total cost is 18 charges for the whole map. Ramming these bots when neutralized this way is safe to do if running low on matter.

Other.Name: Strategy/Zion Deep Caves
Other.Content:
[[Zion Deep Caves]] is an optional challenge [[Branch]] that serves as a series of checklists. Each section of the map plays out in a similar way each time, and there are some requirements to deal with them in a consistent way. Here is a general checklist of things that will be useful throughout the map:
[[List]]
Propulsion/Weapon/Armor + backups: Lots of fighting is required in this map. Having backups of these more important parts will keep the build in fighting shape.|
[[Launchers]]: These can be used for the [[Z-Imprinter]], [[Z-Light (5)|Z-Lights]], and especially for the [[Assembled]] in the wall. Multiple backups are recommended.|
[[Electromagnetic Weapons]]: EM is the only effective way to fight [[Golem|Golems]]. EM traps like [[EM Surge Trap|EM Surge]] or [[Dirty Bomb Trap|Dirty Bombs]] can also be used, but having at least 1 EM weapon is best to be safe.|
(Optional) [[AS-neutralizer No. 17b]]: Completely neutralizes the threat of the Assembled wall.|
(Optional) Allies: Make the opening Z-Imprinter fight much easier to handle. [[A8]]'s grunt code (used at the [[Terminal]] at the entrance to the deep caves) and various friendly Zion bots make great allies.|
(Optional) Dead [[Imprinter]]: Killing the Imprinter in Zion prevents her from showing up in this map. She has no weapons in Zion so taking her out there can be an easy way to skip a big threat on this map.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Starting Area[[/Heading:2]]
There isn't much threat here. There can be groups of 3 Assembled that can be easily dispatched by any weapons, although Launchers are most effective.
[[Image]]ZDC Allies.png|Fighting the Z-Imprinter with allies[[/Image]][[Image]]ZDC Imprinter Launcher.png|Aiming past the Imprinter with a Launcher[[/Image]]

[[Heading]]Z-Imprinter[[/Heading]]
After entering the main open area of the map, the Z-Imprinter will spawn and head directly to Cogmind's location. 2 Z-Lights will follow the Imprinter but are much slower and will take some time to arrive. The Z-Imprinter has high evasion, 150 core integrity, and deals a large amount of damage every volley. Allies are highly recommended for this fight to help destroy her quicker and to draw fire from you. A [[Tactical Coordination Suite]] can really help out with an ally damage. [[Ranged Targeting Utilities]] or 2-slot Treads with [[Siege Mode]] are also recommended to be able to hit the Imprinter more frequently.
For Cogmind's build, any non-EM and non-Impact damage types will work. To get the [[Zio. Metafield Generator]], +Salvage is recommended by using guns with the best available type of [[Salvage Targeting Computers|Salvage Targeting Computer]]. Although it doesn't deal much damage, EM can be used to apply +Salvage if allies are providing enough damage output otherwise. If salvage isn't needed, using [[Explosive Launchers]] will be very effective here. Rather than aiming directly at the Imprinter, aim the launcher at a wall or at the end of its range so that the Imprinter is still hit close to the source. This will maintain a high accuracy while still dealing the bulk of the damage to the Imprinter. This technique can also be used against the Z-Lights to good effect.
After the Z-Imprinter is dead, take care that your allies don't spot the Z-Technicians by the Z-Power machine. They will almost assuredly miss into the machine and end up nuking themselves, and if you're not careful, Cogmind. Beware its large 15 tile radius.
[[Heading]]Z-Light Guards[[/Heading]]The top and bottom of the map have groups of 3 Z-Light guards. There are 2 groups on the top and one on the bottom. All of these are optional encounters. To avoid them, dig through the center of the Z-Facility and hang near the left side of the area. Enter the tunnel near the top side to avoid getting spotted by the bottom group. However, the top Z-Lights are often worth fighting because of the large number of special Zionite parts they guard. It is possible to reach the first alcove on the top right without getting spotted, but the remainder are all guarded
If Cogmind still has strong allies like Enhanced Grunts alive from the Z-Light encounter, it is possible to just charge in and fight them all at once. They are not as dangerous as the Z-Imprinter, but in large numbers they can still pack a large punch. Using Launchers is very effective on these bots since despite their evasion, they have relatively low core integrity. Using a [[Transmission Jammers|Transmission Jammer]] to lure them 1 at a time can also be an effective strategy if fighting with non-launcher weapons to preserve salvage. Without using a jammer, all 6 bots will be alerted simultaneously and come running right away.

[[Heading]]Exit Area[[/Heading]]
Same as the starting area, the only threat here is small groups of 3 Assembled.

[[Heading]]Golems[[/Heading]]
Golems are incredibly tanky enemies with an extreme damage output and the source of many lost runs. In order to claim a GOLEM Unit or the Exiles item, Cogmind must fight or at least run past them. With a 10% core exposure, 200 core integrity, and 15% damage resistance to non-melee damage types, trying to kill with core damage is completely impractical. The best approach is EM damage or Impact. Golems only require an average of 118 damage to corrupt them to death compared to thousands of damage with non-EM weapons. Using [[Zio. Weapon Casing|Weapon Casings]] looted earlier is helpful to preserve EM cannon integrity and avoid running out of weapons.
Due to uneven calculations for line-of-sight and weapon range, it is possible to shoot the Golems once before you are spotted at 16 range. See the Golem 1/2 spots below for reference. This allows Cogmind to wait 2 turns before shooting to avoid any movement accuracy penalties, since every turn counts particularly hard when fighting a Golem. If using EM traps, short ranged EM weapons, or Impact weapons, see the lure images for reference. This will get Cogmind spotted, likely get shot at for 1 volley, and then draw the Golem in closer. This can avoid misses or misfires opening the GOLEM Unit chambers and accidentally triggering the wall early. However, keep in mind that if Cogmind misses or if the Golem misfires into one of the chambers, the wall will open instantly. Luring the Golems out of range where they can attack the GOLEM Unit containers is recommended. The Exiles item will typically require fighting the top Golem, but getting a GOLEM unit typically requires fighting both Golems, or at least luring a Golem closer and grabbing the unit if it drops.
[[Gallery]]ZDC Golem Spot 1.png|16 range Golem 1 spot (safe with Cogmind misses)|ZDC Golem Spot 2.png|Golem 2 spot (unsafe with Cogmind misses)|ZDC Golem Lure 1.png|Golem lure 1|ZDC Golem Lure 2.png|Golem lure 2|ZDC Golem Trap 1.png|Golem trap 1|ZDC Golem Trap 2.png|Golem trap 2[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading]]Impregnable Wall[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]ZDC Wall Activation Zone.png|Approximate wall activation zone[[/Image]]
The Assembled wall is an indestructible wall containing 35 [[Assembled (4)|Assembled]] and 2 [[Assembler|Assemblers]] that will automatically open up when Cogmind gets too close to it, or if any of the GOLEM Unit chambers are destroyed. See the image on the right for a range reference. This range encompasses the GOLEM Unit containers, so fighting the wall is required to grab them.
Fighting the wall practically requires Launchers to avoid becoming overwhelmed. Any kinds of launchers work, although explosive launchers are better due to their higher base damage. Trying to use launchers at a range where they won't miss and take out the GOLEM unit containers is ideal. Otherwise it can be slightly annoying up to even deadly to have a large number of growing Golems running around. They grow slowly, but trying to deal with the Assembled and growing Golems at the same time can be a recipe for disaster. Alternately, the [[AS-neutralizer No. 17b]] can be used here to almost entirely eliminate any threat of the wall. The Assemblers will still need to be destroyed, but the rest of the Assembled will become useless.

[[Heading]]Loot[[/Heading]]
After everything else is cleaned out, all that's left is claiming the loot. Wall Chambers will drop [[GOLEM Unit|GOLEM Units]] when destroyed. They will turn into a Golem in a few turns, so grab them quickly. They can drop their GOLEM Unit upon being destroyed (standard loot rules), so applying positive and negative Salvage affects Golem reformation. Using melee weapons is recommended to avoid missing into other containers and spawning further Golems.
The Exiles item will normally require fighting both the wall and the top Golem. One alternative to grab it is using the Zion special item [[Phasing AFG]]. By using it, the item can be pulled in without any fighting on the left side of the map.

Other.Name: Style Achievements
Other.Content:
Style [[Achievements]] are earned by reaching high statistics in some categories which usually require using an associated playstyle, or by using some rare items and/or their mechanics. Most of them will be simply eventually be obtained by players as they become familiar with the more common mechanics of the game and figure out playstyles that utilizes them or discover some of the less common mechanics of the game. 12 of the 46 Style Achievements have hidden descriptions that are only revealed after completing them. The borders of Style Achievement indicate their difficulty compared to other achievements with similar[[Comment]]TODO: Figure out a way to say "Achievements with almost exactly the same requirements, with the only difference being that one achievement requires doing thing A while the more difficult achievement requires doing thing A+B.", but use fewer words to say this.[[/Comment]] requirements, with more "intense" borders meaning higher difficulty.

[[Comment]]This warning is supposed to be there for all articles about achievement types[[/Comment]]
(The visibility for the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements is set to at least "Spoilers", and may be set to "Redacted" for achievements where that would be relevant. Remember to change your spoilers settings to "None" if you do not wish to see the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements you have not yet obtained!)

[[Heading]]Combat[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Turtlemind: Have 2% or less core exposure.
|Can't Touch This: Absorb 1,500 damage using shields ([[Shield Generators]]/[[Force Fields]].
|Executioner: Have 7 weapon slots.
|Perfect Aim: Have +40% targeting accuracy for ranged weapons via utilities.
|More Dakka Please: Fire 10 kinetic projectiles in a single volley.
Strategy: Equip two "Flak" weapons and fire them both in one volley.
|Gunslinger: Destroy 3 robots with a single volley using secondary targeting.
|Gun Specialist: Destroy 100 hostiles with at least 90% of damage across an entire run dealt by guns.
|Cannon Specialist: Destroy 100 hostiles with at least 90% of damage across an entire run dealt by cannons.
|Launcher Specialist: Destroy 100 hostiles with at least 90% of damage across an entire run dealt by [[Launchers|launchers]].
|Melee Specialist: Destroy 100 hostiles with at least 90% of damage across an entire run dealt by melee weapons.
|Shocking Conclusion: [[Corruption|Corrupt]] 50 hostiles.
|Pyromaniac: Cause 20 hostiles to [[Meltdown|meltdown]].
|Guerrilla Style: Trigger reprogrammed (or placed) [[Traps|traps]] on 30 hostiles.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Various[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Tank: [[Spoiler]]Reach a mass of 150.[[/Spoiler]]
Strategy: Either wait for it to happen on its own while you're playing a heavy combat build, or equip either a [[Humpback]] or a [[Cargo Storage Unit]] and a few other parts.
|Friend Of Zion: [[Spoiler]]Summon 10 [[Imprint#roster_hacks|Zionite dispatches]].[[/Spoiler]]
|Heroic Deeds: [[Spoiler]]Summon a [[Z-Hero|Hero of Zion]].[[/Spoiler]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Flight/Hover[[/Heading]]

|Speed Demon: Reach a speed of 10 spaces per turn.
|Supersonic: Reach a speed of 20 spaces per turn.
Strategy: Only possible by having either at least 5 [[Overload#propulsion|overloaded]] [[Flight Units]] or 15 overloaded [[Hover Units]].
|Dodgeball, But With Guns: Reach 75% evasion.
[[/List]]

[[/List]]
