Other.Name: Surveillance Squad
Other.Content:
[[Image]]Surveillance Squad.png|A Watcher surveillance squad[[/Image]]
Surveillance squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that roam the map looking for hostiles to report to 0b10 combat bots. They consist only of a single [[Watcher]]. This is a [[W-16 Scout]] on -10 and -9, a [[W-25 Informer]] on -8 through -5, and a [[W-44 Eye]] on -4 through -1. They can be Enumerated at [[Terminal|Terminals]]. They patrol between two points at a slow pace, then turn back around when they reach the end. The [[Garrison Access]] hack [[Spoiler]]Trojan(Watchers)[[/Spoiler]] reports where all Watchers are at all times.

Other.Name: TF Node
Other.Content:
[[Image]]TF Node.png|A TF Node in a [[Factory]] junction[[/Image]]
TF Nodes are blue one-tile non-interactive machines that can appear in most [[0b10]]-controlled maps. They appear at junctions in locations similar to where [[Sentry|Sentries]] would be placed. They are more numerous in larger maps, although they are not guaranteed to be present on any given map. They serve no purpose when active, but they can drop [[Sensor Arrays]] and [[Signal Interpreters]] when destroyed. No parts may drop when destroyed, but usually at least one of the two will drop. The parts contained within depend on the depth:
[[Table]]
Depth/Map|Sensor Array|Signal Interpreter||
-10 to -9|[[Sensor Array]]|[[Signal Interpreter]]||
-8 to -5|[[Imp. Sensor Array]]|[[Imp. Signal Interpreter]]||
-4 to -1|[[Adv. Sensor Array]]|[[Adv. Signal Interpreter]]
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|TF Node[[/Lore]]

Other.Name: Terminal
Other.Content:
[[Image]]../game_sprites/Terminal.png|An 0b10-controlled Terminal[[/Image]]
Terminals are typically [[0b10]]-controlled [[Interactive Machine|Interactive Machines]] that [[Cogmind]] can hack for a large variety of benefits. Unlike other interactive machines, non-limited 0b10 Terminals do not list all possible "authorized" hacks and instead only show a selection of hacks chosen from a large pool. Hack not listed can still be indirectly hacked through manual hacking, though this will incur a -15% penalty per security level to the base success rate of hacks. Some [[Branch|Branches]] have [[Derelict]]-controlled Terminals. 0b10 Terminals are also sometimes guarded by an [[Operator]], which if alerted will lock down the Terminal and call for a [[Reinforcement Squad]] unless it or the Terminal is disabled/destroyed.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Terminal[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Types of 0b10 Terminals[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Type|Average Size|Armor|Direct hacks|Other Notes||
Standard security level 1|Small|18|Few available direct hacks|N/A||
2|Medium|25|More available direct hacks|N/A||
3|Large|30|Lots of available direct hacks|N/A||
Terminals inside [[Garrison|Garrisons]]|Small|18|One of Access(Emergency), Download(Navigation), Download(Registry), or Download(Security)|Terminal is always security level 2||
Door-type/Lore Terminals|1 tile|18|Usually one direct hack, to open the relevant door or get relevant lore record|Terminal is always security level 1||
Cave outpost Terminal|1 tile|18|Random mix of flavor (useless) and intel "Report" hacks, with flavor reports always grouped on top of the list and intel reports grouped on the bottom of the list ending in X|Terminal is always security level 1
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Hacks[[/Heading]]
[[Hacks]]Terminal[[/Hacks]]

[[Heading:2]]Operator [[Data Core]][[/Heading]]
Moving over a destroyed Operator's Data Core will automatically collect and it extract its dynamic key, which provides a one-time bonus that multiplies to the base success rate of all direct and indirect hacks by 1.5 if their base success rate was positive, or raise the base success rate to 0% if it was negative. The dynamic key can only be used within 40 turns before it expires at its Operator's Terminal.

[[Heading:2]][[Multitool]][[/Heading]]
Using a Multitool on a Terminal's interactive tile removes all direct hacks and causes tracing to begin immediately, but applies a modifier to indirect hacks. This modifier can range from -20% to +50%. Multitool is best used with a lot of [[Defensive Hackware]] to increase the number of hacks that can be safely performed after modification.
[[Heading:2]]Central database authorization[[/Heading]]
Indirect hacks for lore records, prototype IDs, part or robot schematics, and robot analyses, are all considered "database hacks". Successfully hacking any of them has a base 25% chance to instead cause a map-wide central database lockout, preventing further indirect database hacks. However, direct hacks of those types remain possible after a central database lockout, and they cannot cause one in the first place. The first indirect database hack on a map cannot cause a database lockout.
Not all lore records, parts schematic, robot analyses or robot schematics can be indirectly hacked on all Terminals. Terminals have a level of database authorization dependent on security level and current depth, equal to (10 - current depth + security level). It is only possible to indirectly hack a part/robot schematic or analysis if the Terminal's authorization level is equal to or higher than the rating/tier of the relevant part/robot (prototype parts are considered to have a +1 to their rating for this purpose).
For example, at -5/Factory, level 2 Terminals have an authorization level of (10 - 5 + 2) = 7, which would allow hacking for standard rating 7 parts or prototype rating 6 parts.
Lore records also have a hidden rating/tier stat. This value can only be determined by attempting and failing to access a particular record.
[[Heading:2]]Additional Details/Usage Tips[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:3]]Grayed Out Direct Hacks[[/Heading]]
[[GameText]][Local Emergency Access][[/GameText]], [[GameText]][Purge Alert][[/GameText]] and all [[GameText]][Traps][[/GameText]] hacks appear greyed out in direct hacks if they are currently useless. In other words, if a Terminal has a greyed out direct [[GameText]][Locate Traps][[/GameText]] hack, then there are no traps within the Terminal's range.
[[Heading:3]]Grouped Direct Hacks[[/Heading]]
If either [[GameText]][Disarm Traps][[/GameText]] or [[GameText]][Reprogram Traps][[/GameText]] is available as a direct hack, then [[GameText]][Locate Traps][[/GameText]] will also be a direct hack on that Terminal. If [[GameText]][Purge Alert][[/GameText]] is available as a direct hack, then [[GameText]][Check Alert][[/GameText]] will also be a direct hack on that Terminal. If there is a direct [[GameText]][Recall][[/GameText]] hack available, then the corresponding [[GameText]][Status][[/GameText]] hack will also be available on that Terminal.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Access(Branch)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
Certain branch entrances are not revealed by this hack because they are either unknown to 0b10 or considered more secret/secure. The full list of these branches is: [[Lab]], [[Protoforge]], [[Section 7]], [[Scraptown]] and [[Subcaves]].
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Access(Emergency)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This hack reveals emergency accesses within a radius of 20 tiles of the Terminal. Within a Garrison, this reveals all emergency accesses as well as phase walls throughout the entire map.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Alert(Check)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
[[Alert]] is reported in the alphabet form rather than as the exact precise number. For example, the Terminal reports alert level 1-A at 200 influence.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Alert(Purge)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
The base success rate of this hack goes down by 10% after each successful hack. This reduction only applies for the current map.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Enumerate()[[/GameText]] Hacks[[/Heading]]
Enumerate hacks reveal the current position of all bots of the matching type across the map. These positions can be enabled/disabled in the intel console window. These positions will not update in realtime. If the hack is performed again, all existing intel positions of the same type will be cleared before being added again, so the intel does not stack.
[[Spoiler]][[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Force(Sabotage)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
Adds an additional 50 alert if the hack succeeds but is unsuccessful in sabotaging a machine. Adds 100 alert if the hack succeeds and sabotages a machine. Additional alert from the explosive machine does not get added like when Cogmind shoots a machine to blow it up. This can reduce alert gained in maps with huge explosive machines such as [[Hub_04(d)]]. In fact, Hub is the best place to use this hack, as blowing up a random machine is seldom useful in most other maps, and the only valid targets within the map are the Network Hubs themselves.[[/Spoiler]]
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Layout(zone)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
Reveals an the map in a 32x32 area around the map. That is, 16 tiles in each cardinal direction from the center tile of the Terminal.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Inventory()[[/GameText]] Hacks[[/Heading]]
All stockpiles matching the hack type on the floor are revealed. This is all groups of items within a 2x2-3x3 area, even if not all tiles in the square are filled out. Occasionally, a stockpile named after one item only actually has one of that item and has other different parts. This data can be enabled/disabled in the intel console window.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Prototypes[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
The number of prototype IDs received is 2 on a security level 1 terminal, 3 on a level 2, and 4 on a level 3. Duplicate prototype IDs cannot be received from a single hack. This hack is never grayed out as a direct hack, even if no new prototype IDs are available.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Recall()[[/GameText]] Hacks[[/Heading]]
The base success rate of these hacks go down by 10% after each successful hack. This only applies to hacks of the same type, not all Recall hacks. This reduction only applies for the current map.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Schematic()[[/GameText]] Hacks[[/Heading]]
Direct schematic hacks may contain parts/bots with a rating/tier up to 2 higher than that of the base floor. For example, in -7 Factory, standard floor parts may be rating 4, but schematics up to rating 6 may be offered.
When entering a map, if you already have a schematic that's supposed to appear on a Terminal, that schematic hack may be re-rolled.[[Sup]][[Terminal#references|[1]]][[/Sup]]

[[Heading]]References[[/Heading]]
[[List:Ordered]]
[[https://www.gridsagegames.com/blog/2018/11/debugging-mapgen-seed-divergence/|Kyzrati's blog]]: "recalling that schematic hacks at Terminals would favor the player by usually re-rolling if the randomly chosen schematic happened to be one they already had."[[/List]]

Other.Name: Terminology
Other.Content:
This is a list of terminology, or potentially things that do not merit a full page. Also check out [[Acronyms]].
[[Heading:3]]Partial Spot[[/Heading]]
Partial spotting is when you move through a (hostile) bots field of vision while its not its turn. The bot will investigate where it saw you, look a few tiles further then head back to whatever it was doing.

Other.Name: Transport Squad
Other.Content:
[[Image]]Transport Squad.png|A Hauler guarded by 2 Grunts[[/Image]]
Transport squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that carry parts from one location to another and can be found on most 0b10 controlled maps. They typically consist of a single [[Hauler]] and 0-2 guard [[Grunt|Grunts]] that escort them. Haulers that are guarded have [[Prototype Part|prototypes]] inside them, but some unguarded Haulers may still have prototype parts. If a Hauler that carries prototype parts is attacked, they will summon a [[Reinforcement Squad]] to their location on depths -7 and higher. Typical transport squads all start on the map, and more of them do not appear if destroyed. Transport squads can be Enumerated at [[Terminal|Terminals]], and a [[Transport Network Coupler]] or [[Modified TNC]] will reveal their current positions. The Modified TNC will also show the contents of all Haulers. Similarly, the Manifests hack shows all of the contents of all Haulers on the map, as well as any associated guards. This can be useful to determine that certain guarded/unguarded Haulers are worthwhile to try to loot. The 

[[Heading]]Transport Contents[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Depth|Grunt|Hauler||
-10|[[G-34 Mercenary]]|[[A-02 Transporter]]||
-9|G-34 Mercenary|A-02 Transporter||
-8|[[G-47 Trooper]]|A-02 Transporter||
-7|G-47 Trooper|A-02 Transporter||
-6|[[G-50 Soldier]]|[[A-15 Conveyor]]||
-5|G-50 Soldier|A-15 Conveyor||
-4|[[G-67 Veteran]]|A-15 Conveyor||
-3|G-67 Veteran|A-15 Conveyor||
-2|[[G-73 Enforcer]]|A-15 Conveyor||
-1|G-73 Enforcer|A-15 Conveyor
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Frequency[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Map|Number of patrols||
-10 [[Materials]]|2||
-9 Materials|6||
-8 Materials|6||
-7 [[Factory]]|8||
-6 Factory|8||
-5 Factory|10||
-4 Factory|10||
-3 [[Research]]|10||
-2 Research|10||
-1 [[Access]]|12||
[[Storage]]|6||
[[Extension]]|Varying, they come from Transfer Stations||
[[Hub_04(d)]]|6||
[[Testing]]|2||
[[Quarantine]]|2||
[[Section 7]]|6
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]][[Cargo Convoy]][[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Cargo Convoy.png[[/Image]]
Cargo Convoys are a unique type of transport squad that appear in main [[Factory]] and [[Research]] maps. They are much more heavily guarded than typical Transport squads, but the parts they carry are also much higher rating than usual. If attacked, they will trigger a special response where [[Heavy|Heavies]] guard all of the exits on the map.

Other.Name: Warlord (Alignment)
Other.Content:
Aligning with [[Warlord]] is one of the major faction [[Alignment|alignments]] available to Cogmind in a run and can be done in his [[Warlord (Location)|Base]] in either -5 or -4 [[Upper Caves]]. Aligning with Warlord has effects on 2 major events later in the game. It triggers an event where Warlord, [[God Mode]], and friendly [[Derelict|Derelicts]] assault -2 [[Research]]. It also has a lategame effect in [[Command]]: [[Redacted]]When opening the Command seals, [[Warlord (Command)]] will appear along with a group of other friendly Derelicts.[[/Redacted]]
One Warlord alignment-related item is the [[Encrypted Comm Array]]. If Cogmind either compromises [[Garrison|Garrison]] or [[Sterilization|sterilizes]] [[DSF|DSFs]], Cogmind can receive the Comm Array and learn the depth of Warlord's base. If enough assistance is provided, a force multiplier can provide allies during the -2 assault and in the [[Redacted]]Command Seals[[/Redacted]]. After seeing Warlord in his base, the Comm Array is no longer of any use.

[[Heading]]Restrictions[[/Heading]]
Cogmind cannot align with Warlord in the following scenarios:
[[List]][[RIF]] is installed - The base will be hostile to Cogmind upon entering the base|Attacking [[Scraptown]] - The base will be hostile to Cogmind upon entry|[[Imprint]] - Warlord will be disappointed in Cogmind|[[UFD]] - Warlord will think Cogmind is a spy[[/List]]

[[Heading]]-2 Research Assault[[/Heading]]
The event will begin with the alert [[GameText]]ALERT: Engineering response network critical failure, offline[[/GameText]]. More announcements will show up, but the next most important one will be [[GameText]]Warlord currently on norther/central/southern western approach. All units hit designated targets[[/GameText]] which indicates where Warlord and [[God Mode]] will appear on the map. 50 turns after entering the map, another announcement [[GameText]]Trap arrays successfully disabled[[/GameText]] will come with all traps being removed from the map. 110 after entering the maps, [[GameText]]Machine network successfully disabled[[/GameText]] will indicate that every machine on the map is now shut down except for [[Garrison Access|Garrisons]] due to the follow-up message [[GameText]]Unrecognized interference restored Garrison access controls. Oops. Just blast them.[[/GameText]] 250 turns after entering the map and every 150 turns after that, 3 different assault squad spawns will appear from Garrisons and map exits with the message [[GameText]]Unaware assault squad dispatched in northeast/southeast/southwest/northwest quadrant.[[/GameText]] The spawn location will be indicated on the map. Every 100 turns 1 Derelict squad will spawn on the left side of the map for each tunnel. After 1000 turns on the map, Warlord will tell Cogmind that it is time to retreat and to open the [[Redacted]]Cave Seals in [[Command]] for the final push. He, or a random Derelict if Warlord is not within range, will also give Cogmind a manual hack that can be applied to open the Cave Seals without any need for hackware.[[/Redacted]]
[[Heading:2]]Downside of event[[/Heading]]
As a result of the Warlord assault, additional patrols will be dispatched in [[Testing]], [[Quarantine]], and [[Access]]. Patrols will increase by 40% in these maps. This is most significant in Access, upping the Patrol count from 20 to 28. A few Warlord bots will also appear at the entrance to these maps.
[[Image]]Research Warlord Squads.png|A few Derelict squads[[/Image]]

[[Heading]]Derelict Forces[[/Heading]]
The Derelict forces consist of many unique bots during this event. All of them appear as non-controllable allies that do not generate any alert for Cogmind. There are 3 spawn points in the form of giant tunnels. Each tunnel is dug out by a [[Borebot]] escorted by 2 [[Samaritan|Samaritans]]. They will dig straight across the map to the right side. Tiles that are dug out by Borebots are safe to travel on and will not cave-in. Warlord attack squads can vary greatly in composition but are made up of the following bots:
[[List]][[Butcher (7)|Butchers]]|[[Commander|Commanders]]|[[Dragon|Dragons]]|[[Fireman (7)|Firemen]]|[[Guerrilla (7)|Guerrillas]]|[[Hydra|Hydras]]|[[Knight]]|[[Marauder (8)|Marauders]]|[[Martyr (7)|Martyrs]]|[[Savage (7)|Savages]]|[[Thug (7)|Thugs]]|[[Troll|Trolls]]|[[Wasp (7)|Wasps]]|[[Wizard (7)|Wizards]][[/List]]
[[Image]]Research Warlord Assault Squads.png|0b10 Warlord response assault squad[[/Image]]The 0b10 forces come in groups of 3 bots. There are always 2 (not necessarily of the same type) of [[Executioner]], [[Striker]], and [[D-83 Annihilator]] bots along with a [[C-30 ARC|ARC]] full of bots. They roam around the map looking for bots to fight.
[[Heading:2]][[DD-05H]][[/Heading]]
Sometimes DD-05H will appear a few hundred turns into the invasion. It will run toward Warlord and then follow Warlord around for the duration of the event. When this happens, the [[Tinkerer]] PL-HR7 will also appear at one of the invasion entrances on the left side of the map. PL-HR7 will drop a [[Warlord Statue]] that Cogmind can use.

[[Heading]]Encrypted Comm Array[[/Heading]]
If Cogmind has aided Warlord forces by compromising Garrisons and DSFs, Cogmind may get 1 or 2 additional special escort squads based on the force multiplier. These special squads will head straight to Cogmind's location and follow. The higher the force multiplier, the stronger the squads available for escort. The special squads are as follows:
[[List]]Bridgeowners Association: Trolls|Cat Herders: Wasps|Death Star: Martyrs|Department No. 42: Firemen|Offensive Angels: Wasps|Golden Rifles: Commanders, Geurrillas, Surgeons, and Thugs|Grunt Murderers: Thugs|Gunslingers: Guerrillas|Lair Dwellers: Hydras|Lobotomizers: Wizards|Lucky Slug: Marauders|Magnificent Bastards: Mutants|Metalheads: Mutants|Knights of the Pentagonal Table: Knights|Railsplitters: Guerrillas|Shockpunchers: Wizards|Smaug Morners: Dragons|The Professionals: Commanders, Guerrillas, Knights, Surgeons, Trolls, and Wizards|Vikings: Butchers|Viscera Detail: Butchers and Savages[[/List]]
This event tends to be great for Cogmind. The primary downsides is that the machine network turns off relatively early into the event and locating the desired exit can be a pain. Getting stuck in a bad position without any Derelict allies can also be painful since the assaults, particularly the prototype bots and demolishers, pack quite a punch. However, the large number of alert-free allies and free loot from the bots fighting is great to any build. Like the Revision 17 event, this event will also cause the maps to have no Heavies. Finding any exit is usually possible by following the assault dispatch notifications. Assaults will be dispatched out of any Garrison or exit. The only exits that assaults do not come from are Quarantine prefab exits. In that case, using other infowar like terrain scanning and drones is the best way to locate these exits.

Other.Name: Wins Achievements
Other.Content:
Wins [[Achievements]] are earned by winning the game under certain conditions. 10 of the 37 Wins Achievements have hidden descriptions that are only revealed after completing them. The borders of Wins Achievements indicate whether they are earned by winning with a specific ending, winning under certain conditions, or winning while a challenge mode is active. The borders of Achievements for winning under certain conditions also indicate their difficulty compared to other achievements with similar requirements, with more "intense" borders meaning higher difficulty.


[[Comment]]This warning is supposed to be there for all articles about achievement types, including those that do not have any Redacted-level spoilers.[[/Comment]]
(The visibility for the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements is set to at least "Spoilers", and may be set to "Redacted" for achievements where that would be relevant. Remember to change your spoilers settings to "None" if you do not wish to see the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements you have not yet obtained!)

Warning: The writer of this article has not yet earned the "Stardust", "Winner's Signature", "Data Run" or "By A Hair" Achievements, and as such their descriptions in this page is a (probably accurate) guess instead of being the official description.

[[Heading]]Endings[[/Heading]]
These Achievements are earned by winning the game with a specific ending. Currently, only 7 of the 9 endings have Achievements tied to them. Each ending is mutually exclusive with all other endings, meaning only one of these achievements can be obtained per run.

[[List]]Epsilon Run: [[Spoiler]]Win and escape to Epsilon Eridani.[[/Spoiler]]
|Commander 0b11: [[Redacted]]Win and begin establishing 0b11[[/Redacted]].
|Home At Last?: [[Spoiler]]Win and rendezvous with the fleet.[[/Spoiler]]
|Payload Armed: [[Spoiler]]Win and nuke Complex 0b10 from orbit.[[/Spoiler]]
|MAIN.CPP: [[Redacted]]Win and take control of Complex 0b10.[[/Redacted]]

|Stardust: [[Redacted]]Win and destroy Tau Ceti IV.[[/Redacted]]

Once the description is corrected, please remember to delete the warning for it at the top of the page.[[/Comment]]

|Planet Killer: [[Redacted]]Win and escape the artificial singularity.[[/Redacted]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Winning with challenge modes[[/Heading]]
These achievements are unlocked by winning the game with any ending while their respective challenge mode is active. Challenge modes are activated by starting a new run while the corresponding challenge mode option in the advanced.cfg file is set to 1.

When the next batch of achievements is eventually added, Challenge mode Achievements be removed.

[[List]]
Grand Amoeba: Win the Devolution challenge mode.
|Look Ma, No Swapping!: Win the Fragile Parts challenge mode.
|Unstoppable: Win the Gauntlet challenge mode.
|Stunt Win: Win the Inhibited Evolution challenge mode.
|I Don't Need Leftovers: Win the No Salvage challenge mode.
|Light Traveler: Win the Pure Core challenge mode.
|This Only Looks Like Junk: Win the Scavenger challenge mode.
|Terminals Are For Geeks: Win the Simple Hacker challenge mode.
|Attach With Care: Win the Sticky Parts challenge mode.
|Best of the Best: Win the Super Gauntlet challenge mode.
|Master Trapper: Win the Trapped challenge mode.
|Super Mutant: Win the Unstable Evolution challenge mode.[[/List]]

Other.Name: Wintypes
Other.Content:
W0 "Escaped": Take a [[Surface]] exit on -1.
W1 [[Redacted]]"Establishing 0b11": Take a Surface exit on -1 after destroying both phases of [[MAIN.C]] in [[Command]].[[/Redacted]]
W2 [[Spoiler]]"Heading to fleet": Take a surface exit on -1 after using a [[Core Reset Matrix]].[[/Spoiler]]
W3 [[Spoiler]]"Destroyed 0b10": Take a Surface exit on -1 while carrying the [[Sigix Containment Pod]] in inventory. [[Redacted]]May also be performed by taking the exit with the [[Sigix Warrior]].[[/Redacted]][[/Spoiler]]
W4 [[Redacted]]"Assimilated 0b10": Stand next to the unbroken 0b10 Conduit machine in MAIN.C's room in Command after either killing both forms of MAIN.C or with [[RIF]].[[/Redacted]]
W5 [[Redacted]]"Destroyed Tau Ceti IV": In [[Access_0]], obtain the [[A2 Data Core]] by killing [[A2]] and perform Gate Tests 138-A and 138-B once, then test 138-C twice on the Gate Controls terminal with an intact Singularity Gate machine.[[/Redacted]]
W6 [[Redacted]]"Escaped singularity": In Access_0, destroy all 4 Subspace Access Nodes, destroy the [[Architect]], and take the surface exit within 10 turns.[[/Redacted]]
W7 [[Redacted]]"Establishing Free Derelict Territories": In Command, destroy both forms of MAIN.C with [[Warlord]] still alive and not shut down.[[/Redacted]]
W8 [[Redacted]]"Fortifying 0b10": Choose the Surrender option after destroying MAIN.C's outer shell, then destroy enough [[Enhanced Q-Series]] while keeping MAIN.C alive.[[/Redacted]]
W9 [[Redacted]]Defending 0bPrime: Align with [[UFD]] and [[Optimus]] in [[Scraptown]], install [[GameText]]Force(Fedlink)[[/GameText]] in [[Protoforge]], and help plant 10 [[UFD Drillbomb|UFD Drillbombs]].[[/Redacted]]

Other.Name: YASD
Other.Content:
"Yet Another Stupid Death (commonly abbreviated to YASD) is used when a player has done something, usually avoidable, that leads to their hero's demise." - [[https://nethackwiki.com/wiki/Yet_Another_Stupid_Death|NetHack Wiki]]

Cogmind is full of silly ways to die. Here are just a few. A lot of them are harsh teachers of lessons best learned the hard way.

Note: this page is heavily opinion-based; your mileage may vary.

[[Heading]]General[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Trying to run away or reposition with slow movement speed, either because you missed the warning or because you think you know better. When the game says [[GameText]]MOVEMENT SPEED EXTREMELY SLOW![[/GameText]] in all caps, take heed.
|Fighting next to a bunch of explosive machines. Or in the middle of a bunch of explosive machines. They seem to always explode when you're within range.
|Fighting next to a bunch of explosive machines, but with a melee weapon! Too bad it does knockback... BOOM
|Actually fighting a bunch of explosive machines, for example, because you forgot to turn off Force Melee before moving in one's direction.
|Digging too far and getting crushed by a cave-in. Sometimes it's worth rolling the dice.
|Attaching a risky prototype that fries a vital part.
|Forgetting to watch your heat. It does core damage if it gets too high...
|Forgetting to watch your corruption.
|Getting your squishy [[Infowar]] destroyed because you forget to swap it out in combat.
|Spending too much time around a [[Heavy]], especially as a frail flight build.
|In general, getting spotted on a fragile build by bots you can't outrun (think [[Swarmer|Swarmers]], [[Programmer|Programmers]], and especially [[Cutter|Cutters]]).
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Location-Specific[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Going to the [[Mines]] without a launcher. [[GameText]]Infestation in the Mines, dispatching Demolisher squad.[[/GameText]]
|Going to the [[Subcaves]] unprepared.
|Going to the Subcaves unprepared, "but I got swarmed last time, so this time I'll bring a launcher!"
|Forgetting that parts self-destruct in the [[Caves]]. Hope you brought spares.
|Misfiring in a Caves branch, aggroing the inhabitants. Bonus points if it's [[Zion]] or [[Warlord (Location)]] and you [[I]]almost[[/I]] made it to the [[Spoiler]]Quarantine Array[[/Spoiler]].
|Visiting [[Zion]] or [[Warlord (Location)]] when you have [[RIF]].
|Aggroing the friends of [[Warlord]] while you fight off the [[Spoiler]]0b10 invasion[[/Spoiler]].
|Killing or trying to kill [[Data Miner]] and accidentally sitting in the [[Spoiler]]gamer chair, i.e., Data Conduit[[/Spoiler]]. [[Spoiler]][[Tracker|Trackers]] can be dealt with, if you're prepared.[[/Spoiler]]
|Going too far in the [[Zion Deep Caves]] without a plan to deal with [[Golem|what's inside]].
|The many ways of going into [[Testing]] or [[Quarantine]] on [[FarCom]] (unless you're prepared, of course). Perhaps you needed to desperately dive for an exit. Perhaps you forgot the [[Exiles (Group)|Exiles']] warning. Or perhaps you chose to roll the dice.
|Having a bot destroy the terminal at the [[Surface]] exit in [[Access]]. The closer you were to the terminal, the sillier it is.
[[/List]]

Other.Name: Zhirov (Alignment)
Other.Content:
[[Image]]Testing SGEMP.png|The SGEMP room in Testing[[/Image]]
Aligning with [[Zhirov]] is a minor [[Alignment|alignment]] that can be started in [[Zhirov (Location)|Zhirov's Lab]]. After entering and exiting the Terminal room on the left side of the map, Zhirov will ask Cogmind to steal the [[SGEMP Prototype]] from [[Testing]] and bring it to [[Access]]. If this is done, Zhirov, Perun, and Svarog will show up in Access and give Cogmind full map intel. They will follow Cogmind but will all teleport out if Zhirov falls below roughly half core integrity. They also leave if Cogmind enters [[Command]]. If a [[Core Reset Matrix]] is used prior to Access but Cogmind still carries the SGEMP, Zhirov and his allies will turn hostile and fight Cogmind to the death
There is a second part of this quest that continues in [[Command]]. [[Redacted]][[Image]]ModifiedSGEMP.gif|Zhirov detonating the modified SGEMP in Command, disabling MAIN.C[[/Image]]
After destroying the first form of [[MAIN.C (Shell)|MAIN.C]] in Command, Zhirov, Perun, and Svarog will show up and attack MAIN.C. Zhirov will activate the Modified SGEMP and disable all 0b10-aligned bots on the map. This also affects [[Warlord (Command)]], but no other Derelicts. This does stop Cogmind from getting the score bonuses of defeating [[MAIN.C]], as well as the + on the scoresheet.[[/Redacted]]
